qVOmjra1.title: Influence of altered coagulation and fibrinolysis status on disease activity of inflammatory bowel disease
qVOmjra1.abstract: Objectives To evaluate altered coagulation and fibrinolysis status,and to analysis factors associated with disease activity in active patients with inflammatory bowel disease.Methods A cohort of 271 consecutive patients with active IBD was compared with healthy controls for coagulation and fibrinolysis status.Analyses were done to elucidate the associations between altered coagulation and fibrinolysis status stratified by gender and inflammatory parameters.Results The mean levels of platelet,platelet distribution width,prothrombin time,fibrinogen,activated partial thromboplastin time were significantly higher in male or female patients with Crohn's disease(CD) or ulcerative colitis(UC) than that in controls(all P<0.05),whereas mean platelet volume was lower(P<0.01).Furthermore,linear regression indicated that fibrinogen was an independent predictor of ESR(β=1.316,P=0.000) and CRP(β=1.233,P=0.015) in male patients with active UC.And Crohn's Disease Activity Index was predicted by platelet(β=0.436,P=0.037) and prothrombin time(β=0.810,P=0.000) in female patients with CD.Conclusion It is suggested that in IBD patients,abnormalities in coagulation and fibrinolysis status were associated with disease activity.Fibrinogen,platelet and prothrombin time were predictors of inflammatory parameters.

XmFtK6ZY.title: A special material or a new state of matter: A review and reconsideration of the aerogel
XmFtK6ZY.abstract: The ultrahighly nanoporous aerogel is recognized as a state of matter rather than as a functional material, because of its qualitative differences in bulk properties, transitional density and enthalpy between liquid and gas, and diverse chemical compositions. In this review, the characteristics, classification, history and preparation of the aerogel were introduced. More attention was paid to the sol-gel method for preparing different kinds of aerogels, given its important role on bridging the synthetic parameters with the properties. At last, preparation of a novel single-component aerogel, design of a composite aerogel and industrial application of the aerogel were regarded as the research tendency of the aerogel state in the near future. © 2013 by the authors.

qDwTljaL.title: A Data Dependency and Access Threshold Based Replication Strategy for Multi-cloud Workflow Applications.
qDwTljaL.abstract: Data replication is one of the significant sub-areas of data management in cloud based workflows. Data-intensive workflow applications can gain great benefits from cloud environments and usually need data management strategies to manage large amounts of data. At the same time, multi-cloud environments become more and more popular. We propose a cost-effective and threshold-based data replication strategy with the consideration of both data dependency and data access times for data-intensive workflows in the multi-cloud environment. Finally, the simulation results show that our approach can greatly reduce total cost of data-intensive workflow applications by considering both of data dependency and data access times in multi-cloud environments.

bNprUU14.title: Research of Telecom IPv6 Network Assurance System
bNprUU14.abstract: With the launch of next-generation network researching and building based on IPv6,the process of telecom IPv4 network migrating to IPv6 network is accelerated,and IPv6 security issues have been putting on the agenda.In this paper,combining with IPv6 protocol security features,we analyze the security risks existing in telecom IPv6 network.On this basis,we investigate the key elements and components of telecom IPv6 network assurance system,and propose the building strategy of telecom IPv6 network assurance system.

aWkrgKpV.title: Study on content of iodine in food in Tianjin market and iodine nutrition conditions among college students]
aWkrgKpV.abstract: To know about content of iodine in foods sold in Tianjing markets presently, and the iodine nutrition conditions in college students. It was also aimed to probe the functions of the iodized salt complement with the dietary iodine intake, and whether the urine iodine could reflect dietary iodine intake.278 food samples in markets were collected by a randomly stratified sampling method, while the arsenic-cerium catalytic contact method was used to determine the content in food. The dietary information of students for seven days was recorded, and the urine iodine was determined through the arsenic-cerium catalytic spectrophotometry.The determination of 47 kinds and 278 food samples indicated that the content of iodine within animal foods (7.8 microg/100 g - 30.8 microg/100 g) was higher than that within plant foods (1.8 microg/100 g - 16.1 microg/100 g). The investigation also showed that students who regarded vegetarian food as principle accounted for 70. 19%. The amount of dietary iodine intake among those students, based on the dietary survey, was (111.67 +/- 53.18) microg/d, while supplementary iodine from iodized salt was about (230.27 +/- 45.55) microg/d. Therefore, the total iodine provided from diet would be (341.95 +/- 89.58) microg/d. Modified by urine creatinine, the median of urine iodine was 271.28 microg/gCr, and the urine iodine and dietary iodine intake was found positively related (r(s) = 0.463, P < 0.01).Regarding the vegetarian food as the principle, most of students investigated are not rich. The dietary iodine intake is lower than RDA (150 microg), but it can be obtained the iodized salt by 230. 27 microg, which is the possible supplement to the shortage from foods.

l25Dbwyu.title: THE SEISMOGENIC TECTONICS OF THE M_S 6.8 BACHU-JIASHI,XINJIANG EARTHQUAKE IN FEB.24, 2003
l25Dbwyu.abstract: The M_ S 6.8 Bachu-Jiashi earthquake of Feb.24, 2003 occurred in the western Tarim Basin and is possibly the continuation of the Jiashi strong earthquake swarms in 1997—1998. However, its focal mechanism and rupture process are different from that of the Jiashi strong earthquake swarms, according to our preliminary study on its seismic tectonics with geomorphologic information from satellite images, the deep structures from the petroleum seismic exploration, the macro damage and isoseismic features from field investigation, the relocation of the epicenters of the aftershocks, and the regional seismic tectonics from both deep and surface tectonics. The occurrence of the M_ S 6.8 Bachu-Jiashi earthquake is closely related with the revealed reverse fault on the Maigaiti slope belt between the Bachu uplift and Kashi depression in western Tarim Basin. The sites of the ground fissures found in the field fit with the revealed reverse fault. Isoseismal features are also corresponding to the rupture direction of the fault. These evidences indicate that the M_ S 6.8 Bachu-Jiashi earthquake is the result of the southward rupturing from deep to shallow along a north-dipping reverse fault in Tarim Basin. This reverse fault is possibly the result of the propagation of the thrust fault-fold system named Kalpintag thrust belt in the front of Tianshan.

f1qCMtym.title: A New Model for Microstructure of Liquid Metals
f1qCMtym.abstract: A nanocrystalline model for microstructures of liquid metals is constructed. According to the nanocrystalline model, the intensity curves of x-ray diffraction (XRD) on liquid Cu, Al and Al 65Cu 20Fe 15 alloy are derived by broadening the XRD peaks of these metals in some crystal structures. These broadening intensity curves are identical with the results measured by an x-ray diffractometer on these liquid metals. The present results indicate that the nanocrystal model may be helpful to understand the microstructures of liquid metals and that there is a close correlation between the short-range orders (SROs) of these liquid metals and some crystal lattice structures. That is, the SRO structures of liquid Cu, Al and Al 65Cu 20Fe 15 alloy are fcc, bcc and icosahedron, respectively.

4aUkNyUG.title: Microstructural evolution of directionally solidified Ni-based superalloy DZ125 under planar growth
4aUkNyUG.abstract: By using liquid metal cooling method, the Ni-based superalloy DZ125 was directionally solidified under planar interface growth condition of drawing rate of 1.5μm/s. The microstructures at different solidified fractions were examined by OM and SEM. The results showed that the solid/liquid interface is planar and the microstructure evolution undergoes three stages: the γ phase was formed as solidified fraction (f s) was below 0.26, and the fine HfC phase sparsely distributed in γ matrix; the coupled γ/MC growth appeared as f s ranged from 0.26 to 0.86, and the morphology of MC was fibrous or plate-like shapes; the γ/γ eutectic was obtained as f s was more than and equaled 0.86 0.86, in which the octahedral MC was precipitated simultaneously. EPMA was used to determine the solute distribution along the longitudinal direction of the sample. The contents of Al, Ti, Ta and Mo increased with f s increasing, while the contents of W, Cr and Co decreased. The analysis showed that the microstructure transformation is attributed to macro-scale non-uniform solute distribution which resulted from solute redistribution during directional solidification. © Copyright.

Fn4nvURd.title: A TiAl based alloy with excellent mechanical performance prepared by gas atomization and spark plasma sintering
Fn4nvURd.abstract: Ti-46.15Al-1.87Cr-2.1Nb-(B, Si, Y) alloying powders were fabricated by gas atomization process and then consolidated by spark plasma sintering (SPS). The SPSed TiAl alloy exhibited finer grain microstructure and enhanced mechanical properties than as-cast alloy. The results indicate that TiAl alloys fabricated by the SPS process could open possibilities of application as structural materials offering fine microstructure and excellent properties. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. nnf9Gz63.title: Influence and distribution of CD133 and CD34 antigen expression in proximal tubule epithelial cells during ischemia/reperfusion injury in rats]
nnf9Gz63.abstract: To study the influence and distribution in proximal tubule epithelial cells with the expressions of CD133 and CD34 in a rat model so as to provide a study basis for renal adult stem cell.The kidney ischemia/reperfusion model was established by blocking the bilateral renal arteries for about 50 min and recovering the renal perfusion of blood. Then the rat kidneys were extracted at Days 3, 5 and 7 post-modeling. After a series of special treatment, immunohistochemical staining was used to show the distribution and expression intensity of KIM-1, Brdu antigen, CD34 and CD133 antigens in cells with the elapsing of time.As compared with control group, the KIM-1 and CD133 antigens were present in cortex renis while the CD34 and Brdu antigens were distributed in parts of medulla renis and juncture of cortex-medulla renis. The expression density value of KIM-1 and CD133 antigens rose for the first 3 days then declined afterward (40.3% ± 3.2%, 57.5% ± 3.8%, 24.3% ± 1.4%). Otherwise the expression density value of CD 34 antigen declined (56.0% ± 4.8%, 44.2% ± 2.2%, 28.8% ± 1.0%) and Brdu antigen showed an upward trend at post-operation (10.0% ± 1.1%, 36.0% ± 4.2%, 48.8% ± 5.0%).After ischemia/reperfusion injury in kidney, the expression rates of CD133 and KIM-1 antigen rise obviously in cortex renis. And the D34 and Brdu antigens show a similar trend in medulla renis. The result indicates that the phenomenon of proliferation and differentiation may appears in kidney proximal tubule and migrate from the region of medulla renis to cortex renis. The participating cells not only possess the strong proliferation and repairing ability of stem/progenitor cells, but also can expresses the CD34 and CD133 antigens. Thus it is may provide a study basis for the tissue reconstruction of nephron and research in the field of kidney adult stem cell.

q5Jl16OX.title: Multiplication of shear bands and ductility of metallic glass
q5Jl16OX.abstract: The authors find that metallic glass can be controlled to create regularly arrayed fine multiple shear bands under small punch test, indicating that metallic glass essentially has a good plastic deformation ability and thus high ductility under suitable loading condition. The current findings imply that the initiation and propagation of shear bands in metallic glass strongly depends on the stress state and the small punch test can also be regarded as an effective method to characterize the shear deformation ability and distinguish ductile-brittle transition of different metallic glasses. © 2007 American Institute of Physics.

Zh71as22.title: Freestanding monolithic silicon aerogels
Zh71as22.abstract: The electrical, optical, and (bio)chemical properties of porous Si have attracted considerable interest for battery, solar cell, display, sensor, biomedical, and other applications. Free-standing monolithic Si aerogels have been generated for the first time via low-temperature magnesiothermic reduction of SiO 2 aerogels. Under appropriate conditions, the reaction of Mg gas with SiO 2 produced a co-continuous mixture of predominantly MgO and Si. Selective MgO dissolution then yielded nanocrystalline, porous, photoluminescent Si aerogels with a high degree of porosity (97.3 vol%) and a high specific surface area (615 m 2 g -1). © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2012.

H5a5F3O2.title: Preparation and TiO2 assembly of highly ordered mesoporous silica films
H5a5F3O2.abstract: The research concerns in the preparation and TiO2 assembly of mesoporous silica films at ambient pressure by sol-gel technique. First, the silicate sol was prepared with the procursor acitetraehoxysilane (TEOS) and cationic surfactant hexadecyl trime-thyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) or amphiphilic triblock copolymer (EO20PO70EO20) as template dissolved in ethanol and catalyzed by hydrochloric acid. Then the film was obtained by dip coating, and both XRD patterns and TEM image indicate that the films are highly ordered. Finally, the TiO2 nanofiber was prepared by impregnating a mesoporous silica film with TiCl4 followed by hydrolysis in air and calcination at high temperature in the oven. The prepared TiO2 nanofiber diameter is in the range of 50-300 nm and it was characterized by SEM. TiO2 nanofibers can't be formed on film containting template or bare substrate. TiO2 nanofiber morphology can be varied by controlling the pore size of the mesoporous silica film. TiO2 nanofiber has anatase phase after heating at 200-600°C and its crystallization increases with calcination temperature increasing.

CisxQoLK.title: Thermal and Mechanical Properties of Density-Gradient Aerogels for Outer-Space Hypervelocity Particle Capture
CisxQoLK.abstract: Aerogels with densities in the range 40-175 mg·cm-3 were prepared using a tetraethyl orthosilicate(TEOS)ethanol-water solution as the precursor and hydrofluoric acid as the catalyst via a sol-gel process and CO 2 supercritical-fluid drying.The density-gradient aerogels were prepared using layer-by-layer gelation,sol co-gelation,and gradient-sol co-gelation methods and their gradient properties were studied systematically.The results show that aerogels with different densities all have a three-dimensional skeleton consisting of spherical particles of diameter about 40-90 nm.The lower the density is,the looser the skeleton and pore-size distributions are,and the larger the peak value of the pore size is.Gradient aerogels prepared via different methods exhibited graded,approximately gradient,or gradient distributions.Dynamic mechanical analysis indicates that the Young?s moduli of the aerogels at-100 and 25℃(changed from 4.6×10 5 to 1.9×10 5 Pa and from 5.0×10 5 to 2.1×10 5 Pa,respectively)tend to decrease with decreasing density.Thermal constants analysis shows that as the densities of the aerogels decrease,the thermal diffusion coefficients increase and the specific heat capacities decrease,but the thermal conductivities do not change monotonically.

rD7BLnml.title: Effect of water stress on the photosynthesis charecteristic of different cabbage varieties
rD7BLnml.abstract: The effects of water stress on the photosynthesis of three cabbage varieties were studied.The results showed that the net photosynthetic rate,stomatal conductance and transpination rate were diminished sigificantly with the increasing of water stress,and the net photosynthetic rate of Xinzao 56 was higher than Beijing xiaoza and Xinxiang xiaobao.But the intercellular CO2 concentration was not affected by water stress.The results showed that the non-stomatal factor was the chief cause leading to decrease of photosynthetic rate of cabbage varieties.Xinzao 56 was more toletant to water stress than Xinxiang xiaobao and beijing xiaoza.

cppDQn37.title: Self-heated hydrogen gas sensors based on Pt-coated W18O 49 nanowire networks with high sensitivity, good selectivity and low power consumption
cppDQn37.abstract: Self-heating effect can be applied to develop gas sensors avoiding use of external heaters. We report here a prototype self-heated hydrogen gas sensor based on Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. Such a sensor has been shown to have promising performance, e.g., high sensitivity (able to detect down to 50 ppm of H 2 ), good selectivity (poor response to ethanol, CH 4 , CO, and C 3 H 8 ), and low power consumption of 30–60 mW at 6 V compatible to a portable device. Coaxial cable model and percolation theory are applied to explain the gas sensing effect of the Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. Keywords Gas sensor Nanowire Tungsten oxide Self-heated device Hydrogen Hydrogen sensor 1 Introduction There have been continuous efforts in exploring the metal oxide semiconductor gas sensors with high sensitivity, good selectivity, and stability. The mechanism of gas sensing is considered mainly due to surface reduction and oxidation. The large ratio of surface area to volume of nanostructures has been shown to be useful to develop high sensitivity gas sensors. Due to the activation nature of chemical reactions (Arrhenius's law), temperature is an important factor that affects the sensitivity of the sensor. In order to increase the reactivity at surface, the sensing material of a gas sensor is generally operated at temperatures between 100 and 500 °C [1,2] , and thus additional heating is required in a device. On the other hand, in order to acquire strong sensing effect, it is desirable to have the grain size of the sensing material being as small as possible, e.g., in the range of Debye length [3] . When a sensor is operated at high temperature for long periods, such small grains may become aggregated, which will consequently result in degradation in sensing ability [3–6] . The emergence of semiconductor oxide nanostructures offers a prospective solution due to their highly crystalline in axis but nanosized dimension in lateral [4,5] . Among the nanostructures investigated for gas sensing, ZnO nanorod [7] , SnO 2 nanowire [8] , and TiO 2 nanotube [9] with attractive sensing performance have been reported. In particular, Prades et al. [10] recently demonstrated a novel gas sensor based on a single SnO 2 nanowire. The SnO 2 nanowire can heat itself by the bias current passing through it, thus the requirement of external heater is avoided. Such single nanowire gas sensor has low power consumption, and gives a proof-of-concept for developing self-heated nanowire sensors without integrated heaters. In light of the ideas above, we consider self-heated gas sensors fabricated by using W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. In our early work, three-dimensional (3D) WO 3− x network films have been shown to have very high sensitivity for various gases such as NO 2 , and H 2 S [3] . Here, as shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (b) , the nanowires as-prepared have intercrossings and thus not only the axial semiconducting channel in each nanowire but also the junctions between the overlapping nanowires can be modulated by tested gases [11,12] . The electrical contacts between nanowires in such samples are self-assembled, avoiding complicated fabrication processes. Moreover, in the present work we have added Pt nanoparticles on the surface of the nanowires in order to further enhance the gas sensing capability. Such a sensor has been shown to have promising performance. Through this study, we show that the nano-size effect on self-heating may be employed in a nanowire film-based gas sensor, giving a further support to the proof-of-concept reported by the early authors [10] . 2 Experiment The growth of W 18 O 49 nanowires was carried out by thermal evaporation deposition, as has been described elsewhere by ourselves [13] . Fig. 1 (a) and (b) shows the typical SEM images of W 18 O 49 nanowire networks in the top and cross-sectional views, respectively. The nanowires with diameters of 50 nm and 2 μm in lengthes, overlap each other and form a network structure. Such nanowire networks provide large surface area in 3D space. Compared to the pressed nanograin thin film, in which only surface of the upper layer can be exposed to gas species, the nanowire networks can, in principle, expose all the surface of each nanowire to tested gas. Additionally, the nanowire networks can remain stable for long periods at relative high temperature due to their high crystallinity [5] . After the growth of W 18 O 49 nanowire films, we coated a thin layer of Pt onto the surface of nanowires by sputtering. TEM image in Fig. 1 (c) shows that the Pt particles are uniformly coated around the nanowire. The design of our prototype device is schematically illustrated in Fig. 2 (a) . Firstly, interdigitated electrodes were prepared on ceramic substrate (Al 2 O 3 , 1.5 mm × 1.8 mm). Then Pt coated W 18 O 49 (denoted as Pt–W 18 O 49 in the following) nanowire networks were prepared locally on the central area of the ceramic substrate. As illustrated in Fig. 2 (a), the current can flow from one finger electrode to its counterpart (their separation was about 200 μm) by passing through the nanowires and the junctions of the overlapping nanowires. To meet the voltage requirement of portable devices, the samples should be operated at low bias voltage (e.g., <9 V). On the other hand, in order to achieve self-heating effect in nanowire networks, enough power is needed. We have found that W 18 O 49 nanowire networks are ideal self-heating sensing material owning to their low resistivity; sensors based on materials with high resistivity, such as WO 3 nanowires, have difficulty in producing enough Joule heat at a voltage below 9 V. It is known from the literature that the conductivity of tungsten oxide films depends on the stoichiometry of the films [14] . For example, the W 18 O 49 exhibited very low electrical resistivity of 1.75 × 10 −3 Ω cm [15] , while WO 3 shows resistivity with order of magnitude at 10 7 Ω cm [16] . In order to minimize power consumption of the self-heated devices, the samples were suspended with the bonding wires to form heat insulation structure so as to reduce heat dissipation, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). Also we developed an aging procedure for the self-heating nanowire networks to avoid electrical variation during device operation. This was done by sequentially applying increasing bias voltages in air (25 °C, humility of 30%). The bias voltages were increased from 1 V to 8 V, with step of 1 V and time interval of 10 min. Then the nanowire samples were maintained at 8 V for 30 min. After aging, the samples were set to operate at or smaller than 6 V, which is a standard working voltage of today's portable devices. We checked using Raman spectroscopy that after aging, the nanowires remain as W 18 O 49 . Typical nanowire sample that operated in self-heated mode is shown in Fig. 2 (a). A load resistor R L (150 Ω) is connected in series with the nanowire sample. A fixed voltage (1–6 V) is then applied to the circuit. Change of electrical characteristics of the prototype sensor was studied by monitoring the voltage ( U L ) across the load resistor ( R L ). This arrangement could be expanded to record 1–8 samples simultaneously with a data acquisition card (National Instrument DAQ). The voltage U L was recorded twice per second. The gas detection studies were carried out in a customized gastight chamber, with volume of 16 L. Different concentrations of gases in dry air were provided by injecting pure tested gases of certain volumes. The gas concentrations were determined by volume ratio of injected tested gas and the chamber. The steady-state response of the nanowire samples was also studied. According to the Clifford and Tuma [17] , this should be done in a stable environment; and the time of measurement should be long enough to insure adsorption of gas molecules to reach steady-state. In our experiment, steady-state response of the nanowire samples was designed as following. First, the sample was connected to an external mini-ceramic heater to have a desirable constant working temperature. Second, a constant DC voltage of small value (e.g., 0.1 V) was directly applied to the nanowire sample to prevent self-heated effect, and the current passing through the sample in air or in different concentrations of H 2 was monitored. To consider the effect of temperature on the electrical response, the sample was tested at temperatures ranging from 100 °C to 250 °C. Before the gas sensing measurement was carried out, the sample was annealed in air at 350 °C for 24 h. 3 Results and discussion Hydrogen sensing characteristics relalted to self-heating effect of the W 18 O 49 nanowire networks were investigaed. The sensor was exposed to different concentrations of H 2 , and operated at applied voltages of 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, and 1 V. The substrate temperature was measured with a thermocouple when sensor was operated at different voltages. As shown in Fig. 2 (b), substrate temperature increased with applied voltages. Considering the thermocouple may take away certain amount of Joule heat, the temperature of the nanowires surface may be higher in actual operation. The typical results of response are shown in Fig. 3 (a) . The resistance of the Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks sensor is seen to be reduced significantly by exposing to H 2 . We calculated the response (relative resistance change) of the sensor using the expression of Δ R / R o = ( R o − R g )/ R o . Here R o and R g are the resistance of the sensor before and in exposing to the tested gas, respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 3 (b), the activity of the sensor significantly depends on the applied voltages. When the sensor operated at 4, 5, and 6 V, it was able to detected 50 ppm of H 2 . But the sensor was insensitive to such a low concentration of 50 ppm, while operated at 1, 2, and 3 V. The smallest H 2 concentration that the sensor can detect (detection limit) became low as the applied voltages increased. In addition, the response obtained for the same concentration of H 2 (in the range of 50–400 ppm) also increases with increasing applied voltage. Obviously, the self-heating was gradually enhanced as applied voltage is increased, leading to increase of the surface reactivity for redox reactions. However, though the sensor has high responses at high applied voltages, they gradually become saturated as the concentration increases. As shown in Fig. 3 (c), the response per unit concentration decreases as the H 2 concentration increases, when the sensor is operated at the voltages of 4, 5 and 6 V. The electrical stability analysis of the self-heated Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire was carried out. The self-heated nanowire samples were kept at 6 V at all times for long-term operations. As shown in Fig. 4 (a) , the electrical resistance of each sample during a 4-day operation did not change much. We then carried on the aging process, and checked the resistance of each sample at 12th, 14th, 16th and 19th day. Fig. 4 (a) shows that self-heated nanowire samples operated in air were stable over 19 days. Meanwhile, we also measured the variation of voltage of each sample (Δ U L ) when it was repeatedly exposed to 1000 ppm of H 2 . Fig. 4 (b) shows that all of the samples have good response reproducibility for H 2 gas sensing. In the kind of experiment described above, the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire sample is operated in self-heated mode. During hydrogen sensing, the voltage across the sample will change, which then lead to the variation of the temperature of the nanowires, and thus affect the rate of gas adsorption. In addition, the exact surface temperatures in different operating voltages are unknown. In order to understand the H 2 sensing performance of Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire films at different working temperatures, we further measure the sample under stable environmental conditions and study its steady state response. The performance of the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire film sample in a temperature range from 100 °C to 250 °C was studied at a constant applied voltage (0.1 V) and at four fixed operating temperatures. Typical results are given in Fig. 5 (a)–(d) . First, the trend of current response to H 2 is basically the same; i.e., the current response increases as the gas concentration increases. Second, with increase of temperature up to 200 °C, the magnitude of current response to a specific gas concentration increases, but goes downward from 200 °C to 250 °C. This characteristic is similar to the early findings showing that there is an optimal operating temperature for metal oxides gas sensor [18,19] . If the temperature is too low, the reaction rate between the target gas and the surface is too slow to give a high response, whereas if the temperature is too high, catalytic combustion of the gas with O 2 in the air will happen, so that the concentration of the gas molecules at the surface becomes low [20] . Third, the sample has shorter response and recovery times when it operates at higher temperatures. Fourth, at the operating temperatures of 200 °C and 250 °C, the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire film sample has step-like response and recovery curves. This indicates that the current response can reach a steady state in a short time. This is in contrary to the case of operating temperature of 100 °C, where the response and recovery curves are knife-like. The reaction dynamics are very slow at low operating temperature and the steady state value was not reached in our time cycle. To investigate the nature of reaction kinetics of hydrogen with the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowires, the time dependent of resistance of the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire films on exposed to 1000 ppm of H 2 gas at four different temperatures are given in Fig. 5 (e). Also, the maximum rates of resistance change of each curve are determined [21] . The rate of resistance change becomes greater as temperature increases. Activation energy of 23.6 kJ/mol may be calculated from the slope of the Arrhenius plot, as shown in Fig. 5 (f), which is slightly greater than the Pd-coated ZnO nanowires (11.8 kJ/mol) reported early [21] . The major characteristics of the Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire film sample and the other nanostructure materials reported early by other authors are compared in Table 1 . The responses of all the sensors are normalized to ( R o − R g )/ R o . Since R g is smaller than R o and greater than zero, the range of ( R o − R g )/ R o is from 0 to 1. Table 1 lists responses of our nanowire sensor exposed to 50, 200, 500 and 1000 ppm of H 2 operated at 200 °C. Although not all the concentrations of H 2 used in the referred works are exactly the same as that of ours, the responses of some sensors tested in the similar level of H 2 concentrations may still be compared. First, let us look at the performance of the nanostructured materials [7,22,23] operated using external heating. All of these nanowire/nanorod sensors, operated at 150–250 °C, exhibit large response to H 2 and the values of response of these sensors are slightly larger than that of our Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire films. But typically they are in the same order of magnitude of that of ours. It is also noticed that all of the values are approximate to 1 in all ranges of concentration of H 2 , revealing that the responses of these sensors to H 2 show the states between “on” or “off”. This means that they were not capable of discriminating different concentrations of H 2 . However, our Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire samples were capable of doing so. Second, as compared to the non-heated sensors [21,24–26] , our samples, when operated at 200 °C, shows greater response and faster response time than the non-heated Pd-coated ZnO, GaN and Pt-coated InN, GaN nanowires. In order to investigate the hydrogen selectivity of the self-heated Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowire sample, the responses of the sample to 1000 ppm of H 2 , ethanol, CH 4 , CO, and C 3 H 8 , were obtained. As can be seen in Fig. 6 , the Pt–W 18 O 49 sensor is highly selective to H 2 when operated at applied voltages of 4 V to 1 V. The response to ethanol, CO and C 3 H 8 is also relatively very weak when the sensor is operated at 5 V and 6 V. Generally, selectivity in semiconductor gas sensors may be achieved through various of methods, such as: (i) the use of specific surface additives; (ii) the use of filters; (iii) the use of working temperature control; and (iv) the use of catalysts and promoters [20,27] . The high selectivity of H 2 sensing of the self-heated nanowires sensor we study here may be due to the choice of last two methods. The H 2 molecules can be disassociated at Pt and spill-over to the metal oxides [20,28] . Moreover, many studies clearly show that hydrogen spill-over can take place at room temperature and the spill-over hydrogen atoms can be involved in reaction at the surface of metal oxides [21,24–26,29] . It is also suggested that some hydrocarbon (like ethanol and CH 4 ) could also be decomposed at the catalyst surface and provided H atoms [28,30] . However, the yield rates of hydrogen can differ by orders of magnitude depending on the catalyst-metal oxides system and reaction temperature [28] . In our case, strong response of the self-heated nanowire sample towards H 2 may be due to the very effective dissociation of H 2 into H atoms by Pt, and then spill-over to the nanowires surface to react with the absorbed oxygen and also to diffuse into the nanowires. Responses of sample on exposed to other molecules such as CH 4 or ethanol are quite weak. This may be due to the fact that the yield rate of hydrogen was too low at the surface of self-heated Pt–W 18 O 49 nanowires. The employment of Pt catalyst in our nanowire samples can lower the working temperature according the early study of Ippolito et al. [31] . The H 2 molecules will favorably adsorb onto the surface of Pt and are disassociated into H atoms. Then the H atoms will diffuse to the surface of the metal oxide (i.e., the spill-over process) and react with the oxygen that is previously adsorbed at the surface. In our experiment, without Pt catalyst coating, our self-heated samples did not show any responses on exposure to H 2 . Further, we compare the power consumption of self-heated Pt–W 18 O 49 sensor and the typical sensors based on ceramic tubes/substrates, and MEMS silicon substrates ( Table 2 ). Our prototype sensors operated at power level of 30–60 mW, which are comparable with the sensors based on elegant MEMS process [32] . We adapt coaxial cable model [11,12,33] and percolation theory [34] to explain the sensing mechanism of the Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. The detail discussions are shown following. Firstly, we explain why the conductance of the W 18 O 49 networks increases with increasing concentration of H 2 . As illustrated in (I) of Fig. 7 (a) , the adsorbed oxygen molecules trap electrons at the surface when the nanowires are exposed to air, leading to the presence of a depletion region in surface layer, and the narrowing of the semiconducting channels in the nanowires. In each nanowire, free carriers (electrons) can transport along the semiconducting channel, while electrons transport between the overlapping nanowires, they have to pass through a potential barrier at a junction. The electron transport in the junction can be described in terms of a thermoelectronic emission mechanism [35] . With introduction of H 2 gas, hydrogen molecules will first be dissociated into hydrogen species by Pt nanoparticles [27,36] ((II) of Fig. 7 (a)), and may subsequently react with the absorbed oxygen species to form H 2 O molecules. In addition, the hydrogen species may also undergo a reaction with the lattice oxygen atoms of tungsten oxide to form localized water molecules [37] . Such reducing reactions release the electrons trapped at the nanowires’ surface. As a result, the thickness of the depletion layer decreases, and the semiconducting channel is widened. Meanwhile, the potential barrier heights at the junctions between nanowires become lower. The modulation of both semiconducting channel and potential barrier height contributes to the change in the resistance of the gas sensor. The depleted layer thickness, barrier height, and reactivity of surface reactions could be changed to favor to enhance the response with increasing temperature, thus greater response is obtained. Secondly, we explain the detection limit and sensing saturation effect of the sensor. The response of the W 18 O 49 nanowire networks also depends on the availability of the conduction paths through the overlapping nanowires. Fig. 7 (b) illustrates how the percolating theory may be used to explain the conduction of the nanowire networks of our prototype sensor. The nanowires in air will exhibit high resistance state (left of Fig. 7 (b)) due to less conduction paths available. When H 2 gas is introduced, some nanowires switch from high resistance state to low resistance state. Meanwhile, barrier heights at junctions between nanowires turn low. Then paths of low resistance state composed of overlapping nanowires will be formed between two adjacent electrodes (right of Fig. 7 (b)). There is a concentration threshold at which the nanowire networks can form the first path. The concentration threshold turns low as chemical reactivity of the nanowire networks increases. 4 Conclusion In summary, the present work has demonstrated a prototype of self-heated hydrogen gas sensors based on Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. The concept of single nanowire-based self-heated gas sensor proposed early [10] can be employed in a nanowire film-based gas sensor. The response of our prototype sensor could be modulated by self-heating effect of the nanowires. Coaxial cable model and percolation theory can be used to explain the gas sensing behavior of the Pt-coated W 18 O 49 nanowire networks. Such prototype sensors have exhibited attractive performances, and they may be further developed for practical application. C 113 2009 15877 15881 Mr. Lian Feng Zhu received his B.E. degree in electronic materials from the South China University of Technology, China in 2004. Currently, he is studying for Ph.D. at Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China. His research activities are focused on the surface physics and chemistry of metal oxides, and development of new nanomaterials for the gas sensor applications. Prof. Jun Cong She graduated from Sun Yat-sen University in China with Degrees of B.Sc. and Ph.D. in Physics at 1997 and 2005, respectively. His research interests include (i) micro-fabrication process, (ii) vacuum micro/nano electronics, and (iii) control synthesis and in-situ characterization of individual nanostructures. Mr. Jian Yi Luo received his Ph.D. degree in optical engineering from Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China, in 2009. His areas of research include optical and electrical properties of tungsten oxides nanostructures, surface physics and chemistry of metal oxide nanomaterials. Ms. Shao Zhi Deng received the B.Sc. degree and M.Sc. Degree in electrical technologies at University of Electronic Science and Technology of China in 1984 and 1987, respectively. From 1987 to 1989 she was a Assistant Lecturer at the Department of Electrical Engineering at Guilin University of Electronic Technology, China, where she worked on intelligent instrumentation and measurement. Since 1990, she has been employed as an academic staff of Sun Yat-Sen University, China, and has been Professor of Physics since 2002. Since 1997, she has worked on cold cathode materials, cold electron devices, field emission flat panel display, ultra-large screen display, E-paper display and driving circuits and IC design for flat panel display. Mr. Jun Chen received the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees, both in physics, from Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China, in 1991 and 2004, respectively. He is presently a Professor of Physics in Sun Yat-sen University. His areas of research include nanomaterials and their applications in field emission devices. Mr. Xue Wen Ji received his B.S. degree in automation technology from Jilin University, China in 1983. Since 2000, He has been the chief engineer of Shenzhen Dovelet Sensors Technology Co., Ltd. Shenzhen, China. He was specialized in the field of gas sensing and gas sensor applications. And currently, he is the chairman of the board of Shenzhen Dynanonic Co., Ltd. Shenzhen, China. Now his research activities are focused on the development of novel nanostructured materials, including nano-lithium iron phosphate, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanotube conductive fluid and variety of nano-oxides. Mr. Ning Sheng Xu is academician of Chinese Academy of Sciences and professor of Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China. He received his Ph.D. degree from, and subsequently worked at Aston University, UK. Since 1996, he has been working at Sun Yat-sen University. He is currently the director of State Key Lab of Optoelectronic Materials and Technologies. He specializes in vacuum micro/nanoelectronics. His present research interest covers nanomaterials and their potential novel applications.

cfGWcvsW.title: Design and analysis of optical antireflective multilayer coatings derived from sol-gel process
cfGWcvsW.abstract: The design and performance calculation of optical antireflective (AR) multilayer coatings derived from sol-gel process were made by Essential Macloed program. The concept of packing density was used to modify the nano-porous coatings, and it is also a convenient way of introducing variable refractive index. The best design was chosen by the reflectance and relative sensitivity analysis. Optical performances of quarter-wave layer AR coatings were calculated, for example, the distribution of electric field inside different layers and the influence of thickness errors to the reflectivity. These results can give good guides to the practical coating preparation.

Axh593Su.title: Porous MoP network structure as co-catalyst for H2 Evolution over g-C3N4 nanosheets
Axh593Su.abstract: Abstract   Exploring an efficient and inexpensive noble-metal-free co-catalyst to replace noble-metal is a huge challenge for photocatalytic H 2  evolution. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) as co-catalysts for photocatalytic H 2  generation have been extensively employed due to their exceedingly good property, stability and low cost. Herein, a new photocatalyst containing g-C 3 N 4  and porous network-like MoP as a highly efficient co-catalyst was fabricated. The maximal H 2 -generation rate of the MoP/g-C 3 N 4  photocatalyst could reach 327.5 µmol⋅g -1 ⋅h -1 , which was ∼3.4 times higher than that of pure g-C 3 N 4 . The quantum efficiency achieved 9.6% at 400 nm. The improvement in photocatalytic H 2 -generation of MoP/g-C 3 N 4  was resulted from the proper Fermi level alignment and the close contact interfaces of porous network-like MoP and g-C 3 N 4 , in which MoP not only increased light absorption but also fasted the separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers as well as lowered the H 2  evolution overpotentials. The possible photocatalytical mechanism of the MoP/g-C 3 N 4  photocatalyst was speculated based on various characterization techniques. It is believed that this study can offer a novel pathway to design high-performance and low-cost photocatalytic materials composed of metal phosphide co-catalyst for efficient water-splitting H 2 -generation over semiconductors under visible-light illumination.

hnS5R5UM.title: Block Correlated Coupled Cluster Theory With A Complete Active-Space Self-Consistent-Field Reference Function: The General Formalism And Applications
hnS5R5UM.abstract:
We have presented in this chapter the general formalism of block correlated coupled cluster method with a CASSCF reference
 function (CAS-BCCC in short) and a number of its applications for electronic structure calculations of molecules with multireference
 character. The CAS-BCCC method has the following features: (1) free of the intruder states; (2) invariant with respect to
 orbital rotations within separated orbital subspaces (occupied, active, and virtual); (3) cost-effective; (4) core-extensive,
 but not size-extensive with respect to the total number of electrons. With the cluster operator truncated up to the four-block
 correlation level, the approximate CAS-BCCC method is named as CAS-BCCC4. The CAS-BCCC4 method is applied to investigate a
 number of chemical problems such as bond breaking potential energy surfaces, singlet-triplet gaps of diradicals, reaction
 barriers, spectroscopic constants of diatomic molecules, and low-lying excited states. Comparisons between results from CAS-BCCC4
 and those from FCI or other theoretical methods demonstrate that the CAS-BCCC4 approach provides very accurate descriptions
 for all problems under study. The overall performance of CAS-BCCC4 is illustrated to be better than that of CASPT2 and MR-CISD
 methods.

M2SfwK62.title: Effect of Annealing Temperature on Structure and Gaschromic Properties of WO_3 Thin Films
M2SfwK62.abstract: WO3 sol(600 mL) was prepared with tungsten powder and 37% H2O2 through the sol-gel method in this paper.WO3 thin films were prepared on silicon chips and ordinary slide glasses via Dip Master method and annealed in ambient air at temperatures of 50,150,250,350 and 450 ℃,respectively.Thickness and refractive index of the WO3 thin films were researched by Spectroscopic Ellipsometer.Surface morphology and microstructure of the films were analyzed with AFM,IR and XRD respectively.The annealing temperature have an important effect on the structure and gaschromic properties of WO3 thin films.At low annealing temperature,WO3 thin films is amorphous and porous structure,and the water of WO3 thin films is appropriate,then this kind of WO3 thin films have a good gaschromic properties.

3neNtWaQ.title: Research on characteristics of prestress change of anchorage cable in anti-explosion model test of anchored cavern
3neNtWaQ.abstract: The model explosion test methods are adopted to study the anti-explosion effect of prestressed cable reinforced cavern. In this paper, the characteristics of anchorage cable prestress changes caused by explosion are specially researched, and the features of anchor cable prestress changes of different types of anchor cable reinforced caverns are analyzed and some regulations have been obtained. The corresponding numerical calculations are also carried out. The reliability of the test results is proved, and the suggestions to the anti-explosion reinforced cavern design in anchor engineering are put forward.

D0zpvB0E.title: Composite nano chromotropic film
D0zpvB0E.abstract: Physical method, including thermal evaporation and magnetic sputtering, and chemical coating method are applied to prepare organic-inorganic composite chromotropic film. The chromotropic film showing obvious opto-chromo effect with the change of incidence angle and view angle, can be used as a counterfeiting preventing material. The structure of the film system is designed as PET/Cr/dielectric/Al according to the optical interference principle of multiplayer. The dielectric materials are polymer and SiO2 respectively. The SiO2 prepared by sol-gel method shows nano-holes. Its refractive index is between 1.15 and 1.45 by varying the method and condition of catalyst and gel process. Fabrication method and film characteristics are described.

EP7lMDwJ.title: Diagnostic Value of Spiral Computed Tomography in Digestive Obstruction
EP7lMDwJ.abstract: Objective: To discuss the diagnostic value of spiral computed tomography(CT) in digestive obstruction. Methods: Twelve cases suspected of digestive obstruction underwent MDCT. Nine of them were subsquently surgically proved and the diagnostic results of MDCT were compared with the surgical and pathological findings. The main reconstraction method included multi-planar reconstruction(MPR) and maximum intensity projection(MIP). Results: Among 12 cases, 9 were subsquently surgically proved. To comparing with the results of surgery, the localization diagnosis was correct in 9 patients(100%) and the pathogenic diagnosis was correct in 8 patients(88.9%). Conclusion: Spiral CT has an important value in detecting digestive obstruction.

Otn9kRAy.title: Preparation of hydrophobic-shortwave-band antireflective film by Sol-Gel process and its performance analysis
Otn9kRAy.abstract: With the development of large-scale high power laser system, large size shortwave-band (such as 355 nm) antireflective coatings are needed. In this paper, the Sol-Gel deriving SiO2 nano-structure shortwave-band antireflective coatings were prepared. Ellipsometer, FTIR, UV-Vis-VIR spectrometer and AFM were used to characterize the properties of the films. The refractive index of the film is about 1.22, and the thickness is 75 nm. The reflectance of the film (on silica substrate) at 355 nm is reduced to 0.2%. The scratch-resistant property of film was improved obviously after ammonia treatment, the maximum transmission values of the film are only reduced by 0.13% and 0.39% after 20 and 50 times scratch by the tampon with dirty. After surface modification the hydrophobicity of the film is improved and the contact angle is about 110°.

WfmOAtCP.title: Three-dimensional six-fold symmetry ZnO sub-microstructures
WfmOAtCP.abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) six-fold symmetry ZnO sub-microstructures were prepared by using a low temperature (80 °C) solution method. The 3D structure has unique configuration, i.e., a support core with six symmetric branches located on its middle. It was found that the structure can only be produced in a critical basicity condition, i.e., pH=11.8±0.2. The formation mechanism of the 3D structure involves the enhancing effect on the growth of ZnO [0 0 0 1] direction and the secondary nucleation process. The 3D sub-microstructure is likely to be candidate as building block for nano-electromechanical system (NEMS) and nanomachines, i.e., act as a gear. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

JKzam8Z9.title: Role of miRNA in circadian rhythmicity:recent progress
JKzam8Z9.abstract: MicroRNA(miRNA)is a group of recently discovered small RNA molecules that have a significant role in regulating gene and protein expression.These small RNAs(-22nt)can bind to 3′-untranslated regions(3′-UTRs)and induce mRNA degradation and repress protein expression.They play important roles in development and maintenance of normal cell function.More recently,a few studies have suggested that miRNA may also serve as an important regulator of circadian rhythmicity,which casts new lights on our understanding of biological clocks.Here we describe the function of miRNA in regulation of circadian system.

sWsV4GZz.title: Effects of catalytic components of tannin extract desulfurization solution on reaction of HS-with oxygen
sWsV4GZz.abstract: Effects of catalytic components in tannin extract desulfurization solution on the reaction of HS-with oxygen were in-vestigated using a continuous bubbling reactor.The results showed that the reaction of HS-with oxygen was accelerated by catalytic components such as tannin extract and pentavalent vanadium V(V).Tannin extract and V(V) could both directly react with HS-,and their oxidabilities enhanced with concentration increase.The reduced tannin extract could be generated by oxidation with oxygen,but V(V) could hardly regenerate.The tetravalent vanadium V(IV) formed by V(V) reduction might complex with tannin extract,which made the tannin extract lose its oxidability.Moreover,the oxidability and catalytic activity of tannin extract could be strengthened when the pH value and reaction temperature rise.In contrast,the oxidability of V(V) could be heightened and the reaction between V(V) and HS-became easier when the pH value and reaction temperature decreased.Therefore,how to accelerate the transformation of HS-to S is the key for inhibiting side reaction and reducing by-products.

SB5Gibd5.title: Model construction of renal acute ischemia-reperfusion injury in Wistar rats
SB5Gibd5.abstract: Objective:To construct a simple,safe,high successful rate model of renal acute ischemia-reperfusion injury in Wistar rats. Methods:Renal artery of Wistar rats was bilaterally clamped with a micro-artery clamp for 50 minutes to make the animal model of renal acute ischemia-reperfusion injury. Then these kidneys were removed at the 3rd,5th,7th day after injury. Immunohistochemistry staining was used to show the distribution and expression of Kim-1 antigen,and the changes of cytomorphology were observed by HE staining. Results:The successful rate of model construction reached to 85% in the experiment. The expression of Kim-1 antigen increaced. Meanwhile,changes of cytomorphology took place. Conclusion:Stable model of renal acute ischemia-reperfusion injury of Wistar rats can be constructed by applying micro-artery clamp to incarcerate bilateral renal arteries,and its successful rate is very high.

REEYpV6i.title: The investigation on the vapour liquid phase equilibrium of (ammonia + 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane) system over the temperatures ranging from (243.150 to 283.150) K
REEYpV6i.abstract: Abstract   To blend ammonia with some hydrofluorocarbons may give these mixed refrigerants lower flammability and global warming potential. In this paper, the isothermal vapour liquid equilibrium (VLE) of (ammonia + 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane) system at temperatures ranging from (243.150 to 283.150) K are presented. Two models were employed to regress the experimental VLE results, namely the Peng–Robinson (PR) equation of state with the simple van der waals (VDW) mixing rule; the Peng–Robinson equation of state combined non-random two-liquid (NRTL) activity coefficient model with the modified Huron-Vidal one-order (MHV1) mixing rule. The maximum average absolute relative deviation of pressure (AARD p ) and average absolute deviation of the vapour phase mole fraction (AAD y ) for PR-VDW are 0.56% and 0.010, respectively, while the maximum AARD p  and AAD y  for PR-MHV1-NRTL are 0.27% and 0.014, respectively. Positive azeotropic behaviour was exhibited at each temperature investigated.

BtUpCRpn.title: Observation of a new type of field-induced electron emission from a diamond-based heterostructure
BtUpCRpn.abstract: The nitrogen-doped diamond films were deposited on Mo substrates by Microwave Plasma Enhanced CVD using N2/CH4 as feedstock. A two-layer structure consisting of a α-Mo2C buffer layer and diamond film was formed. Their field-induced electron emission characteristics, ie, I-V characteristics and distribution of emission sites were studied using the Transparent Anode Imaging Technique. Repeatable abrupt change of `on' and `off' states of emission was observed at two corresponding specific fields during circling of both increasing and decreasing applied gap field. A plausible explanation is given to this new type of field-induced electron emission phenomenon.

5vC21d18.title: Localization algorithm of model parameters real-time estimate based on RSSI optimized
5vC21d18.abstract: Received signal strength indicator(RSSI) ranging technology is a low-cost distance measurement technique.To reduce the RSSI measurement error because of the influence of environment effectively,and solve the problem of high ranging error which is brought by using the fixed signal propagation model in the traditional algorithms,a localization algorithm of model parameters real-time estimation based on RSSI optimized is put forward.This algorithm processes the all RSSI measured values that the node received by adopting the Gauss model firstly,and determines the minimal region where the location node is placed in according to RSSI values secondly,then environment parameters are estimated by the cooperation of selected beacon nodes,which is placed in the minimal region.The parameters of the signal propagation model is adjusted dynamically according to the actual situation,which makes the ranging precision exacter,thus the positional error is reduced.It verifies that the proposed algorithm can provide higher localization accuracy from the simulation results by comparing with the other algorithms.

ES4xbIZ9.title: The State of Skewed X Chromosome Inactivation is Retained in the Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells from a Female with Hemophilia B.
ES4xbIZ9.abstract: Skewed X chromosome inactivation (XCI) is a rare reason for hemophilia B in females. It is indefinite whether X chromosome reactivation (XCR) would occur when cells of hemophilia B patients with skewed XCI were reprogrammed into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). In this study, we investigated a female hemophilia B patient with a known F9 gene mutation: c.676C>T, p.Arg226Trp. We demonstrated that skewed XCI was the pathogenesis of the patient, and we successfully generated numerous iPSC colonies of the patient from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMNCs), which was the first time for generating hemophilia-specific iPSCs from PBMNCs. Then we detected the XCI state of these iPSCs. Ninety-two iPSC lines were picked for XCI analysis. All of them retained an inactive X chromosome, which could be proved by amplification of the androgen receptor gene and XIST (X inactivation-specific transcript), expression of H3K27me3, and existence of XIST clouds in XIST RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis. We attempted to obtain iPSC lines with the wild-type F9 gene on the active X chromosome for further disease treatment. But it turned out that the patient's iPSCs were still skewed such as the somatic cells with 92 iPSC lines having mutant F9 on the active X chromosome. In conclusion, skewed XCI is one reason for hemophilia in females. PBMNCs are excellent somatic cell resources for hemophilia patients to do reprogramming. More attentions should be paid to generate naive iPSCs with two active X chromosomes for further clinical disease treatment. The state of skewed XCI is retained in the iPSCs from a female with hemophilia B.

hOC2i9kd.title: Cause Analysis and Measures for Difficult Pushing of Coke
hOC2i9kd.abstract: During the coking production process,the coke pushing with frequently high electric current would cause serious failures to the coking oven body,would highly reduce the service life of the coking oven and would increase the coking production cost.The paper from the several points analyzed the difficult factors of the coke pushing and analyzed the cause of the high current occurred by the coke pushing during the coking production process.The results showed that the coke pushing difficulty would mainly be the heating temperature too lower or too high,the graphite occurred was too thick,the brick deformation of the oven wall and oven bottom,the coke pushing bar deformation,poor coking of the feeding coal and the water content of the feeding coal increased as well as others.The coke pushing difficult was a procedure from a quantitative change to a qualitative change.Therefore,during the quantitative change period,an investigation and analysis shall be made on the cause to make a coke pushing difficult.Also the means of the coking oven production technology and management shall be enhanced and the hidden danger could be rationally eliminated.

zntCNVnI.title: Hydrophobic behavior of nanoporous silica films with low refractive index
zntCNVnI.abstract: A silica precursor sol was prepared by the sol-gel method and using tetraethoxysilane as silica source, cetyltrimethylam-monium bromide as template surfactant and with hydrochloric acid and water as other raw materials. The silica precursor sol was then modified by methyltriethoxysilane (MTES) to obtain modified silica sol organically. The results show that the modified silica sol organically modified by MTES is better than that modified by hexame-thyldisihazane HMDS. Hydrophobic nanoporous silica film with a refractive index of 1.10 and adjusted from 1.1 to 1.38 can be prepared by evaporation-induced self-assembly process and MTES modification. The porosity and dielectric constant of the film are about 81.8% and 1.77, respectively. The infrared spectrum of the film indicates that the film is hydrophobic due to the introduction of the methyl groups and the picture of a drop of water on the film supports this result.

gzL9D5bM.title: Observation of a non Fowler-Nordheim field-induced electron emission phenomenon from chemical vapor deposited diamond films
gzL9D5bM.abstract: A field-induced electron emission phenomenon has been observed from nitrogen-doped diamond films deposited on molybdenum substrates by microwave plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition using N2/CH4 as feedstock. Their field-induced electron emission characteristics, i.e., current-voltage characteristics and distribution of emission sites, were studied using the transparent anode imaging technique. A repeatable abrupt change of "on" and "off" states of emission was observed at two corresponding specific fields during circling of both increasing and decreasing applied gap fields. A plausible explanation is given to this type of field-induced electron emission phenomenon, in which a two-layer structure consisting of amorphous carbon and diamond is proposed. © 1999 American Institute of Physics.

QiPo6ugW.title: Study on hexagonal mesoporous silica film for antireflective coating
QiPo6ugW.abstract: In this paper, ordered mesoporous silica film as a novel antireflective coating was directly synthesized via evaporation induced self-assembly (EISA) process with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as template surfactant. The mesoporous silica film exhibits ordered 2D hexagonal microstructure as demonstrated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and small angle X-ray diffraction (SAXRD). The average transmittance of the coated glass is about 98%, which indicates an increasing transmitted light of 7.5% in the wavelength between 400nm and 800nm. The mechanical performance and hydrophobicity tests prove that the films have excellent scratch resistance and long-time stability. The results of the characterizations and tests show that the film prepared by this convenient method would be very useful and promising for lots of commercial applications. © (2012) Trans Tech Publications.

WzcFnxbX.title: Magnetic labelling of transplanted stem cells and in vivo tracking with magnetic resonance imaging
WzcFnxbX.abstract: How to monitor and track the survival, migration and differentiation of grafted stem cell in vivo is necessary for the widespread clinically application of stem cell transplantation. Manegtic resonance imaging(MRI), which can display and specifically track and localize labelled stem cell by paramagnetically labelling of the stem cell, is an extremely prospective method to monitor stem cell in vivo. The ferrum and gadlinium derviative contrast agents were mainly used to paramagnetically label the stem cell, and each had its own advantages and disadvatages. Currently, on the basis of paramagnetically labelling of the stem cell with ferrum and gadlinium derviative contrast agents, MRI had been succeessfully used to monitor the stem cell in vivo and had been applied into animal model of the heart and brain stroke, but these are still some problems exist such as the selection of vehicle transferring the contrast agents into stem cells, the labeling efficiency, the duration of labelling and the viablity and heredity changes of the stem cell after labelling.

VH2nGli1.title: EFFECT OF TANNIN EXTRACT IN TANNIN EXTRACT DESULFURIZATION
VH2nGli1.abstract: The effect of tannin extract in tannin extract desulfurization was investigated using UV-vis absorption spectroscopy and Foulier transferred infrared(FTIR) method.The study of interaction between tannin extract of oxidation state(TEos) and vanadium ion show there exists complex reaction between TEos and tetravalent vanadium ion/pentavalent vanadium ion.The study of reaction between TEos and bisulfide ion show: the reaction consists of two steps: the fast reaction and the slow reaction;concentration of HS-decreases with reaction time,and the reaction rate appears first quick back slow trend;the conversion of HS-increase with the increase of initial concentration of TEos;HS-reacts with TEos to form organic compounds containing sulfur,not to generate elemental sulfur.

D3qPTjxC.title: Effect of Dy on the microstructures of directionally solidified NiAl-Cr(Mo) hypereutectic alloy at different withdrawal rates
D3qPTjxC.abstract: The effect of various Dy content on the microstructure of Ni-31Al-32Cr-6Mo hypereutectic alloy was studied at the withdrawal rates of 6, 30 and 90 ��m/s. The results show that the solid-liquid interface morphology has an evolutionary process of planar �� cellular �� dendritic interface with the increasing withdrawal rate. The primary Cr(Mo) dendrites are gradually weeded out through competitive growth between the primary phase and the eutectic phase. The volume fraction of primary Cr(Mo) dendrites decreases with the modest addition of Dy (0.05 wt.%) at 6 ��m/s. When the withdrawal rate increases to 30 ��m/s, the appropriate addition of Dy (0.1 wt.%) refines the microstructure, such as the width of intercellular zone and the lamellar thickness in the intercellular zone. With the increase of withdrawal rate to 90 ��m/s, the addition of Dy has no significant effect on the microstructure. In addition, the white Dy-containing phase can occur in the boundary of eutectic cells when the Dy content is no less than 0.1 wt.%. ? 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

jC2V4eOd.title: Microstructure evolution in directionally solidified Fe-Ni alloys under traveling magnetic field
jC2V4eOd.abstract: Based on the simulation results, directional solidification experiments under traveling magnetic field were performed to obtain thin samples with 7 mm diameter. The experimental results demonstrate that banding is overgrown by peritectic coupled growth or island banding structures as solidification proceeds. Numerical results indicate that this phenomenon should be attributed to the different solute distribution at the S/L interface with different TMF. The effects show that it is possible to control solidification microstructure evolution by using a traveling magnetic field during directional solidification of peritectic alloys. ? 2013 Elsevier B.V.

pW2CFbNp.title: Micro-Structure Examination of Strengthened Wood Sheets by Compression Perpendicular to Grain
pW2CFbNp.abstract: Saw cutting wood sheet of Populus ussuriensis,rotary cutting wood sheet of Betula platyphylla and planer slicing wood sheet of Tilia amurensis were dipped in water under normal temperature until water-saturated,and then were compressed perpendicular to grain.The micro-structure at across-grain section and along-grain section of wood sheets before and after compression were examined with scanning electron microscope,and aimed to probe the feasibility of this wood sheets strengthened method.The results showed that:the entirety compression deformations of these three species were relatively even and well-distributed,no obvious differences between the surface and the internal.There were no cracks or breaks found at both across-grain and along-grain sections.At along-grain section,the transverse wrinkles at along-grain direction were observed.At across-grain section,the vessel deformation of Populus ussuriensis and Tilia amurensis along compression direction were most obvious,and that vessel deformation of Betula platyphylla was also observed remarkable along its longitude direction,which simultaneously caused the distortions of bilateral xylem ray cells and the fiber cells that arrayed along radial and compression direction.

MJ55c9pM.title: Effects of Hydrogen on the Crystallization Process of Zr_(41.2)Ti_(13.8)Cu_(12.5)Ni_(10)Be_(22.5) Bulk Amorphous Alloys
MJ55c9pM.abstract: Zr41.2Ti13.8Ni10Cu12.5Be22.5 bulk amorphous alloy was prepared by arc-melting and rapid casting into a copper mould. Hydrogen charging was performed electrochemically in glycerine-phosphoric acid electrolyte. The effects of hydrogen on the crystallization process of Zr-Ti-Cu-Ni-Be bulk amorphous alloy were studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), Kissinger equation and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). It is shown that hydrogen increases the activation energy of the glass transition and crystallization, and retards the nucleation and crystal growth. Moreover, hydrogen charging contributes to the formation of isolated crystals, resulting in the precipitation of fine and uniformly distributed nanocrystallines.

EV5joIWz.title: Influence of heat treatment on properties of V2O5 ambient dried aerogel films
EV5joIWz.abstract: Ambient dried V2O5 aerogel films were deposited by dip coating of V2O5 sol followed by solvent exchange. The films were characterized with X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, etc. The results show that annealing significantly affects its quality. For example, the film annealed at 300°C has higher V5+ density, lower porosity density and better compactness than as deposited one.

OFlGtcik.title: An evaluation of three-dimensional CT in the diagnosis of maxillofacial diseases
OFlGtcik.abstract: Objective To evaluate the applications of three dimensional CT in the diagnosis of maxillofacial diseases. Methods In total 48 patients with maxillofacial diseases were examined using three-dimensional CT with a reconstruction interval of 1mm and a pitch of 1.5. All raw data were transferred to workstation and post-processed with the technique of the SSD and VR. The imaging findings were compared with surgical and pathological findings. Results Three-dimensional CT was superior to two-dimensional CT in showing the location, size, shape and extent of the lesions. The bone destruction was objectively demonstrated, while the details of the soft tissue were not revealed. Conclusion Three-dimensional CT provides spatial anatomical relationship of the disorders. Two-dimensional CT and three-dimensional CT have their own advantages respectively in the demonstrating and diagnosing the maxillofacial lesions. Integration of these two methods can improve the accuracy of imaging diagnosis.

avjFLYBd.title: Bionics materials of hydroxyapatie/poly(ε-caprolactone) with gradual change pore structure
avjFLYBd.abstract: To get hydroxyapatite(HA)/ polycaprolactone(PCL) bionic bone material with gradual changing pore structure similar to the bone structure and good mechanical properties,HA powder was prepared by hydrothermally synthesized method,and it had been compounded with PCL via solvent blending method,then vesicular HA/PCL composite were prepared with cast/sodium chloride particle-leaching technique.On this basis,HA/PCL composite with different pore size,different porosity rate and HA/PCL composite with gradual changing pore structure were achieved via changing the particle size and the quantity of sodium chloride.The pore structures were observed by optical microscope,and the pore size is from 100~300 μm,the maximum porosity rate is of 80%.What's more,the mechanical properties had been studied near the body temperature(37±5) ℃,and the results indicated that the mechanical properties were greatly improved compared to the HA / PCL composite with single pore structure.

i2G2lxKt.title: Modification and laser-damage resistance of zirconia thin films
i2G2lxKt.abstract: ZrO 2 sol was obtained by using hydrothermal synthesis. Thin ZrO 2 films and ZrO 2-PVP composite films were prepared with spin coating method. Both the ZrO 2 films and ZrO 2-PVP composite films were characterized by ellipsometer, FTIR, AFM respectively. The crystallization behavior of ZrO 2 xerogels was examined by X-ray diffraction. And 1-on-l laser-induced damage threshold tests on ZrO 2 films and ZrO 2-PVP composite films were carried out with a Q-switched Nd: YAG high power laser at 1064 nm with a pulse width of 10 ns. The measured laser-induced damage threshold of ZrO 2 films with heat treatment at 300°C for 60 min was 24.5 J/cm 2, and 37.5 J/cm 2 for that of ZrO 2-PVP composite films. The experimental results show that the incorporating organic binder PVP (polyvinyl pyrrolidone), without obvious influence on film surface micro morphology, helps to improve the performances of ZrO 2 films such as high refractive index, thickness and laser induced damage threshold. The ZrO 2-PVP composite films can achieve good performances with high refractive index of 1.75 and the laser-induced damage threshold of 37.8 J/cm 2, which is 50% higher than that of ZrO 2 films.

hNaoRBhF.title: Environmentally assisted fracture behavior of Fe-based amorphous coatings in chloride-containing solutions
hNaoRBhF.abstract: Abstract   Environmentally assisted fracture behaivor of Fe-based amorphous metallic coating (AMC) sprayed on 316L stainless steel was investigated in chloride-containing solutions using a slow strain rate test method in situ electrochemical measurements and subsequent fractography analysis. A systematic detrimental effect of applied loading and aggressive ions on passive current density and localized corrosion was found. The high applied loading deteriorated the stability of passivation of AMC, which increased the passivation density and the pitting tendency. The fracture surface of AMC exhibited brittle fracture morphology with no significant crack branching. A mechanism was proposed in which the localized corrosion taking place preferentially at coating defects, and for producing the necessary crack-tip geometry. The tensile stresses accelerated the localized corrosion susceptibility near the defects by forming microcracks and promoting fast diffusion path for chloride ions. The poor environmental cracking resistance of AMC was attributed to the low protective effect of the passive film for the stress assisted localized corrosion at the crack tip and to the metastable nature of the amorphous structure.

ljtRx1Vc.title: Field emission properties of CuO nanobelts film under light illumination
ljtRx1Vc.abstract: CuO nanobelt arrays were prepared by an aqueous reaction method at room temperature. Effects of pulsed and continuous light illumination on field emission from CuO nanobelt arrays were studied. Possible physical mechanisms behind the observed phenomena are discussed.

pzfzvaSH.title: Patterned growth of A1N nanowires and investigation on their field emission properties
pzfzvaSH.abstract: A1N nanowires have low electron affinity, which has been considered as one of the ideal cathode materials in future. Although many methods have been developed to prepare A1N nanowires with different morphologies, little effort is found to focus on the patterned growth technique, which has limited their applicaitions. Here we provide a ceramic template method to fabricate patterned A1N nanowire arrays, which have better field emission performance than the continuous nanowire film.
