KjxdOfrM.title: Superplastic deformation behavior of Zr41.25Ti 13.75Ni10Cu12.5Be22.5 bulk metallic glass in the supercooled liquid region
KjxdOfrM.abstract: This paper presents the tensile deformation behavior of Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 (at%) bulk metallic glass in the supercooled liquid region. Isothermal tensile tests were carried out at four characteristic temperatures of 616, 636, 656 and 676 K which are in the range from glass transition temperature (∼616 K) to onset crystallization temperature (∼690 K). The results show that the superplastic flow behaviors of the material (flow stress and elongation to fracture) vary, depending strongly on the test temperatures and initial strain-rates. At a given temperature, the elongation first increases and then decreases with the initial strain-rate increasing, and the maximum elongation was found to be as high as 1625% at the temperature of 656 K with the strain-rate of 7.6×10 −3 s −1 . DSC analysis shows the crystallized volume fraction in the deformed section is always higher than that of the undeformed section in the specimens. The maximum elongation always corresponds to the maximum crystallized volume fraction. Nanocrystals homogeneously embedded in the amorphous matrix of the deformed specimens were observed by transmission electron microscope. It is conjectured that the nanocrystallization was induced by the flow stress and environmental temperature. Keywords B. Glasses, metallic B. Superplastic behaviour D. Microstructure F. Calorimetry F. Electron microscopy, transmission 1 Introduction Zr-based bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) have unique mechanical properties such as high strength and low elastic modulus [1,2] . They also have a good processability in the supercooled liquid state, which is attractive for applications in near-net-shape fabrication of complex components [3,4] . Since the 1990s, superplastic behavior of BMGs in the supercooled liquid region has been widely studied. Kawamura et al. [5–10] , Lu et al. [11] and Johnson et al. [12] showed that the high temperature deformation behavior of Zr-based BMGs could be classified as Newtonian or non-Newtonian type flow. Nieh et al. [13] , Lee et al. [14] and Bae et al. [15] studied the phase transformation of BMGs during superplastic flow process and found that nanocrystallization could be induced by an applied stress. Nieh et al. [16] suggested that non-Newtonian type flow could be attributed to nanocrystallization during deformation of a BMG. So far, the reports about tensile tests of BMGs in the supercooled liquid region are relatively limited. In this paper, tensile deformation behavior of a BMG was investigated at various initial strain-rates and temperatures. 2 Experimental procedure The material used in the present study has the composition Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 . Alloy ingots were prepared by arc-melting a mixture of pure metal elements in a titanium-gettered argon atmosphere, followed by suction into a copper mold to form sheet-like BMG samples with a size of 3×70×30 mm. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed to observe the microstructure by using a TECNAI T20 (200 kV) microscope and a PHILIPS EM430 (300 kV) microscope. The TEM samples were prepared using standard twin-jet electropolishing in a solution containing one part nitric acid and two parts methanol at 248 K. The thermal properties of the alloy were measured using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) in a Pekin–Elmer Pyris 1 DSC. The onset glass transition temperature ( T g onset ) , glass transition end temperature ( T g end ) and onset crystallization temperature ( T x ) were examined at a heating rate of 20 K/min. Tensile test specimens were fabricated from the sheet-like BMG samples by means of electrical discharge machining. They had a gauge length of 11 mm, a thickness of 3 mm and a width of 1.1 mm. High temperature deformation tests were conducted using an Instron 5500R1186 type machine equipped with an air furnace. Tensile tests were carried out at the temperatures of 616, 636, 656 and 676 K. These temperatures were in the range of T g – T x , which involves the supercooled liquid region of the BMG. 3 Results and discussion DSC curve of the as-cast BMG sample is shown in Fig. 1 . T g onset , T g end and T x can be clearly identified as 616, 656 and 698 K, respectively. The stress–strain curves for the BMG specimens at different test temperatures and strain-rates are shown in Fig. 2 . As can be seen, BMG shows homogeneous deformation in the supercooled liquid region. Typically, a yield drop or a stress overshoot phenomenon is observed. The stress reaches a peak and then decreases significantly with increasing strain. The yield drop phenomenon has also been reported in Pd 40 Ni 40 P 20 [5] , Zr 65 Al 10 Ni 10 Cu 15 [7] , Fe 72 Hf 8 Nb 2 B 18 [8] and Zr 52.5 Ti 5 Ni 14.6 Cu 17.9 Al 10 [14] alloys. It is considered to be the result of rapid increase of free volume during the process of deformation. On reaching the peak stress, the excessive free volume is quickly redistributed via rearrangement of local atoms, which may induce the yield drop. In the present study BMG is considered to be a kind of material without defects, unable to exhibit the strain-hardening during the tensile deformation process. Therefore the local necking is unavoidable as shown in Fig. 3 . As a result, the stress yield drop is affected by the local necking besides the redistribution of the free volume. It is evident in Fig. 2 that the flow stress, peak stress and elongation depend strongly on strain-rates and test temperatures. The BMG exhibits a high fracture stress of 1860 MPa at room temperature (not shown). With increasing temperature to 616 K, the fracture stress decreases to 1388 MPa ( Fig. 2 (a)). At this temperature, sudden fracture is observed in the tensile samples and the deformation is inhomogeneous, which is similar to the behavior at room temperature. On the other hand, in the temperature range of 636–676 K, catastrophic fracture does not occur due to the homogeneous deformation. The yield drop decreases with further increase in temperature. The strain-rate is also a factor in the deformation behavior of the BMG. With decreasing strain-rate the behavior transforms from inhomogeneous to homogeneous deformation, as shown in Fig. 2 (a). The dependence of yield drop on strain-rate is shown in Fig. 2 (b)–(d). The elongation increases initially and then decreases with increasing strain-rate. The maximum elongation reaches as high as 1625% at 656 K with the strain-rate of 7.6×10 −3 s −1 . Fig. 3 shows the tensile specimens after deformed at 656 K with different initial strain-rates. To investigate microstructural evolution during superplastic deformation, a series of DSC analyses were carried out on the deformed specimens. It is conjectured that the strain energy stored during superplastic deformation may reduce the thermal activation energy barrier required for crystallization, as was suggested by Lee et al. [14] , Bae et al. [15] and Nieh et al. [16] . Two samples for DSC measurements were prepared from each deformed specimen. One was cut from the grip section (undeformed section), and another one was cut from the region near to the fracture point (deformed section). Figs. 4 and 5 show the DSC curves for the samples cut from the undeformed and deformed sections after tensile test at 636 and 656 K, respectively. For the purpose of comparison, the DSC trace for the as-cast Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 alloy is also given. The DSC curves for the specimens deformed at higher strain-rates are similar to that of the as-cast specimen, although the heat of crystallization is lower than that of the as-cast specimen. When the strain-rate decreases to 1.5×10 −3 s −1 at 636 K, 7.6×10 −3 s −1 at 656 K or 3×10 −2 s −1 at 676 K, the first crystallization peak on the DSC curves disappears. These results indicate that the amorphous phase evolves to a primary crystallization during deformation. As we know, BMG generally exhibits a distinct glass transition ( T g ) with an endothermic reaction, followed by the appearance of a wide supercooled liquid region (Δ T x = T x − T g ). Then, an exothermic reaction due to crystallization occurs at the onset crystallization temperature, T x . The heat of crystallization can be measured by integrating the peak area of exothermic crystallization. The crystallized volume fraction for deformed specimens is calculated as: (1) V f = ( 1 − Δ H D Δ H C ) 100 % where Δ H D is the heat of crystallization for a deformed specimen, and Δ H C is the heat of crystallization for the as-cast metallic glass. The value of Δ H D is measured from the deformed and undeformed section of the deformed samples, respectively. The integrated heat of crystallization and the tensile elongation measured from the deformed and undeformed sections of specimens tested under various conditions are summarized in Table 1 . The crystallized volume fraction reaction percentage and the corresponding elongations, varying with the strain-rates at different test temperatures, are summarized in Fig. 6 . It is evident that the crystallized volume fraction percentages of the undeformed sections decrease with increasing strain-rate. This is because the time for the sample exposed to high temperature increases with decreasing strain-rate. It is also clearly shown that the reaction percentages of deformed sections are always higher than those of the undeformed sections when the specimens are exposed at a given temperature. This indicates that the crystallization of amorphous phase is affected by both environmental heating and flow stress. In the undeformed sections crystallization is affected by the heat treatment during the superplastic extension process. For the deformed sections, however, the crystallization is affected by both flow stress and isothermal treatment. Lee et al. [14] and Nieh et al. [16] studied the microstructure of BMGs after superplastic deformation and suggested that the flow stress could induce crystallization at temperatures below the crystallization temperature during the superplastic deformation. In present study it is found that, when tensile test is carried out in the supercooled liquid region, transformation of amorphous phase to crystalline phase occurs because the DSC analysis shows that the heats of crystallization of undeformed sections are always less than that of the as-cast specimen. On the other hand, this phase transformation process is accelerated by the applied flow stress because the heats of crystallization of deformed sections are always less than those of undeformed sections (as shown in Table 1 ). As seen from Fig. 6 , the changes of crystallized volume fraction of the deformed samples with strain-rate are quite different from those of the undeformed samples. The former generally shows a peak (except for deformation at a lower temperature of 616 K) at a specific strain-rate, roughly, at which the elongation also features a peak value. For example, in the case of deformation at 636 K with the strain-rate of 1.5×10 −3 s −1 , the elongation of the specimen reaches its maximum of 1110%, and the crystallized volume fraction reaches its maximum of 14.2%. This implies that crystallization occurs to the largest extent in the deformation process of the deformed samples with the largest elongation. This finding provides direct evidence for the statement that crystallization of amorphous material could be activated either by heating or by stress. A further study of BMG's microstructure is carried out using TEM. Fig. 7 shows images and the corresponding selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns for the samples tested at 636 K with the strain-rate of 7.6×10 −4 s −1 ( Fig. 7 (a) and (b)) and at 656 K with the strain-rate of 7.6×10 −3 s −1 ( Fig. 7 (c) and (d)). The TEM samples were extracted from the deformed section. It is evident that there are dispersed nanocrystals embedded in the amorphous matrix. The nanocrystal sizes are approximately 10±3 nm at 636 K and 25±3 nm at 656 K ( Fig. 7 (a) and (c)). The corresponding SAED patterns show the polycrystalline halos, since the sizes of the precipitated phase are small. The SAED shown in Fig. 7 (b) displays the multiple rings indicating that a substantial fraction of the amorphous phase still exists. The second inner ring of the diffraction pattern of the specimen deformed at 636 K is slightly sharper and the pattern contains two more outer-diffraction rings compared with a diffraction pattern of the as-cast specimen. These features also reveal the presence of nanocrystals embedded in an amorphous matrix. Based on Fig. 7 (d), it is determined that the nanocrystals are hexagonal Be 2 Zr for the specimens deformed at 656 K. This result agrees well with the argument made by Busch et al. [17] and Wanderka et al. [18] . They suggested that Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 metallic glass annealed between 613 and 673 K would undergo decomposition and primary crystallization. The decomposition brings out Be-rich and Zr-rich regions. In present study, it is confirmed that, when Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 alloy is exposed at 656 K for a certain time, primary crystallization occurs to produce Be 2 Zr phase as a dominant phase, possibly precipitating from the decomposed Be-rich region. 4 Conclusions (1) The superplastic flow behavior of Zr 41.25 Ti 13.75 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 bulk metallic glass in the supercooled liquid region, viz. the flow stress and the elongation, varies depending strongly on the test temperature and initial strain-rate. The elongation increases firstly and then decreases with the strain-rate increasing and the maximum elongation reaches as high as 1625% at 656 K with the strain-rate 7.6×10 −3 s −1 . (2) The crystallized volume fraction of deformed section is always higher than the crystallization fraction of undeformed section of the tensile test specimens. The maximum elongation always corresponds to the maximum crystallized volume fraction. And consequently, flow stress and environmental temperature are believed to be two main factors affecting the phase transformation during the superplastic deformation of the amorphous material. (3) It is found that the precipitation of nanocrystals is driven by the flow stress and environmental temperature. In addition, the maximum elongations coinciding with the maximum crystallized volume fraction further illustrates that the effect of the flow stress on nanocrystallization is unavoidable during the tensile deformation process. As a result, the superplastic deformation leads to the precipitation of the nanocrystal phases. Acknowledgements This work is in part supported by Harbin Institute of Technology Foundation. The assistance of staff and use of resources in the Electron Microscope Unit at ANU is acknowledged. References [1] A. Inoue Acta Mater 48 2000 279 [2] W.L. Johnson MRS Bull 24 10 1999 42 [3] Y. hZDI0Q7G.title: Synthesis and mechanical properties of Zr-Cu-Ni-Ta-Al bulk amorphous alloy matrix composites
hZDI0Q7G.abstract: Zr-based bulk amorphous alloy (BAA) matrix composites with Ta crystalline phase as reinforcement were prepared by arc-melting copper mold casting method. The effect of Ta element adding on the glass-forming ability and the mechanical properties of (Zr 0.65Cu 0.175 Ni 0.175) 90-xTa x Al 10 (x=0, 4, 6, 8, 10) (at%) alloys were investigated mainly by means of differential scanning calorimeter (DSC), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electric microscopy (SEM). It was shown that the Ta element adding into alloy matrix changed the crystallization behaviors of continuous heating for the alloys. For (Zr 0.65Ni 0.175 Cu 0.175) 80Ta 10Al 10 alloy composite, the solubility limit of Ta in the amorphous phases is approximately 4%. The maximum stress and plastic strain of the composite containing 10% Ta are as high as 1855 MPa and 3.2%, respectively, both higher than those of the Ta-free BAA. The Ta crystalline particles prevent the catastrophic propagation of the single shear band, favorable for the formation of multiple shear bands, and significantly increasing the plastic strain and yield strength under an uniaxial compression, compared to the Ta-free alloy.

uNvNNeXB.title: Lamellar Orientation Control in γ-TiAl Alloys by Directional Solidification
uNvNNeXB.abstract: Gamma titanium aluminide(γ-TiAl) alloys are candidate materials for lightweight high-temperature structural applications and the mechanical properties of the alloys with fully lamellar microstructure are extremely anisotropic.In the seed method of directional solidification,the seed crystal materials with special lamellar orientation are applied,the high-temperature α phases are controlled to grow along <112 0> direction,and finally the fully lamellar microstructures parallel to the growth direction are obtained.Another approach of controlling the orientation of lamellar microstructure is to change the solidification pathway so that the alloys solidify completely with β phases,and the obtained lamellar microstructure is aligned at 0° and 45° angles to the grow direction.This paper summarized the mechanism and recent research progress of the lamellar orientation control by the two methods in TiAl alloys,and systemically studied the effects of the alloy composition and processing parameters on the lamellar orientation control process.Finally the problems of aligned lamellar microstructure preparation in TiAl alloys at home and abroad that needed to be further investigated were presented.

7W8ur0mk.title: The value of MRI examination on bilateral hands including proximal interphalangeal joints for disease assessment in patients with early rheumatoid arthritis: a cross-sectional cohort study.
7W8ur0mk.abstract: In consideration of asymmetric MRI features in early RA, potential overuse influence for certain tenosynovitis in dominant hands, and high prevalence of MRI findings in PIPJs, MRI examination on bilateral hands including PIPJs is deserved for disease assessment in early RA patients.

31XSTLZG.title: Study of the working performance of WO 2 nanowire arrays in gated field emission display devices
31XSTLZG.abstract: Tungsten oxide nanowires are integrated into gated wing-type field emission display (FED) devices, which are synthesized at low temperature of 550 °C by catalyzed-growth CVD way. The emission behaviors of the device are testified by transparent anode way to investigate their future application. These WO 2 FED devices are found to have a turn-on field of 5.76 V/μm and their emission current density reaches 0.59 mA/cm 2 when the applied field is 7.55 V/μm. It suggests that they should have a promising future in field emission applications if their emission uniformity can be further improved. © 2012 IEEE.

N09KWOMR.title: Magnetic properties and magnetic entropy change in Heusler alloys Ni 50Mn35-x Cu x Sn15
N09KWOMR.abstract: The influence of Cu substitution for Mn on magnetic properties and magnetic entropy change has been investigated in Heusler alloys, Ni50Mn 35-x Cu x Sn15 (x=2,5 and 10). With increasing Cu content from x=2 to x=5, the martensitic transition temperature, T M , decreases from 220 K to 120 K. Further increasing Cu up to x=10 results in the disappearance of T M . For samples Ni 50Mn33Cu2Sn15 and Ni 50Mn30Cu5Sn15, both martensitic and austenitic states exhibit ferromagnetic characteristics, but the magnetization of martensitic phase is notably lower than that of austenitic phase. The magnetization difference, ΔM, across the martensitic transition leads to a considerably large Zeeman energy, μ 0ΔṀH, which drives a field-induced metamagnetic transition. Associated with the metamagnetic behavior, a large positive magnetic entropy change ΔS takes place around T M . For the sample Ni50Mn33Cu 2Sn15,ΔS reaches 13.5 J/kġ under a magnetic field change from 0 to 5 T. © 2009 Springer-Verlag.

QpTJGUm9.title: Dynamic Service Selection for Service Composition with Time Constraints
QpTJGUm9.abstract: Service selection is a kind of planning approach that evaluates and selects from multiple services to form a composite plan. In service selection, we found one additional issue that has not been investigated yet namely time constraints consistency among composite services. This issue is significant because there are potential time constraints involved that might cause inconsistency between selected services although they can offer aggregated QoS that satisfy global requirements. Furthermore, there might be some unintended waiting time to be considered in the QoS aggregation. Thus, this paper contributes to the analysis on the problem caused by the time constraints and proposes general selection approach to tackle these issues. The approach comprises two major functionalities; (i) exploration of the process model based on patterns, (ii) evaluation of candidates based on time constraints and objective functions.

2nEEbQB7.title: Experimental study on an absorption refrigeration system driven by temperature-distributed heat sources
2nEEbQB7.abstract: Abstract   The absorption refrigeration system driven by low grade heat sources, especially the waste heat sources, becomes more and more attractive in recent decades. However, most traditional absorption systems cannot achieve a high utilization rate of the waste heat with limited heat capacity. These systems are usually designed to obtain heat in the generator, which means that the waste heat sources cannot be utilized to the temperature lower than the generator temperature. This paper proposed a new structure heated by heat conduction oil in the generator and electric heating rings around the stripping section. This structure can simulate the temperature-distributed heat sources when the electric heating rings work. It can also simulate a traditional generator when the electric heating rings do not work. Influences of different heat distributions are analyzed in detail in this paper. The results show that the heat sources utilization rate will increase with the increase of the heat in the stripping section, while the coefficient of performance will be negatively affected by the increasing heat in the stripping section. By optimizing the heating structure, the coefficient of performance can be similar to that of a traditional system when the heat is just added in the middle and lower part of stripping section. The optimum utilization rate of heat sources in this test model can reach 1.8 times to that of a traditional system. Under this heating model, the lowest temperature required in the heating section is 82 °C when the heat conduction oil inlet temperature is 169 °C. It is much lower than the temperature inside the generator, which is 137.3 °C.

b7gVFVeR.title: Effect of rotating magnetic field on microstructure formation of directionally solidified Sn-1.6Cd peritectic alloy
b7gVFVeR.abstract: In order to investigate the effect of rotating magnetic field on the microstructure formation of peritectic alloys, directional solidification experiments of Sn-1.6Cd peritectic alloy have been conducted under different rotating magnetic field conditions. The directional solidification microstructure of Sn-1.6Cd peritectic alloy changes from banded structure to axisymmetric isolated banded structure to axisymmetric oscillatory tree-like banded structure and to single primary phase structure when the magnetic Taylor number of forced-melt flow generated by a rotating magnetic field increases from 0 to 91 to 364 and to 1456. The second and third banded structures are observed in a peritectic alloy for the first time. The results indicate that it is possible to control solidification microstructure and prepare a single primary phase structure by using a rotating magnetic field during directional solidification of peritectic alloys. The experiments show that the effect of forced-melt flow on solute distribution transforms from solute buildup to homogenization with an increase in the magnetic Taylor number. The formation mechanisms of those structures are also discussed. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2013.

brpL7LAx.title: Low-temperature Preparation of Mechanically Robust and Contamination-resistant Antireflective Coatings for Flexible Polymeric Glasses via Embedding of Silica Nanoparticles and HMDS Modification.
brpL7LAx.abstract: Mechanical and contamination-resistance properties are the most crucial and challenging issues which impede the practical application of sol-gel antireflective (AR) coating. In this paper, we report a low-temperature vapor surface treatment strategy for the partial embedding and surface functionalization of silica nanoparticles (SNPs) on flexible polymeric glass substrates. SNPs, which were synthesized via Stöber method, were partially embedded onto the polymeric glass substrates by vapor-phase surface treatment of volatile chloroform. Further vapor-phase surface treatments of water and hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS) were applied successively to achieve high trimethylsilyl coverage of the SNPs. The HMDS modification could convert the polar surface of SNPs to nonpolar surface for contamination-resistance, while the ammonia, as by-product generated, could help to cross-link the SNPs via self-condensation of silanol groups, thus hardening the coating. The SNP-CWH coated PMMA substrate shows an average transmittance of 98.62% in the wavelength region of 400-800 nm, which is 6.32% higher than the uncoated bare PMMA. The AR performance of SNP-CWH coated PMMA has almost no degradation after 100 times of rubbing or bending, indicating the greatly enhanced abrasion-resistance and flexibility. Furthermore, the SNP-CWH coating exhibits superior contamination-resistance property, where the transmittance curve of the coated substrate displays barely noticeable change after exposure to a "dirty" environment with water and organic contaminants for 6 months. This work paves the new way for developing mechanically robust and contamination-resistant AR coating for polymeric substrates.

ERl3Pb89.title: Effect of Preparation Conditions on Property of Zirconia Optical Films
ERl3Pb89.abstract: The stable ZrO2 sol is prepared by sol-gel process with Zr(O-Bu)4 as the starting materials in this paper . The ZrO2 films and the ZrO2-PVP composite films are derived by spin-coating, and they are characterized by XRD, ellipsometer, FTIR and AFM, respectively. And the laser damage threshold is also measured. The results show that the laser damage threshold of these films is increased by incorporation of organic binder. The proper temperature of heat-treatment is 300℃?After heat-treatment at 300℃,the ZrO2 films with PVP have high laser damage threshold (52 J/cm2) .

IXAxDqOC.abstract: A method was employed to improve the growth condition of carbon nanotube (CNT) in microwave plasma CVD system. Plasma etching on silicon substrates was avoided effectively. CNT bundles arrays were synthesized and the CNTs were vertical to the substrate. ©2006 IEEE.

0dGPwpL2.title: Fabrication and mechanical properties of WC-Co-Al2O3 nanocomposites by spark plasma sintering
0dGPwpL2.abstract: Small amounts of nanocrystalline Al2O3 particles were doped in WC-Co nanocrystalline powders to study their reinforcing effects, and spark plasma sintering technique was used to fabricate the WC-Co-Al2O3 nanocomposites. Experimental results show that the use of Al2O3 nanoparticles as dispersions to reinforce WC-Co composites can increase the hardness, especially the transverse rupture strength of the WC-Co hardmetal. With addition of 0.5% (mass fraction) Al2O3 nanoparticles, the spark plasma sintered WC-7Co-0.5Al2O3 nanocomposites exhibit hardness of 21.22 GPa and transverse rupture strength of 3548 MPa. The fracture surface of the WC-7Co-0.5Al2O3 nanocomposites mainly fracture with transcrystalline rupture mode. The reinforcing mechanism is maybe related to the hindrance effect of microcracks propagation and the pinning effect for the dislocations movement, as well as the residual compressive strength due to the Al2O3 nanoparticles doped.

2NZcLiyH.title: Range-image-based calculation of three-dimensional convex object moments
2NZcLiyH.abstract: In the paper, a novel method is proposed to calculate three-dimensional (3-D) moments. First, a discrete Gaussian theorem is proposed to convert the summation in a 3-D volume domain to that on a 2-D plane region, which decreases computational complexity from O(N3) to O(N2). Second, a Pascal triangle transform, a Pascal triangle matrix, and a systolic structure are proposed to calculate the monomials on a 3-D object boundary surface, which simplifies the monomial calculation. Third, a range-image measurement system is used to implement the new method. Finally, a comparison of the authors' method with the known ones is provided, showing that the authors' method is much simpler

PiGVZaj6.title: Field pull-out test research on tension and pressrue unbonded anchor cables
PiGVZaj6.abstract: The shear stress distribution curves of tension and pressure unbonded anchor cable between grouting body and rock hole wall, and the shear stress distribution curves of tension anchor cable between grouting body and steel wires are given;then, the shear stress distribution laws along the grouting body length are obtained by field pull-out tests. The tests results show that, for the tension anchor cable, shear stress peak value between grouting body and rock hole wall is less than that between grouting body and steel wires, but the shear stress distribution length is longer and the peak value point locates in back grouting segment. The shear stress between grouting body and rock hole wall is not equally distributed no matter what the anchor cable type is, and the peak value point locates at different grouting segment positions. For the pressure anchor cable, shear stress peak value is large and the distribution length is short and shear stress decays quickly under the same load. The effective bonded length of tension anchor cable increases significantly with the increasing resisting load. On the other hand, the shear stress peak value of pressure anchor cable increases significantly with the increasing resisting load. The bearing capacity of tension anchor cable is constant and it is normally adopted when requiring lower bearing capacity, the key construction is ensuring the grouting length. The bearing capacity of pressure anchor cable is in proportion to the number of the pressure bearing segment and it is adopted when requiring higher bearing capacity, the key construction is ensuring the grouting fullness and avoiding the grouting body shrinkage.

oSmtrhqE.title: Field electron emission from ultra-high density Si nanotip arrays
oSmtrhqE.abstract: Earlier, welldeveloped techniques of reactive ion etching (insotropic) and wet chemical etching (anisotropic) in combination with oxidation sharpening were used for the fabrication of nanotip arrays for field electron emission applications. The fabrications require lithography technique to form masks for the following etching, and normally high temperature oxidation sharpening process is needed. In the present paper, we report a non-lithography and non-oxidation-sharpening method for ultra-high .&nsity Si nanotip arrays fabrication. In addition, novel processes were developed to obtain Si nanotip array with different coating materials on apex, i.e., Sic and amorphous Si (a-Si). Comparative studies were carried out on the field electron emission properties of the Si nanotip arrays with different coated layers.

ZhroI8hq.title: Solidification characteristics of rapidly solidified high speed steel powders produced by water atomization
ZhroI8hq.abstract: The cooling rate of the water atomized powders of M3/2 high speed steel was calculated to be 105-107 K/s. In the size range of the atomized powders, the microstructure consisted of equiaxed crystals and continuous network-like carbides between the equiaxed grains. The matrix of the powders was principally austenite; as the particle size decreased, the matrix changed from austenite to a composite consisting of austenite and δ-ferrite. The types of carbides were mainly cubic MC and close-packed hexagonal M2C.

mhcQJM2Z.title: The crust structures and tectonics of Ürumqi depression revealed by deep seismic reflection profile in the northern margin of Tianshan mountains
mhcQJM2Z.abstract: It is known from the active tectonic research results that the northern margin of Tianshan mountains is characterized with typical intra-continental active tectonics, which has thrust faults and anticlines with multiple parallel mountains. In order to investigate the fine crustal structures and the main fault geometries as well as the deep-shallow tectonic relations in Ürümqi depression, a deep seismic reflection profile of 78 km long, running in nearly SN direction, was completed in 2004. This profile is located in the transition zone between Tianshan mountains and Junggar Basin of the western Ürümqi. The results show that the crust beneath the investigated area is divided into upper and lower crusts by a strong reflective zone with about 9 ∼ 10.5 s TWT. The thicknesses of the upper and lower crusts are about 26 ∼ 28 km, 23 ∼ 25 km, respectively. There are rich reflective layers and clear tectonic patterns above 5s TWT while presenting obviously different tectonic features along the profile. In the southern region of Xishan, the stacked deep seismic reflection section has a series of thrust anticlines extending in the EW direction and arranging in the SN as well as a group of faults thrusting from south to north. All of those are influenced by the deep detachment zone. In the Xishan and Wangjiagou area, it shows a set of steeply north-dipping reflective layers and a group of faults slipping along the layers. The northern part of the profile shows the images of typical sediment basin and its deepest depth is about 10 ∼ 12 km. Between 6 and 9 s TWT, the stacked deep seismic reflection section shows disordered reflections with comparatively short continuing time and weak energy. These indicate that this part of the crust is evidently possessed with "reflection transparence". The Moho transition zone occurs at 14 ∼ 17 s TWT, and the zone thickness is about 9 ∼ 10 km. In the studied area, the Moho discontinuity gradually deepens from north to south. Its depth is about 50 ∼ 52 km at the northern segment of the profile and is about 54 ∼ 55 km near north Tianshan. In the neighbourhood of Xishan at the middle profile, the reflections from the boundary between upper and lower crusts as well as Moho transition zone become misty while the shallow stratums show signs of uplift and fold, which may have something to do with the extrusions between Junggar basin and Tianshan mountains.

W4P2anGu.title: Microstructural evolution of Ti-47Al alloy during directional solidification by seeding method
W4P2anGu.abstract: Microstructural evolution during directional solidification (DS) of Ti-47Al alloy grown from Ti-43Al-3Si seed was studied. The high-temperature hexagonal close packed α-phase can be correctly oriented in the case of cellular solid/liquid interface at growth rate of 90 mm/h, so the final lamellar microstructure was parallel to the DS direction in the initial part of ingot. With the progress of solidification, the composition of liquid was close to Ti-47Al alloy that is favorable for β phase formation, and β phase started to nucleate and grow among the interdendrites of α phase, therefore lamellar microstructure inclined with an angle of 45° to the DS direction and the process of seeding was interrupted. As the growth rate reached 720 mm/h, finer α dendrites grew in preferred crystallographic direction and the lamellar microstructure was vertical to the DS direction.

tnqw4KWg.title: Photon absorption of conduction-band electrons in fused silica
tnqw4KWg.abstract: By using a second-order and third-order perturbation theory, the interaction rates of intense laser field at wavelength of 193 nm and 355 nm with conduction-band electrons of fused silica were calculated. Compared with the linear absorption of conduction-band electron simultaneously absorbing or emitting an acoustic or longitudinal optical photon, the linear absorption simultaneously scattering off a hole and two-photon absorption are important in the process of electrons transferring laser energy to solids.

xFzYZzrO.title: A TEM study on the crystallization behavior of an yttrium-doped Zr-based bulk metallic glass
xFzYZzrO.abstract: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is used to conduct the systematic study of the annealing induced crystallization, both continuously and isothermally, of a Zr-based metallic glass. Through detailed microstructure analysis, it is found that the crystallization of this metallic glass is initialized by a nano-scaled primary crystallization process with a tetragonal structured crystal ( a = 0.96 nm and c = 2.82 nm) as the primary phase. A eutectic crystallization is followed afterwards with two types of crystalline phases as the crystallization products, one of which is determined to be a metastable orthorhombic phase ( a = 0.69 nm, b = 0.75 nm and c = 0.74 nm). Upon annealing at a raised temperature or isothermal treatments, a solid state phase transformation takes place and the orthorhombic metastable phase transforms into two types of tetragonal crystalline phases. The whole crystallization process of this metallic glass is in turn realized, and the thermal stability and nano-crystallization mechanism are discussed based on the microstructure and thermal analyses. Keywords B. Glasses, metallic F. Electron microscopy, transmission B. Thermal stability D. Microstructure 1 Introduction Crystallization behavior study has been hotly pursued in the field of bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) for at least two reasons. Firstly, it is critical for the achievement of partially or fully nano-crystallized BMG composites, which show higher comprehensive mechanical properties [1,2] or enhanced physical properties, such as soft magnetism [3] . Secondly, it is critical for the thermal stability assessment of BMGs, considering that they are thought to be potentially good industrial materials and yet in metastable states compared with their crystalline counterparts [4] . Zr-based BMGs are one of the best glass forming alloys and have shown prospective engineering applications. Very recently, we discovered that the glass forming ability (GFA) and mechanical properties of an oxygen-containing Zr-based BMG, i.e. Zr 51 Al 16.3 Ni 12 Cu 20.7 , can be optimized in terms of GFA by a 0.5 at% yttrium doping [5,6] . The thus obtained yttrium-doped BMG, (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 , shows a high GFA ( T rg = 0.633), high glass transition temperature ( T g = 725 K) and high fracture strength ( σ f = 2.04 GPa). However, for this material to be practically useful, it is necessary to investigate its thermal stability as well as the crystallization mechanism when subjected to thermal exposure. In this study, annealing induced crystallization behavior of the (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 alloy is investigated by TEM and other structural characterization techniques. Thermal stability, crystallization mode and solid state phase transformation in the crystallization process have been discussed. 2 Experimental An alloy with a nominal composition of (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 was fabricated in Ф3 mm samples. These samples were prepared by the non-consumed arc melting and copper mold casting techniques. During the fabrication, raw materials were melted at least four times to ensure the compositional homogeneity and high purity argon was used as the protective atmosphere. Thermal analysis was performed on a Perkin–Elmer Pyris I differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) machine. Fig. 1 shows a DSC curve with a heating rate of 0.167 K/s for the as-cast alloy, in which T g (=725 K) and T x (=802 K) are marked by arrows. It is noted that there is a second peak on the DSC curve at the temperature of about 904 K (referred as T s ), which might correspond to a solid state phase transformation [7] . Based on these characteristic temperatures, the annealing temperatures were designed at 673 K (sub- T g temperature), 723 K (near- T g temperature), 773 K (in the super-cooled liquid region) and at two higher temperatures of 873 and 923 K. Isothermal annealing experiments were also performed at these temperatures with a holding time of 30 min to investigate the response of the microstructure to the isothermal treatment. Annealing treatments were conducted in a nitrogen gas protected furnace with the heating rate of 0.167 K/s, followed by quenching to room temperature. The annealed samples were characterized using TEM, X-ray diffraction (XRD) and DSC. TEM investigation was carried out on a 200 kV Tecnai F20. XRD study was performed on a D/max IIIA diffractometer with a Cu Kα target operated at 40 kV and 60 mA. TEM specimens were prepared by electro-polishing method using a chemical solution of 5% H 2 SO 4 + 95% methanol. The ImageJ software was used to do the image analysis of the obtained TEM images in terms of the crystal size and volume fraction of the crystalline phases. 3 Results 3.1 Primary crystallization Fig. 2 (a) presents the XRD patterns for the as-cast and annealed alloys, where 673 K – 0 min, 673 K – 30 min, 723 K – 0 min, 723 K – 30 min and 773 K – 0 min denote the corresponding annealing temperatures and times. The alloys do not show any significant crystallization even after annealing at 773 K, as evidenced by the diffuse peaks in these XRD curves. Fig. 3 shows the TEM bright-field images of the alloys with inserted corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns. In consistent with the XRD results, one can see that the amorphous phase dominates the microstructure in these alloys with a very small fraction (<2%) of nano-sized (10–30 nm) crystalline phases in the annealed alloys. To clarify the crystal structure of the particles present in these annealed alloys, extensive SAED studies have been carried out and the results show that these nano-scaled crystals have the same crystal structure with large lattice parameters (referred as LL phase hereafter). Fig. 4 (a) shows a high resolution image of a representative primary phase and its SAED pattern (inset). Since this LL phase can be determined to be one of the final crystallization products, its detailed structure specification will be discussed in detail later on. EDS analysis, shown in Fig. 4 (b), indicates that the primary crystalline phase contains an increased Cu concentration and a decreased Zr concentration when compared with the composition of the amorphous matrix. At the same time, no noticeable compositional change can be detected for the Al and Ni elements. 3.2 High temperature crystallization and solid state phase transformation Significant crystallization can be observed in the alloys isothermally annealed for 30 min at the temperature of 773 K or in the alloys continuously heated up to 873 K, as evidenced by the XRD patterns shown in Fig. 2 (b). It is of interest to note that the XRD patterns for the 773 K-30 min and 873 K-0 min alloys show two main peaks while more peaks can be seen for the 873 K-30 min, 923 K-0 min and 923 K-30 min alloys, in which one of the main peaks (at∼36.5°) that belongs to the 773 K-30 min and 873 K-0 min alloys disappears. Based on these, one can realize that phase transformation is involved in this period of crystallization and this transformation should be completed either when annealed at 923 K or with a 30 min isothermal treatment at 873 K, as evidenced by the almost identical XRD patterns for the 873 K-30 min, 923 K-0 min and 923 K-30 min alloys. Fig. 5 presents the TEM bright-field images with inserted corresponding SAED patterns, showing the general morphology of the 773 K-30 min ( Fig. 5 (a)) and 873 K-0 min ( Fig. 5 (b)) alloys. Extensive SAED studies suggest that there are only two types of crystalline phases associated with these two alloys, including the LL phase that appears in the low temperature annealed alloys as the primary phase. Interestingly, some of the LL structured phases have grown to a relatively large size, associated with twin structures, as shown in  Fig. 5 (b). Detailed structural analysis of these twin structures suggests that this phase has a similar crystal structure with a tetragonal phase discovered by de Oliveira et al. in an annealed Zr 55 Al 10 Ni 5 Cu 30 alloy [8] . Through careful TEM analysis, we determine the lattice parameters of this LL phase to be a = 0.96 nm and c = 2.82 nm. In addition, the chemical composition of this phase is determined as Zr 47.5 Cu 29.6 Ni 13.0 Al 9.9 by averaging multiple TEM EDS analysis results. Fig. 6 shows a TEM bright-field image of the other crystalline phase and its corresponding SAED patterns (insets) along different zone axes. The crystal structure of this phase is indexed to be orthorhombic with lattice parameters of a = 0.69 nm, b = 0.75 nm and c = 0.74 nm. This crystal phase was also detected in similar Zr-based BMGs [6] , whose precipitation was accompanied by the fcc structured NiZr 2 that was believed to be a metastable phase in certain circumstances [9] . For the 873 K-30 min, 923 K-0 min and 923 K-30 min alloys, Fig. 7 (a)–(c) shows their general morphologies with the corresponding inserted SAED patterns. It can be seen that the nano-crystallization is realized in these high temperature annealed alloys, and the crystal size of most of the phases is in the scale of tens of nanometres. Extensive SAED investigation suggests that there are three crystalline phases in these alloys. Apart from the above-mentioned primary crystalline phase, two crystalline phases are observed and their TEM images and corresponding SAED patterns are given in Fig. 7 (d) and (e), respectively. The phase shown in Fig. 7 (d) has a tetragonal structure with the lattice parameters of a = 1.59 nm and c = 1.13 nm, which is close to the primitive tetragonal Zr 2 Cu phase while the phase shown in Fig. 7 (e) has a tetragonal structure with the lattice parameters of a = 0.32 nm and c = 1.12 nm, which is close to the body-centered tetragonal Zr 2 Cu phase. Interestingly, the orthorhombic phase existing in the lower temperature annealed alloys disappears in these alloys, suggesting it to be a metastable phase. It is then clear that, when the annealing treatments are carried out at higher temperatures, the solid state phase transformation takes place from the orthorhombic metastable phase to these two tetragonal crystalline phases. 4 Discussion 4.1 Primary crystallization and thermal stability According to the above TEM (together with EDS) studies, the averaged size and volume fraction of the primary phases as a function of the annealing temperature as well as the holding time are shown in Fig. 8 (a); the composition variation of the primary phase in these alloys is shown in Fig. 8 (b). From Fig. 8 , it is clearly seen that the alloy in this study shows a nano-scaled primary crystallization with two characters: low nucleation rate (volume fraction from ∼0.5% to ∼2%) and low growth rate (averaged crystal size from ∼25 to ∼35 nm), combined with a slight increment in Zr concentration and decrease in Cu concentration when isothermal treatments are performed. Based on the current understanding, nano-scaled primary crystallization requires either the phase decomposition prior to the crystallization [10] or the existence of localized orders [11] . Considering that the crystal size of the primary phases in our alloy is larger than the short range orders or medium range orders [12] , the phase decomposition is more likely to be the reason for the nucleation/formation of these nano-scaled primary phases. Since the relative content of Zr and Cu is changed during the isothermal treatment, the inter-diffusion of Zr and Cu between the primary phases and the amorphous matrix should be responsible for the growth of these phases. Considering that Zr and Cu have relatively large atomic radius, the diffusivity should be slow, which will restrict the diffusion and hence limit the growth of the primary phase. The fact that the amorphous phase dominates the microstructure of the alloy annealed below the temperature of 773 K also indicates that this alloy has a good thermal stability when compared with some well-known Zr-based BMGs. For example, Zr 41.2 Ti 13.8 Ni 10 Cu 12.5 Be 22.5 and Zr 65 Cu 15 Ni 10 Al 10 alloys have crystallized up to 30% [13] and 100% [14] , respectively, when annealed at 723 K. In strong contrast, the alloy in this study has only ∼1% crystallization under the identical annealing condition. 4.2 Solid state phase transformation and crystallization sequence The appearance and disappearance of the orthorhombic phase when the alloy (Zr 0.51 Al 0.163 Ni 0.12 Cu 0.207 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 is annealed at different conditions indicate strongly that this orthorhombic phase is a metastable phase. Since metastable phases, in general, have a smaller surface energy [15] , their nucleation should become easier, which can result in a high nucleation rate. As high nucleation rate and low growth rate are necessary conditions for the nano-crystallization, it is reasonable to believe that the formation of metastable phases is the reason for the nano-crystallization in these high temperature annealed alloys. To give a quantitative evaluation of the nucleation and growth process, the activation energy for the nucleation and growth of the present alloy is studied via thermal analysis. Fig. 9 presents the DSC analysis results, from which the values of E n (activation energy for nucleation) and E g (activation energy for growth) can be determined to be ∼357.6 kJ/mol and ∼265.4 kJ/mol, respectively, by the method suggested by Lu et al. [16] . Compared with one of the famous Zr-based BMGs [17] , the nucleation activation energy of the present alloy is smaller and the growth activation energy is larger, corresponding to a high nucleation rate and a low growth rate and consistent with the TEM analysis results. On the other hand, as discussed above, we have determined that the primary phase in the temperature region of 673–773 K is a tetragonal structured LL phase; after 30 min isothermal treatment at 773 K or at higher annealing temperature of 873 K, an orthorhombic structured crystal appears together with the LL phase; and then this orthorhombic structured phase transforms into two tetragonal structured crystalline phases; in the end, the LL phase and these two tetragonal structured crystalline phases compose the final crystallization products. The whole crystallization process can be summarized as the schematic graph shown in Fig. 10 . 5 Conclusions (1) The primary phase formed in the crystallization process of the (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 alloy is determined to be a large lattice parameter phase with a = 0.96 nm and c = 2.82 nm. (2) During the crystallization process of the (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 alloy, a solid state phase transformation is involved between the metastable phase (orthorhombic structure with a = 0.69 nm, b = 0.75 nm and c = 0.74 nm) and two stable tetragonal phases ( a = 1.59 nm and c = 1.13 nm; a = 0.322 nm and c = 1.118 nm). (3) Nano-crystallization is realized in the high temperature annealed alloys with nucleation and growth activation energies of about 358 kJ/mol and 265 kJ/mol, respectively. (4) The general crystallization process of the (Zr 0.51 Cu 0.207 Ni 0.12 Al 0.163 ) 99.5 Y 0.5 alloy with increasing annealing temperature or time can be summarized as follows: amorphous phase → amorphous phase + primary LL phase → primary LL phase + (orthorhombic metastable phase + LL phase) → primary LL phase + (LL phase + primitive and body-centered tetragonal phases). NSfCZogI.title: Large-scale synthesis and optical behaviors of ZnO tetrapods
NSfCZogI.abstract: Zinc oxide tetrapods were synthesized on a large scale through thermal evaporation of zinc powder with a vapor transportation deposition method. Scanning electron microscope images gave clear evidences of twin planes at the junction of the tetrapods. Photoluminescence and waveguide behaviors of a single tetrapod were demonstrated with a near-field scanning optical microscope. © 2007 American Institute of Physics.

RCpqaBPF.title: Preparation of ultralow-density SiO2 aerogels by using a two-step sol-gel process
RCpqaBPF.abstract: The low-density SiO2 gels were prepared by using a two-step sol-gel process from the raw material TEOS with the influence of various solution ratios on the gelation process investigated. The comparative characterization of gels using different solvents, such as ethanol, acetone and methyl cyanide was also given, and the ultralow-density SiO2 aerogels with their density less than 10kg/m3 were prepared by using the CO2 supercritical drying technique. Besides, the structural difference between the SiO2 aero-gels prepared by the conventional single-step process and the two-step process was also presented.

i0eBc5nt.title: Synthesis of Fe-Cr-Mo-C-B amorphous coating with high corrosion resistance
i0eBc5nt.abstract: Fe-based metallic glasses usually possess ultrahigh hardness, elastic modulus/limit and wear/corrosion resistance. In the present investigation, atmospheric plasma spray was used to deposit Fe-based metallic coatings onto 921A navy steel and Ti-6Al-4V alloy substrates. The microstructure and corrosion properties of the Fe-based metallic coatings were studied. It was found that the obtained Fe-based coating with about 300 μm in thickness showed fully amorphous state and possessed low porosity. Moreover, the Fe-based coating exhibited better corrosion resistance than 921A navy steel and Ti-6Al-4V alloy in aggressive H 2SO 4 solutions. This amorphous metallic coating could be applied as an excellent alternative material in corrosion environments. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

ha9Xr6KG.title: Hot deformation behavior of Ti-6Al-4V alloy: Effect of initial microstructure
ha9Xr6KG.abstract: Abstract   The purpose of this study was to identify plastic flow behavior and microstructural evolution during sub-transus hot deformation of a Ti-6Al-4V alloy with three initial microstructures (namely, transformed β microstructure, bimodal microstructure, and α′ martensitic microstructure) through compressive deformation at different strain rates in a Gleeble simulator and via SEM and TEM examinations. When deformed at a temperature of 800 °C and 850 °C (below the beta transus temperature of ∼975 °C), samples with a transformed β microstructure exhibited globularization of lamellar α phase at a strain rate of 10 −3  s −1 , while adiabatic shear banding occurred at a strain rate above 10 −3  s −1  due to the presence of initial coarse β grains. Equiaxed grain microstructures were present after hot deformation in the samples containing a bimodal starting microstructure mainly at lower strain rates, and in the samples with an α′ martensitic starting microstructure at all strain rates from 10 −3  s −1  to 1 s −1 . Especially, a homogenous ultra-fine grained structure with an average grain size of 400 nm was achieved at both deformation temperatures at a strain rate of 1 s −1  in the case of α′ martensitic starting microstructure. The new ultra-fine grains were formed mainly through the phase transformation of α′/α+β and the subsequent continuous dynamic recrystallization during hot deformation. This opens the door to the development of homogenous ultrafine-grained structure from a fully martensitic initial microstructure via hot deformation (e.g., hot rolling, extrusion, forging).

7fB2xBOd.title: Analysis of spray forming and processing factors of superalloy billets
7fB2xBOd.abstract: Spray forming is a rapid solidification technique suitable for preparing superalloy turbine disk billets. Superalloy billets prepared by this technique has fine and homogeneous microstructure without macrosegreation while the hot working ability and performance are improved. The processing characteristics and affecting factors are described.

9EAgvO3m.title: Preliminary Study on the Production Technology of Thin and Long High-density Particleboards of Pobulus Davidiana Wood
9EAgvO3m.abstract: In order to explore the production process of thin and long high-density particleboards,particles in special appearance were selected in experiment,which were thin and long.When other elements were fixed,the effects of three technological parameters,including hot pressing temperature,particleboard density and consumption of adhesive,on MOR,MOE,internal bonding strength and absorbent thickness swelling of the particleboard were studied,and the optimum parameters were obtained.After reasonable analysis on the data,it was concluded that,to certain extent,hot pressing temperature,particleboard density and the consumption of adhesive all had influence on physical and mechanical properties of the particleboard,in which hot pressing temperature and particleboard density had greater effects.The optimum technological parameters are: hot pressing temperature is 155℃,particleboard density is 0.88 g/cm3 and the consumption of adhesive is 12%.

3vn748ed.title: LncRNA DQ786243 affects Treg related CREB and Foxp3 expression in Crohn's disease.
3vn748ed.abstract: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) have different functions in cells. They work as signals, decoys, guides, and scaffolds. Altered lncRNA levels can affect the expression of gene products. There are seldom studies on the role of lncRNAs in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).Quantitative RT-PCR showed that DQ786243 was significantly overexpressed in clinical active CD patients compared with clinical inactive CD patients (P = 0.0118) or healthy controls (P = 0.002). CREB was also more highly expressed in active CD than in inactive CD (P = 0.0034) or controls (P = 0.0241). Foxp3 was interestingly lower in inactive CD than in active CD (P = 0.0317) or controls (P = 0.0103), but there were no apparent differences between active CD and controls. CRP was well correlated with DQ786243 (r = 0.489, P = 0.034), CREB (r = 0.500, P = 0.029) and Foxp3 (r = 0.546, P = 0.016). At 48 hours after DQ786243 transfection, qRT-PCR showed both CREB (P = 0.017) and Foxp3 (P = 0.046) had an increased mRNA expression in Jurkat cells. Western blot showed the same pattern. After DQ786243 transfection, CREB phosphorylation ratio (p-CREB/t-CREB) was increased (P = 0.0043).DQ786243 can be related with severity of CD. It can affect the expression of CREB and Foxp3 through which regulates the function of Treg. CREB itself seems not the mediator of DQ786243 to up-regulate Foxp3. The phosphorylation of CREB might play a more important role in the process.

VI0fiflj.title: Clinical significance of perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies in inflammatory bowel disease
VI0fiflj.abstract: Background: Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (pANCA) and anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are immunoglobulins closely related with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The role of pANCA and ASCA in the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn's disease (CD) remains further verification. Aims: To investigate the significance of pANCA and ASCA in the diagnosis and differential diagnosis of UC and CD. Methods: Serum samples were obtained from 64 patients with UC, 62 patients with CD and 56 healthy controls. Levels and positivity rates of pANCA and ASCA were determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). The sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV) and negative predictive value (NPV) of pANCA, ASCA and their combination were analyzed. Results: Serum pANCA level was significantly higher in UC group than that in CD group and healthy controls [(584.22±347.70) pg/ml vs. (304.99±211.10) pg/ml and (390.92±82.82) pg/ml, P<0.01], so was the positivity rate of pANCA (50.0% vs. 14.5% and 14.3%, P<0.01). The level and positivity rate of serum ASCA among these three groups had no significant difference. The sensitivity, specificity, PPV and NPV of pANCA+ and pANCA+/ASCA- in diagnosis of UC were 50.0%, 85.7%, 80.0%, 60.0% and 42.2%, 89.3%, 81.8%, 57.5%, respectively, and those of ASCA+ and ASCA+/pANCA- in diagnosis of CD were 8.1%, 87.5%, 41.7%, 46.2% and 3.2%, 91.1%, 28.6%, 45.9%, respectively. Conclusions: Positive pANCA favors the diagnosis of UC. Detection of pANCA together with ASCA is helpful for the differential diagnosis of UC, but is not of high value for the diagnosis of CD.

1fyD7MKf.title: A micro-scale printable nanoclip for electrical stimulation and recording in small nerves.
1fyD7MKf.abstract: Our nerve interface addresses key challenges in interfacing with small nerves in the peripheral nervous system. Its small size, ability to remain on the nerve over sub-chronic timescales, and ease of implantation, make it a promising tool for future use in the treatment of disease.

M52IueuG.title: A Pragmatic GIS-Oriented Ontology for Location Based Services
M52IueuG.abstract: With advances in automatic position sensing and wireless connectivity, location-based services (LBS) are rapidly developing, particularly in fields of geographic, tourism and logistic information systems. Currently, Web service has been viewed as one of most significant innovations in business industry, and designed on demand to provide spatial related information for LBS consumption. However, the traditional Web Service Description Language (WSDL) cannot meet those requirements, as WSDL is not able to support semantic content and information. In recent years, Ontology came up with an effective approach to enhance service description, automated discovery, dynamic composition, enactment, and other tasks such as managing and using service-based systems. In this paper, we propose geographic ontology based on Geography Markup Language (GML) and extend OWL-S profile to form geographic profile. Web service, which is advertised on the basis of our GeoProfile, contains geographic information inherently.

k6qvITaB.title: Effects of several halobios amylose extracts with Newcastle disease vaccine on the immunity
k6qvITaB.abstract: Objective: To investigate the effects of several halobios amylose powder and injection,including polysaccharide sulfate from alga [S.fusiforme(Harv.) Setch],glycosaminoglycan from Pinctada margaritifera and peptidoglycan from Sepia on the immune response to Newcastle disease(ND) vaccine in chickens.Methods: Amylose extracts injections were respectively mixed with ND vaccine to form three variant ND vaccine injection and stabilities of the mixtures were all tested.And amylose extracts powders were respectively mixed in the feed for chicken to eat.All groups were received intramuscularly inoculation administration.Respectively on the 7th,14th and 21st days after vaccine administration,sera samples of all chickens were collected to detect the antibody titers by hemagglutination inhibition(HI) assay method.Results: In the amylose powder feed groups,the ND HI titers belonged to the 14th day in the peptidoglycan and alga polysaccharide sulfate groups were obviously higher than those in the control group(P<0.05),and the value belonged to the 21st day in the alga polysaccharide sulfate group were still obviously higher than that in the control group(P<0.05).The ND HI titers belonged to the 14th and 21st days in the alga polysaccharide sulfate(50 mg/kg BW dosage)group were obviously higher than those in the control group(P<0.05).The ND HI titers belonged to the 7th,14th and 21st days in the alga polysaccharide sulfate(100 mg/kg BW dosage)group were obviously higher or markedly obviously higher than those in the control group(P<0.05,or P<0.01).Conclusions: These results showed that by the way of either injection or feed,the alga polysaccharide sulfate could improve chicken's immune response,and the effects generate quickly and could keep a long time.These suggest it should be a good immune enhancing adjuvant.

xFzsKey2.title: Towards massive data and sparse data in adaptive micro open educational resource recommendation: a study on semantic knowledge base construction and cold start problem
xFzsKey2.abstract: Micro Learning through open educational resources (OERs) is becoming increasingly popular. However, adaptive micro learning support remains inadequate by current OER platforms. To address this, our smart system, Micro Learning as a Service (MLaaS), aims to deliver personalized OER with micro learning to satisfy their real-time needs. In this paper, we focus on constructing a knowledge base to support the decision-making process of MLaaS. MLaas is built using a top-down approach. A conceptual graph-based ontology construction is first developed. An educational data mining and learning analytic strategy is then proposed for the data level. The learning resource adaptation still requires learners’ historical information. To compensate for the absence of this information initially (aka ‘cold start’), we set up a predictive ontology-based mechanism. As the first resource is delivered to the beginning of a learner’s learning journey, the micro OER recommendation is also optimized using a tailored heuristic.

R5rM8StM.title: A new adaptive Mamdani-type fuzzy modeling strategy for industrial gas turbines
R5rM8StM.abstract: The paper presents a new system identification methodology for industrial systems. Using the original Mamdani fuzzy rule based system (FRBS), an adaptive Mamdani fuzzy modeling (AMFM) is introduced in this paper. It differs from the original Mamdani FRBS in that it applies different membership functions and a denazification mechanism that is `differentiable' with respect to the membership function parameters. The proposed system also includes a back error propagation (BEP) algorithm that is used to refine the fuzzy model. The efficacy of the proposed AMFM approach is demonstrated through the experimental trails from a compressor in an industrial gas turbine system.

psL3pTqV.title: Effect of Hydrophobicity on the Vacuum-Contamination Resistance and Laser Damage Threshold of Sol-Gel Silica Coating
psL3pTqV.abstract: Silica antireflective coatings modified by hexamethyldisilazane(HMDS) were deposited on clean substrates by sol-gel process.The effects of HMDS on the contamination resistant capability and laser-induced damage threshold(LIDT) of coatings were investigated.With the modified sol the resultant coatings were hydrophobic and the contact angle for water increased with the increasing amount of HMDS in the reaction mixture.The antireflective properties were retained after HMDS-treatment and the transmission maximum values were above 99%.The introduction of HMDS into silica sols had also increased the LIDT of coatings from 24.3 J·cm-2 to 37 J·cm-2 when the molar ratio of HMDS to TEOS was 0.05∶1.After some of the hydroxyl groups on the surface of the SiO2 particle were replaced by methyl groups,from which the SiO2 particle gained a water-repellent surface,the stability of coatings in vacuum were increased.The peak transmittance of modified sample decreased only 0.25% after conserved in vacuum circumstance for 168 hours,in contrast to 2% reduction for the unmodified sample.At the same time,the LIDT of modified coating retained a high LIDT of 30.8 J·cm-2.

LYhupqAk.title: Mechanical performance and fracture behavior of Fe41Co7Cr15Mo14 Y2C15B6 bulk metallic glass
LYhupqAk.abstract: The mechanical properties of a new Fe41Co7 Cr15Mo14Y2C15 B6 bulk glassy alloy were studied by impact bending, compression, and hardness tests carried out at room temperature. The compressive fracture strength, elastic strain to fracture, Young's modulus and Vickers hardness were measured to be 3.5 GPa, 1.5%, 265 GPa, and 1253 kg mm-2, respectively. The fracture mode of the glassy alloy under uniaxial compression is different from those of other bulk metallic glasses in that this fracture mode causes the samples to be broken, in an exploding manner, into a large number of micrometer-scale pieces. The fracture mechanisms of this bulk glassy alloy under bending and uniaxial compression are discussed based on the observation of the fracture surfaces. Vickers indentation tests indicate that the structure of the glassy ingot may be inhomogencous. © 2007 Materials Research Society.

VlyB4N93.title: Acoustic Vibration Property of Full-Size Spruce Wood Soundboard of Musical Instruments
VlyB4N93.abstract: For former researches were focusing on the small-size wood samples,this paper studied on the acoustic vibration property of full-size spruce wood soundboard of musical instruments by natural frequency measurement system of fast Fourier transform(FFT).Species included Picea glehnii,P.jezoensis,P.likiangensis and P.sitchensis.They were divided into three separate groups respectively.In the first group,the length of sample was less than or equal to 1 400 mm(L≤1 400?mm).In the second,that was more than 1 400 mm(L>1 400 mm).The third one was single species.The vibration property of each sample group was evaluating by comprehensive coordinate method and comprehensive marking method.The classified quality of the species was ranked:P.likiangensis>P.jezoensis> P.glehnii> P.sitchensis.Moreover,it showed a significant correlation between the results of these two statistics methods.It indicated that the method could be suitable for evaluating vibration properties for musical instrument soundboard in real production.

IHnRlJIy.title: Investigation for Micro-shape Fabrication of Carbon Aerogel and Its Mechanical Property
IHnRlJIy.abstract: Organic RF aerogels shaped by capillary and sheet moulds were derived from resorcinol and formaldehyde's polymerization reaction which was catalyzed by sodium carbonate via sol-gel process.Micro-shape carbon aerogels were formed by pyrolyzing the RF aerogels dried at ambient conditions by solvent substitution.Typically,the carbon aerogels show a widely density range from 300 to 1 000 mg/cm3,extremely high surface areas up to 1 521 m2/g,and the variety of microstructure through adjusting the prior reaction conditions.The mechanical property of carbon aerogels was also investigated and it keeps definitely stable in cryogenic circumstance for inertial confinement fusion experiment's requirements.

d5jx9dDX.title: Fabrication of graded density SiO_2 aerogel via layer-by-layer gelation and its interface research
d5jx9dDX.abstract: Graded density silica aerogel was derived from a layer-by-layer gelation technic with tetraethoxysilane(TEOS)as the organic precursor and supercritical drying process,whose density ranges from 50-200mg/cm3.SEM,X-ray phase contrast method were used to characterize the graded density silica aerogel prepared,especially its layer interface structure.It can be found that the practical packing tightness was different between adjacent layer and there exist interdiffusion in the interface.Moreover,the gradient density aerogel was expected to be fabricated in this paper.

sjO6ZWbD.title: A novel approach to data deduplication over the engineering-oriented cloud systems
sjO6ZWbD.abstract: This paper presents a duplication-less storage system over the engineering-oriented cloud computing platforms. Our deduplication storage system, which manages data and duplication over the cloud system, consists of two major components, a front-end deduplication application and a mass storage system as back-end. Hadoop distributed file system HDFS is a common distribution file system on the cloud, which is used with Hadoop database HBase. We use HDFS to build up a mass storage system and employ HBase to build up a fast indexing system. With a deduplication application, a scalable and parallel deduplicated cloud storage system can be effectively built up. We further use VMware to generate a simulated cloud environment. The simulation results demonstrate that our deduplication storage system is sufficiently accurate and efficient for distributed and cooperative data intensive engineering applications.

MZ3zBXO1.title: Gasochromic Properties of Stable WO_3-SiO_2 Composite Films
MZ3zBXO1.abstract: Gasochromic films are prepared by sol-gel process and dip-coating technology with tungsten powder and TEOS.Particulate size description analyser(PSDA) is applied to characterize properties of the sols.Microstructure and gasochromic properties of the films are studied by UV-visible spectrophotometer and fourier transform infrared spectrometer(FTIR).The results show that SiO2 restrains the condensation of WO3 during cycles.Accordingly,there is little degradation after 500 cycles for WO3-SiO2 films,which is much more than 20 cycles for WO3 films.The stable network structure improved the cycling durability of gasochromic films.

OEVjVOuC.title: Microstructure Fabrication on Negative Tone SiO_2/ZrO_2 Gel Film
OEVjVOuC.abstract: The SiO2-ZrO2 gel films were formed on silica or K9 glass substrate from the sols that were derived from Zr-butoxide modified chemically with benzoylacetone and then mixed with tetraethyl orthosilicate via sol-gel process. The obtained gel film shows a characteristic absorption band, at around 334nm. The Si-O-Zr, Zr-O bands were detected by FTIR. The negative tone gel film was irradiated with high pressure mercury lamp through the mask and then leached in ethyl alcohol. The above process gave uniform surface-relief gratings of different patterns with different masks. The present study has proved that the photosensitive gel films are versatile in fabrication of micro optical devices.

u0joYNW4.title: Microscopic observation method for active faults in soft sediments.
u0joYNW4.abstract: Active faults in soft sediments usually do not have distinct macroscopic appearance, forming so-called obscured faults.Therefore, active faults in soft sediments cannot be identified thoroughly through macroscopic observations of trenches or natural outcrops across the faults.Obviously, it is necessary to develop a new method for the identification of active faults in soft sediments.An attempt to identify active faults in soft sediments through microscopic observations has been made in this study.For this purpose, a total of 24 trenches and natural outcrops across the Shunyi-Qianmen-Liangxiang Fault in Beijing, Jiaocheng Fault in Taiyuan, Wangjiagou and Xishan Faults in rümqi, and Lintong-Chang'an Fault in Xi'an have been observed.During the observations, 140 samples were collected by using sampling boxes to preserve their original state, from which 275 large thin sections were cut in the lab, and 122 samples of dispersed particles were also collected at the same position.Microstructural, micro-sedimentologic and SEM observations were carried out on all the samples collected.The results show that the obscured faults in soft sediments can be identified distinctly under microscope.Microscopically, they may appear as slip surfaces, deformation bands, zone of deformation bands, relatively wide micro-fault zones, micro-shutter zones, filled tension cracks, zones of concentrated clastic grain and zones of concentrated ferruginous materials or organics.The angularity, grain-size, grain-size distribution and surface textures of the clastic grains from the samples collected on the fault plane and outside are significantly different.Microstructural observations have revealed several microstructures comparable well with macroscopic structures indicative of seismites, such as balls-and-pillows structure, load structure, fluid flow, mass flow, truncation surface and floatation of organics.Obviously, the afore-mentioned microstructural and micro-sedimentologic features can be used as the microscopic indicators of obscured faults in soft sediments, as well as for the indicators of whether the faulting process is accompanied by seismic event.The results of this study, therefore, indicate that microscopic observation is an effective approach to the identification of active faults in soft sediments.

mDiAC4co.title: Transplanted neural stem cells promote nerve regeneration in acute peripheral nerve traction injury: assessment using MRI.
mDiAC4co.abstract: The purpose of our study was to monitor neural stem cells (NSCs) transplanted in acute peripheral nerve traction injury and to use MRI to assess the ability of NSCs to promote nerve regeneration.After labeling with gadolinium-diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid (gadopentetate dimeglumine) and fluorescent dye (PKH26), 5 × 10(5) NSCs were grafted to acutely distracted sciatic nerves in 21 New Zealand White rabbits. In addition, 5 × 10(5) unlabeled NSCs (n = 21) and vehicle alone (n = 21) subjects were injected as a control. Serial MRI was performed with a 1.5-T scanner to determine the distribution of grafted cells. Sequential T1 and T2 values of the nerves and functional recovery were measured over a 70-day follow-up period, with histologic assessments performed at regular intervals.The distribution and migration of labeled NSCs could be tracked with MRI until 10 days after transplantation. Compared with vehicle control, nerves grafted with labeled or unlabeled NSCs had better functional recovery and showed improved nerve regeneration but exhibited a sustained increase of T1 and T2 values during the phase of regeneration.Gadopentetate dimeglumine-based labeling allowed short-term in vivo MRI tracking of NSCs grafted in injured nerves. NSCs transplantation could promote nerve regeneration in acute peripheral nerve traction injury as shown by a prolonged increase of nerve T1 and T2 values.

1Zn4usTt.title: Maximum field emission current density of CuO nanowires: theoretical study using a defect-related semiconductor field emission model and in situ measurements.
1Zn4usTt.abstract: In this study, we proposed a theoretical model for one-dimensional semiconductor nanowires (NWs), taking account of the defect-related electrical transport process. The maximum emission current density was calculated by considering the influence of Joule heating, using a one-dimensional heat equation. The field emission properties of individual CuO NWs with different electrical properties were studied using an in situ experimental technique. The experimental results for maximum emission current density agreed well with the theoretical predictions and suggested that multiple conduction mechanisms were active. These may be induced by the concentration of defects in the CuO NW. The concentration of defects and the transport mechanisms were found to be key factors influencing the maximum field emission current density of the semiconductor NW. As is limited by the change of resistivity with temperature, only thermal runaway can trigger breakdown in CuO NWs.
