a3OrBln1.title: PEM fuel cell reaction kinetics in the temperature range of 23–120°C
a3OrBln1.abstract: The performance of a Nafion 112 based proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell was tested at a temperature range from 23 °C to 120 °C. The fuel cell polarization curves were divided into two different ranges based on current density, namely, <0.4 A/cm 2 and >0.4 A/cm 2 , respectively. These two ranges were treated separately with respect to electrode kinetics and mass transfer. In the high current density range, a linear increase in membrane electrode assembly (MEA) power density with increasing temperature was observed, indicating the advantages of high temperature operation. Simulation based on electrode reaction kinetic theory, experimental polarization curves, and measured cathodic apparent exchange current densities all gave temperature dependent apparent exchange current densities. Both the calculated partial pressures of O 2 and H 2 gas in the feed streams and the measured electrochemical Pt surface areas (EPSAs) decrease with increasing temperature. They were also used to obtain the intrinsic exchange current densities. A monotonic increase of the intrinsic exchange current densities with increasing temperature in the range of 23–120 °C was observed, suggesting that increasing the temperature does promote intrinsic kinetics of fuel cell reactions. There are two sets of cathode apparent exchange current densities obtained, one set is for the low current density range, and the other is for the high current density range. The different values of cathode current densities in the two current density ranges can be attributed to the different states of the cathode Pt catalyst surface. In the low current density range, the cathode catalyst surface is a Pt/PtO, and in the high current density range, the catalyst surface becomes pure Pt. Keywords Temperature effect High temperature PEM fuel cells O 2 reduction H 2 oxidation Cathode and anode electrode kinetics Exchange current density Electrochemical Pt surface area (EPSA) Reaction activation energy 1 Introduction In the effort for fuel cell commercialization, during recent years, R&D of the proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) has been concentrated on fuel cell performance improvements such as increasing power density, reducing cost, and increasing reliability/durability [1] . The improvement of fuel cell performance will impact all aspects including stack volume power density (W/L), stack weight power densities (W/kg and Wh/kg), and stack power cost ($/kW). High temperature operation (>80 °C) of a PEMFC has been considered as an effective way to improve the performance in terms of reaction kinetics, catalyst tolerance, heat rejection and water management [2–10] . In the effort to improve performance, the cathodic O 2 reduction reaction (abbreviated as ORR) and/or anode (H 2 oxidation reaction, abbreviated as HOR) kinetics have been considered as one of the determining processes that limits performance, especially in the low current density range (low power applications). It has been expected that ORR and HOR kinetics could improve when the fuel cell is operated at higher temperatures [11,12] . The electrode kinetics of oxygen reduction in simulated fuel cell environments and in PEMFCs has been widely studied in the literature in the low temperature range (<80 °C) [13–19] . For high temperature PEMFC, several papers published in recent years have given some attention to the electrode kinetic approach [11,20–22] . Xu et al. [11] studied the kinetics of the ORR at high temperature. Kinetic parameters such as catalytic activity were investigated using current densities at an overpotential of 0.3 V, which corresponds to a Pt/PtO surface. However, it is very difficult to get consistent values for some kinetic parameters, especially the exchange current density values through the literature. It is believed that apparent exchange current density (AECD) is one of the most important parameters in describing kinetics because it not only contains the intrinsic catalytic activity of the Pt catalyst, but also includes the catalyst layer morphology such as electrochemical Pt surface area (EPSA). Although one cannot do much to increase the intrinsic catalyst activity, the improvement in EPSA through optimizing catalyst supporting strategies, catalyst layer structures, and composition can significantly increase the fuel cell performance. Another important parameter is the Tafel slope of the fuel cell polarization curve (steady-state cell voltage versus current density). This parameter is directly related to kinetic parameters such as the electron transfer coefficient and the number of electrons involved in the rate-determining step. In order to gain a more fundamental understanding about fuel cell reaction kinetics at higher temperatures, fuel cell performance in the temperature range of 23–120 °C is reported in this paper with a focus on the temperature dependence of fuel cell kinetics. Nafion 112 based membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) were used as the baselines to obtain performance at different temperatures. 2 Experimental Nafion 112 (DuPont), used as the proton electrolyte membranes, were treated in 3% H 2 O 2 (aq), 1 M HNO 3 (aq), 1 M H 2 SO 4 (aq), rinsed and then soaked in deionized water for 1 h at 60–80 °C separately, followed by a careful washing step with double distilled water. MEAs, with an active area of 4.4 cm 2 , were prepared by hot pressing the anode, Nafion 112 membrane, and cathode together. Anodes and cathodes consist of Pt/Ru (20% PtRu/C, E-tek) and Pt (20% Pt/C, E-tek), respectively, with a total Pt loading of 1.0 mg/cm 2 . The MEAs were tested in an in-house single cell fed with fully humidified H 2 and air at a fixed flow rate of 0.1 L/min, and 1 L/min, respectively. A blade pressure of 6.7 atm was used to hold the single cell together and provide sufficient electrical contact between the MEA and the graphite bipolar plates. Polarization data at different temperatures and two pressures (0 atm and 3.0 atm) was collected using a Fideris fuel cell test station controlled by FC Power software. Cyclic voltammograms for the EPSA of the cathode catalyst layer were recorded while the fuel cell was simultaneously flushed with N 2 (99.99%) through the cathode compartment and H 2 through the anode compartment. In this case, the anode served as both reference and counter electrodes, and the cathode as a working electrode. For the anode catalyst layer EPSA measurements, the anode side was simultaneously flushed with N 2 and the cathode side with H 2 , where the cathode served as both the reference electrode and the counter electrode. The charges under those two hydrogen surface waves on the volammogram near 150 mV and 230 mV (versus SHE), respectively, were used to estimate the EPSA by adopting a well-recognized value of 210 μC/cm 2 for hydrogen electrochemical adsorption/desorption on a smooth Pt surface. A Solartron 1260 FRA and 1287 potentiostat were used for AC impedance measurements at the cell's open circuit voltage (OCV) conditions with a perturbing amplitude of 5 mV in the frequency range of 7000–0.1 Hz. The purpose of AC impedance experiments at OCV is to obtain the apparent exchange current densities of individual anodic H 2 oxidation and cathodic O 2 reduction reactions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Polarization curves at different temperatures A Nafion 112 based MEA was used as the baseline to achieve the performance goal in this paper, which is 0.65 V @ 1.0 A/cm 2 at 80 °C, 3.0 atm absolute, and 100% relative humidity (RH) in order to optimize the hardware designs including single cell and test facilities. Fig. 1 shows the polarization curves of a H 2 /air fuel cell operated at 3.0 atm, 100% RH and at different temperatures. At 80 °C, a performance of 0.68 V @ 1.0 A/cm 2 was achieved, which is comparatively higher than those reported at similar operation conditions [20] . These results shown in Fig. 1 are indicative of the state-of-the-art PEMFC performance. The performance at ambient pressure was also obtained (not included in this paper). A performance drop of around 30–60 mV over the whole current density range was observed when the backpressure was controlled to ambient pressure. For all temperatures, the performance has the same trend, that is, the higher the backpressure, the higher the performance. This observation is consistent with that reported by Mallant [23] . It is believed this improvement at higher backpressures is mainly due to the increase in H 2 pressure and O 2 partial pressure in the feed streams as well as an improvement in electrode kinetics. At high pressure, the thermodynamic electrode potential of O 2 will shift to more positive values and that of H 2 will shift to more negative potentials, resulting in a higher cell voltage, which contributes an improvement in cell performance throughout the whole current density range studied. Additionally, as predicted by electrode kinetics theory, an increase in H 2 and O 2 partial pressures leads to higher current densities at the same voltage. It was also observed that the gaps between polarization curves for two backpressures slightly increased with an increase in current density. For example at 80 °C, and 0.1 A/cm 2 , the voltage difference between backpressures (absolute) of 3.0 atm and 1.0 atm was 40 mV, while at 1.0 A/cm 2 with the same backpressures, the voltage difference becomes 60 mV. In the low current density range, as shown in Fig. 1 , among the polarization curves obtained at 23 °C, 40 °C, 60 °C, 80 °C, 100 °C, and 120 °C, the best performance is at ∼80 °C. The performance increases as temperature increases from 23 °C up to 80 °C, after which a further increase to 120 °C leads to a decrease in performance. The performance drop behaviour at high temperatures, ca. 120 °C compared to that at 80 °C has been reported by Song et al. [20] . This performance drop could be attributed to several different effects such as a decrease in catalyst active surface, drying of both the membrane and catalyst layer ionomer, H 2 crossover, a decrease in O 2 and H 2 partial pressures, and a decrease in catalyst layer EPSAs. In the high current density range, all performances dropped rapidly, as shown in Fig. 1 , which is typical of mass transfer limitation. However, an increase in temperature makes a huge difference in this high current density range, due to improvements in mass transfer at higher temperatures. Fig. 2 shows MEA peak power density as a function of temperature. A linear increase in peak power density with increasing temperature can be observed, indicating the benefit of operation at high temperatures. 3.2 Kinetic parameters based on electrode kinetic and mass transfer theories For a H 2 /air (O 2 ) fuel cell, the catalyzed cathode reaction within the catalyst layer is: (I) O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − ↔ 2 H 2 O and the corresponding anode reaction is: (II) H 2 ↔ 2 H + + 2 e − For the reaction occurring inside porous three-dimensional catalyst layer, a thin-film-flooded agglomerate model has been developed [24,25] to describe the potential–current behaviour as a function of reaction kinetics and reactant diffusion. For simplicity, if the kinetic parameters, such as exchange current density and diffusion limiting current density can be defined as apparent parameters, the corresponding Butler–Volmer and mass diffusion relationships can be expressed as Eqs. (1) and (2) , respectively [26] : (1) I c = i O 2 o 1 − I c I d c f e n α O α O F η c / R T − 1 − I c I d c b e − ( n α O ( 1 − α O ) F η c / R T )   ( Cathode   reaction   ( I ) ) (2) I a = i H 2 o 1 − I a I d a f e n α H α H F η a / R T − 1 − I a I d a b e − ( n α H ( 1 − α H ) F η a / R T )   ( Anode   reaction   ( II ) ) In Eqs. (1) and (2) , R is the gas constant (8.314 J/mol/K), T the temperature (K), I c and I a the cathode and anode current densities, respectively, while i O 2 o   and   i H 2 o are the apparent exchange current densities for cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation reactions, respectively. I d c f   and   I d c b are the apparent diffusion limiting current densities for the cathodic forward and backward reactions, respectively, and I d a f   and   I d a b are the corresponding apparent diffusion limiting current densities for anode reactions. It is assumed that these six apparent current densities are all a function of the morphology and structure of the three-dimensional catalyst layer matrix [27] . η c and η a in Eqs. (1) and (2) are the cathodic and anodic overpotentials, respectively. η c can be expressed as E c r − E c , and η a can be expressed as E a − E a r , where E c r   and   E a r are the thermodynamic electrode potentials (or reversible electrode potentials) for cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation, respectively. However, E c r can be depressed by a surface Pt–O 2 reaction and a H 2 crossover oxidation, which will be discussed in more detail later in this paper. n α O and n α H in Eqs. (1) and (2) are the electron transfer numbers in the rate-determining steps for the cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation reactions, respectively. For hydrogen oxidation on Pt/C catalysts, the value of n α H is 2.0, which is widely reported in literature [28–30] . For the value of n α O , two situations should be considered. In the literature, the oxygen reduction polarization curve has two Tafel slopes [12,14,15,17,31–35] . In the low current density range (higher cathode potential range where the electrode surface is partially covered by PtO), the slope is ∼60 mV/decade at 25 °C, which is corresponding to a n α O value of 2.0. The second Tafel slope in the high current density range is around 120 mV/decade at 25 °C with a n α O value of 1.0. Parthasarathy et al. [14] explained that the rate-determining step for O 2 reduction is different at different current densities. At low current densities, a chemical step following the initial fast charge transfer is the rate-determining step, under Langmuir conditions. At higher current densities, the first electron transfer step might be the rate-determining step, leading to a Tafel slope of 120 mV/decade. Perry et al. [36] proposed that the double Tafel slopes are due to the control of O 2 reduction in fuel cells by both the ORR and O 2 mass transport. This postulation was based on the porous electrode model. However, on a pure Pt electrode surface, double Tafel slopes were observed using either Nafion membrane as the electrolyte [14] or an aqueous acid as the electrolyte [32,33,37] . Therefore, the double Tafel slopes are likely due to the difference in reaction mechanisms between that on a pure Pt surface and that on a Pt/PtO surface (see below). α O and α H in Eqs. (1) and (2) are the electron transfer coefficients for cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation, respectively. On a Pt electrode, α O is a temperature dependent parameter in the temperature range of 20–250 °C as reported in the literature [12,38–41] , and can be expressed as: α O = α O 0 T , where α O 0 equals 0.001678 at 25 °C. However, α H for H 2 oxidation on a Pt electrode seems to be independent of temperature and the well-recognized value of 0.5 is widely reported in the literature [29,42–44] . For the cathode, the Pt catalyst surface state is strongly dependent on electrode potential. A surface cyclic voltammogram of the cathode (not shown) showed that when the cathode potential is >∼0.8 V (versus NHE) (low fuel cell current density range), the Pt catalyst surface will be covered partially by a PtO layer with surface coverage of ∼0.3 [45] . Only when the cathode potential is lower than 0.8 V (high current density range), can the catalyst surface be entirely pure Pt. It has been demonstrated that the kinetics of O 2 electroreduction on a pure Pt surface is different from that on PtO surface [33] . In this paper, the two current density ranges will be treated separately to reflect this difference between Pt and Pt/PtO catalyst surfaces. The reaction in the low current density range, where the catalyst surface is partially covered by PtO, will be a pure electron transfer controlled process. Therefore, reactant mass transfer processes will not be considered. In the high current density range where the catalyst surface is a pure Pt surface, the reaction could be controlled by both electron transfer and mass transfer processes. Thus the two processes have to be considered simultaneously. For the anode side, the electrode potential is not positive enough to yield an PtO surface. Thus, the H 2 oxidation reaction could only occur on a pure Pt surface throughout the whole current density range studied. In a similar fashion for the cathodic reaction, in the low current density range, only the electron transfer process of anodic H 2 oxidation is considered. In the high current density range, both electron transfer and mass transfer processes will be accounted for simultaneously. 3.3 Fuel cell voltage The measured fuel cell voltage ( V cell ) can be expressed as Eq. (3) : (3) V cell = E OCV − η c − η a − I cell R m where E OCV ( = E c r − E a r ) is the fuel cell open circuit voltage, I cell the fuel cell current density, R m the MEA resistance dominated by the membrane resistance, and η c and η a are the overpotentials as defined in Eqs. (1) and (2) , respectively. According to Eqs. (1) and (2) , it is impossible to derive the analytical expressions for η c and η a as a function of fuel cell current density. In order to obtain E OCV , i O 2 o , i H 2 o , I d c f ,   and   I d a f by simulating the performances in Fig. 1 according to Eq. (3) , η c , η a , R m , α O , α H , n O , and n H must be known. Fortunately, the membrane resistance, R m , can be experimentally measured, and parameters α O , α H , n O , and n H can be obtained by adopting well-recognized values from literature. As described later in this paper, other parameters such as E OCV , i O 2 o , i H 2 o , I d c f , I d a f , η c ,   and   η a can be simulated separately in low and high current density ranges. 3.4 Low current density range In the low current density range, the contribution from mass transfer polarization can be negligible, and the electrode charge transfer and membrane resistance polarization are significant. In this case, Eqs. (1) and (2) can be simplified into Eqs. (4) and (5) , respectively: (4) I c = i O 2 o ( e ( n α O α O F η c / R T ) − e − ( n α O ( 1 − α O ) F η c ) / ( R T ) ) (5) I a = i H 2 o ( e n α H α H F η a / R T − e − ( n α H ( 1 − α H ) F η a ) / ( R T ) ) From the AC impedance spectra, the exchange current density of the ORR can be calculated from the charge transfer resistance (see below). The numerical relationship between η c and I c can thus be obtained. Then by inputting η c into Eq. (3) , η a and E OCV can be simulated. In the simulation, the linear relationship between η a and I cell in the low current density range (<0.4 A/cm 2 ) was adjusted to pass through the zero point on the η a − I cell graph by adjusting the E OCV value. 3.5 Measurement of the cathode apparent exchange current densities [47] As described in the experimental section, AC impedance spectra were measured at OCV conditions. Fig. 3 shows a Nyquist plot at 80 °C, 3 atm absolute backpressure and 100% RH. At the high frequency end, the curve intersect at the X -axis is the membrane resistance ( R m ). The measured R m values for the Nafion 112 membrane at different temperatures are listed in Table 1 , which were more or less constant with exception of a slight increase with increasing temperature. The diameter of the semicircle ( R c t OCV ) is the charge transfer resistance at OCV. Proposed equivalent circuit for the H 2 oxidation and O 2 reduction reactions is shown as inserts in Fig. 3 . The resistances, R c and R a , are the charge transfer resistances of cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation, respectively, and their corresponding double layer capacitances can be expressed as C c and C a . The measured R c t OCV is the sum of both sides (anode and cathode), that is, R c t OCV = R c + R a . As R c ≫ R a , R c t OCV ≅ R c . At OCV conditions, if the perturbing voltage amplitude is very small (<5 mV in this paper) so that the overpotential, η c or η a is much smaller than RT / n α O α O F or RT / n α H α H F , Eqs. (4) or (5) can be approximated as Eqs. (6) and (7) , respectively: (6) η c = R T n α O F i O 2 o I c (7) η a = R T n α H F i H 2 o I a As a result, i H 2 − P t o ≫ i O 2 − Pt / PtO o [46] , and the resulting polarization, η c + η a , via current perturbation, should be dominated by η c , that is, η c + η a ≈ η c . For AC impedance measurements, using a very small perturbing AC current at OCV, the obtained R c t OCV can be expressed as Eq. (8) by differentiating Eq. (6) : (8) R c t OCV = ∂ η c ∂ I c = R T n α o F i O 2 o Based on Eq. (8) , the apparent exchange current density of O 2 reduction can be calculated if R c t OCV and n α O (=2.0) are known. The obtained AECD for O 2 reduction reactions at different temperatures are listed in Table 1 . The E OCV and i H 2 o values simulated according to Eqs. (2) and (3) are listed in Table 1 . The calculated polarization curves based on the parameters listed in Table 1 are shown in Fig. 4 (a–c) for current densities <0.4 A/cm 2 . Fig. 4 (d) shows the comparison between simulated fuel cell performance and those measured at different temperatures for current densities < 0.4 A/cm 2 . The simulated data are fairly consistent with the measured ones for each curve, confirming the parameters listed in Table 1 are reliable. It may be worthwhile to point out that the anode overpotential ( Fig. 4 (c)) may not be insignificant when compared to those of cathode and membrane polarizations, especially for the low temperature cases, where the anode overpotentials are large enough to make a significant contribution to the overall polarization. In fuel cell performance simulation and modeling literature, anode polarization was neglected by assuming that its overpotential is significantly smaller than that of cathodic side. The contribution of anode overpotential (AO%) to the overall polarization can be defined as shown in Eq. (9) : (9) AO % = η a η a + η c + η m where η m is the contribution portion of membrane resistance ( I c R m ). For example, at 80 °C, at 0.4 A/cm 2 , the anode overpotential is 10 mV, the cathode overpotential is 174 mV, and the membrane voltage drop is 41 mV. The percentage of the anode overpotential in the total polarization based on Eq. (9) is about 4.4%. However, at room temperature, the percentage is about 10%, which should not be neglected when simulating experimental fuel cell performance. If the anode overpotential is negligible, that is η a = 0, and fuel cell current density ( I cell ) is much larger than i O 2 o in Eq. (4) , Eq. (3) can be simplified as: (10) V cell = E OCV + R T 0.001678 T n α o F   ln ( i O 2 o ) − R T 0.001678 T n α o F   ln ( I cell ) − I cell R m Eq. (10) is the most popular expression for fuel cell polarization in the literature [18,19] . The constant RT /0.001678 Tn α O F in Eq. (10) is normally defined as the Tafel slope. Strictly speaking, this equation is not the best way for describing a continuous polarization curve because I cell is not allowed to be close to or equal to zero. As a matter of fact, it is in this low current density range that accurate electrode kinetic parameters can be simulated. This equation is also not applicable to the situation when the anode overpotential is no longer negligible. Another confusing point in the literature is treating the term of E OCV + ( R T / 0.001678 T n α o F )   ln ( i O 2 o ) in Eq. (10) as the OCV. In Table 1 , the simulated E OCV s are all lower than those theoretically calculated. This is due to two factors: mixed potential of the cathode for a Pt/PtO surface, and hydrogen crossover from anode to cathode. This issue is discussed in more detail in another paper [47] . As shown in Fig. 1 , the fuel cell performance in low current density increases with increasing temperature from 23 °C to 80 °C, then decreases when the temperature further increased from 80 °C to 120 °C. This behaviour has a similar pattern to the apparent exchange current densities listed in Table 1 . For comparison, Fig. 5 shows apparent exchange current density curves and cell performance as a function of temperature. It is obvious that the performance drop with increasing temperature in the range of 80–120 °C is due to the decrease in AECD value with increasing temperature. There may be two major factors contributing to the decrease of AECDs with increasing temperature from 80 °C to 120 °C. The first is the rapid drop in O 2 and H 2 partial pressures as calculated according to fuel cell feed conditions [47] , and the other is the reduction of the electrochemical Pt surface area of the catalyst layers. The AECDs of cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation may be expressed as Eqs. (11) and (12) , respectively: (11) i O 2 o = ( EPSA ) c i O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) o P O 2 P O 2 o 0.001678 T (12) i H 2 o = ( EPSA ) a i H 2 ( Pt ) o P H 2 P H 2 o 0.5 where (EPSA) c and (EPSA) a are the electrochemical Pt surface areas of cathode and anode catalyst layers, respectively, with a unit of cm 2 Pt surface per cm 2 electrode geometric area (cm 2 /cm 2 ); i O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) o   and   i H 2 ( Pt ) o are the intrinsic exchange current densities (IECDs) of O 2 reduction on a Pt/PtO surface and H 2 oxidation on a Pt surface; P O 2   and   P H 2 are the partial pressures of O 2 and H 2 in the feed streams; and P O 2 o   and   P H 2 o are the standard pressures of O 2 and H 2 . As described in Section 2 , (EPSA) c and (EPSA) a can be obtained by surface cyclic voltammetry measurements. The obtained values are listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that both (EPSA) c and (EPSA) a drop significantly with increasing temperature, suggesting that the number of active Pt catalyst site for fuel cell reactions are reduced dramatically, resulting in a decrease in the AECD. This phenomenon has been previously reported by Song et al. [20] . Currently it is not very clear why an increase in temperature leads to a decrease in EPSA. One possibility is that the water content inside the catalyst layer is reduced with increasing temperature. It is believed that the active sites on a Pt catalyst are those covered by a thin water and Nafion (if any) film, and that the areas which are not covered by such water and Nafion films should not be involved in the reaction. With water content decreasing with increasing temperature, the area covered by the thin layer of water could be reduced, resulting in a reduction of the EPSA. As listed in Table 1 , the IECDs for both O 2 reduction and H 2 oxidation were calculated based on Eqs. (11) and (12) according to the partial pressure and EPSA data listed in Table 2 . Both IECDs for the anode and cathode increase monotonically with increasing temperature, indicating that temperature does promote fuel cell intrinsic reaction kinetics. The observed drop in fuel cell performance for temperatures greater than 80 °C is mainly caused by partial pressure drop of feed gas and reduction in the EPSA. 3.6 High current density range In the high current density range, the diffusion related terms in Eqs. (1) and (2) must be considered. As a result, at the high overpotentials (both η c and η a are large), the second terms in the brackets of Eqs. (1) and (2) will be insignificant compared to the first terms, suggesting that they could be negligible. Therefore, Eqs. (1) and (2) can be simplified as Eqs. (13) and (14) , respectively: (13) I c = i O 2 o 1 − I c I d c f e n α O α O F η c / R T (14) I a = i H 2 o 1 − I a I d a f e n α H α H F η a / R T Eq. (3) then can be expressed as Eq. (15) : (15) V cell = E OCV + R T 0.001678 T n α O F   ln ( i O 2 o ) + R T 0.5 n α H F   ln ( i H 2 o ) − R T 0.001678 T n α O F   ln I cell I d c f I d c f − I cell − R T 0.5 n α H F   ln I cell I d a f I d a f − I cell − I cell R m where i O 2 o is the apparent exchange current density for cathodic O 2 reduction on the Pt surface which should be a different value from that listed in Table 1 because the O 2 reduction occurs on a pure Pt surface rather than on a Pt/PtO surface. The electron number ( n α O ) in Eq. (15) should accordingly be taken as 1.0 rather than 2.0. It is believed that i H 2 o in Eq. (15) should have the same value as listed in Table 1 because in both low and high current density ranges only the pure Pt surface is involved. There are three parameters which need to be simulated: i O 2 o , I d c f ,   and   I d a f . Some uncertainties exist if too many parameters are simultaneously involved in the simulation. Fortunately, as an estimation, the relationship between I d c f   and   I d a f could be calculated if the thicknesses of the cathode and anode catalyst layers (defined as L c and L a , respectively), the concentrations of O 2 and H 2 (defined as C O 2   and   C H 2 , respectively), and the diffusion coefficients of O 2 and H 2 (defined as D O 2   and   D H 2 , respectively) are roughly known. According to diffusion theory [26] , the relationship between I d c f   and   I d a f can be roughly expressed as Eq. (16) : (16) I d a f = 0.5 D H 2 D O 2 C H 2 C O 2 L c L a I d c f where L c and L a are about 20 μm and 15 μm, respectively, for the MEA used in this study. As reported in the literature [48,49] , while C H 2 is temperature independent, D O 2 , D H 2 , C O 2 , C H 2 are all temperature dependent, and can be expressed as: (17) D O 2 = 3.1 × 10 − 3   exp − 2768 T (18) D H 2 = 4.1 × 10 − 4   exp − 2602 T (19) C O 2 = P O 2 K O 2 = P O 2 e ( − ( 666 / T ) + 14.1 ) (20) C H 2 = P H 2 K H 2 = P O 2 4.5 × 10 4 In Eqs. (17)–(20) , T is the temperature in Kelvin, and K O 2 as well as K H 2 are Henry's constants in atm cm 3 /mol. Values of i O 2 o , I d c f ,   and   I d a f listed in Table 3 were obtained from a simulation based on Eqs. (15) and (16) in the high current density range. In the simulation, the theoretical values of E OCV listed in Table 3 were used. It is believed that in the high current density range, the Pt/PtO surface does not exist, and H 2 crossover is negligible due to the depletion in surface concentration on the anode surface. Therefore, the fuel cell OCV should be the same as the theoretical one. The intrinsic exchange current densities were also calculated in a similar way to Eq. (11) based on the partial pressures of O 2 in the feed stream, and on the cathode catalyst EPSA. Fig. 6 compares the polarization curves simulated according to Eqs. (15) and (16) with those measured at different temperatures. It can be seen that the simulated curves are fairly fitted with those measured data points, suggesting that Eq. (15) is valid for the performance simulation. All three parameters ( i O 2 o , I d c f ,   and   I d a f ) show a monotonic increase with increasing temperature. The values of i O 2 o in the high current density range are different from those in the low current density range, probably a reflection of the difference in catalytic activity between Pt/PtO and Pt surfaces. 3.7 Reaction activation energies The relationship between activation energy and the IECD should follow the Arrehnius theory: (21) i O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) o = I O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) o e − ( E O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) ) / ( R T )   ( Low   current   density   range ) (22) i O 2 ( Pt ) o = I O 2 ( Pt ) o e − ( E O 2 ( Pt ) ) / ( R T )   ( High   current   density   range ) (23) i H 2 ( Pt ) o = I H 2 ( Pt ) o e − ( E H 2 / R T )   ( Whole   current   density   range ) where I O 2 ( Pt / PtO ) o   and   I O 2 ( Pt ) o   and   I H 2 ( Pt ) o are the intrinsic exchange current densities of cathode O 2 reduction in the low and high current density ranges, respectively. I H 2 ( Pt ) o is the anode H 2 oxidation. E O 2 (or E O 2 ( Pt ) ) and E H 2 are the activation energies for cathode and anode reactions, respectively. Fig. 7 shows the logarithm of IECDs as a function of the reciprocal of temperature. From the slopes of the three plots, activation energies can be obtained. An activation energy of 34.6 kJ/mol for anode H 2 oxidation was obtained. This value is close to the reported value of 35 kJ/mol on Pt supported on WO 3 –ZrO 2 [50] . However, it is much larger than that for bulk or single crystal Pt surfaces (10–18 kJ/mol) [30,51] . The activation energy of hydrogen oxidation on a Pt electrode is structure sensitive [51,52] . The deviation may be due to the structural difference between bulk Pt electrodes and supported PtRu nanoparticles. In this work, anode catalyst is PtRu/C. It is known that H 2 oxidation occurs more easily on Pt/C than does on PtRu/C [53] . Activation energy values of 28.3 kJ/mol and 57.3 kJ/mol were obtained for cathodic O 2 reduction in the low current density range (on Pt/PtO surface), and in the high current density range (on pure Pt surface), respectively. In the literature, values of 21–25 kJ/mol on Pt and Pt alloy surfaces [52] , 73.2 kJ/mol [12] , up to 82.5 kJ/mol in PEM fuel cells with sputtered Pt as the catalyst [13] on oxide covered Pt surfaces have been reported. At low current density, the value is within the range, and close to that reported in the literature [52] . However, in the literature, it was also reported that the activation energy of ORR on a PtO surface is about 16 kJ/mol higher than that on a pure Pt surface [12,54] , which is based on the assumption that the first charge transfer step is the rate-determining step at both current densities. We found that the activation energy on a pure Pt surface reported here is higher than that on a PtO surface, indicating that the rate-determining step in the two current density ranges is different as well. The difference in catalyst structure between the Pt nanoparticles supported on carbon and Pt bulk electrodes probably plays a very important role. For example, it has been reported that in PEM fuel cells, a sputtered Pt electrode showed an activation energy of 63 kJ/mol for the ORR, while the unsputtered electrode gave a value of 82.5 kJ/mol [18] . 4 Conclusion Temperature dependent performances of Nafion 112 based MEAs were obtained in order to simulate the kinetic parameters for PEM fuel cells in the temperature range of 23–120 °C. An increase in temperature leads to an increase in fuel cell performance from room temperature up to 80 °C, after which, a further increase in temperature results in a change in the current density dependent performance. That is, at low current density, an increase in temperature leads to a decrease in performance, and at high current densities, the temperature increase leads to an increase in performance. The best performance was observed at around 80 °C, with 3.0 atm absolute backpressure and 100% RH. A higher backpressure always gives better performance. The simulation based on electrode reaction kinetic theory, experimental polarization curves, and measured cathodic apparent exchange current densities in the kinetically-dominated current density range (<0.4 A/cm 2 ) gave the temperature dependent apparent exchange current densities of anodic H 2 oxidation. The partial pressure of O 2 and H 2 gas in the fuel cell feed streams were calculated and the electrochemical Pt surface areas of the cathode and anode catalyst layers at different temperatures were measured. The obtained partial pressures and EPSAs were then used to calculate the intrinsic exchange current densities, which show a monotonic increase with increasing temperature in the range of 23–120 °C. This monotonic increase with temperature suggests that increasing temperature does promote intrinsic fuel cell reaction kinetics. At low current densities, a drop in fuel cell performance at temperatures greater than 80 °C is mainly caused by a drop in feed gas partial pressure and by a reduction in EPSA. The decrease in EPSA with increasing temperature could be attributed to the reduction of water content inside the catalyst layers at higher temperatures. The reaction activation energies for cathodic O 2 reduction and anodic H 2 oxidation were obtained, respectively, from the temperature dependence of intrinsic exchange current densities according to Arrehnius theory. SMvnV0ws.title: Effect of annealing temperature on structure and gaschromic properties of WO3 thin films
SMvnV0ws.abstract: WO3 sol (600 mL) was prepared with tungsten powder and 37% H2O2 through the sol-gel method in this paper. WO3 thin films were prepared on silicon chips and ordinary slide glasses via Dip Master method and annealed in ambient air at temperatures of 50, 150, 250, 350 and 450°C, respectively. Thickness and refractive index of the WO3 thin films were researched by Spectroscopic EUipsometer. Surface morphology and microstructure of the films were analyzed with AFM, IR and XRD respectively. The annealing temperature have an important effect on the structure and gaschromic properties of WO3 thin films. At low annealing temperature, WO3 thin films is amorphous and porous structure, and the water of WO3 thin films is appropriate, then this kind of WO3 thin films have a good gaschromic properties.

9nR4qAgU.title: Atomic-scale bonding of bulk metallic glass to crystalline aluminum
9nR4qAgU.abstract: A Ti40 Zr25 Cu12 Ni3 Be20 bulk metallic glass (BMG) was welded to a crystalline aluminum by the parallel plate explosive welding method. Experimental evidence and numerical simulation show that atomic-scale bonding between the BMG and the crystalline aluminum can be achieved, and the weldment on the BMG side can retain its amorphous state without any indication of crystallization in the welding process. Nanoindentation tests reveal that the interface of the explosive joints exhibits a significant increase in hardness compared to the matrix on its two sides. The joining of BMG and crystalline materials opens a window to the applications of BMGs in engineering. © 2008 American Institute of Physics.

Mt1raqvP.title: STUDY ON THE SURFACE PROPERTY OF OXIDIZED TANNIN EXTRACT SOLUTION IN TANNIN EXTRACT DESULFURIZATION PROCESS
Mt1raqvP.abstract: Comparing with ADA,the tannin extract desulfurization is more superior and applied widely in industry.In order to reveal the advantages,the surface properties of oxidized tannin extract and ADA aqueous solution are researched using surface tensiometer and conductivity meter.The results shows that the oxidized tannin extract is an ionic surfactant,which can reduce the surface tension of solution and intensify the gas-liquid mass transfer rate of hydrogen sulfide or air with solution.Howere,the ADA solution is not of property.That is the reason for advantage.The critical micelle concentration of oxidized tannin extract solution is 0.53 g/L,and this value can be used as a minimum concentration in tannin extract desulphurization solution.

GkpL8PkC.title: Sol-gel derived wide-band antireflection SiO2 coating for solar collector
GkpL8PkC.abstract: To improve the efficiency of solar collector, a wide-band antireflection coating composed of nanostructured porous SiO2 particles was designed and coated on the transparent glazing of a solar collector to reduce its reflectivity. The optimal optical parameters of the coating were determined by theoretical calculation of the reflectivity according to the optical principle of these films. Using different catalysts and control methods, the mol ratio of reactors and other experimental parameters, were determined and the SiO2 sols with different particles were prepared by hydrolysis and condensation reaction of TEOS diluted in ethanol. SiO2 coatings derived from such sols were prepared with the desired optical parameters of antireflection coating. The optical parameters of the coating are measured by ellipsometer and alpha-step apparatus, and the microstructure is observed by SEM while the reflectivity is shown by spectrophotometer.

3z7lDK9t.title: Nanocrystallization of Zr–Ti–Cu–Ni–Be bulk metallic glass
3z7lDK9t.abstract: The nanocrystallization kinetics of Zr 41.2 Ti 13.8 Cu 12.5 Ni 10 Be 22.5 (at.%) bulk metallic glass was investigated by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) in the mode of continuous heating and isothermal annealing. In the case of continuous heating, three exothermic crystallization peaks can be observed, and the peak temperatures display a strong dependence on the heating rates, which can be fitted by a first order decay equation. The activation energies for crystallization are estimated to be E p1 =166.83±8.85 kJ/mol, E p2 =256.15±9.34 kJ/mol, E p3 =174.36±12.56 kJ/mol, which correspond to peak temperatures of T p1 , T p2 , and T p3 , respectively, indicating the formation of different crystallization phases at different stages. In the case of isothermal annealing, the crystallization products under isothermal annealing were observed and determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The precipitation phases of the sample heated at higher temperatures were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD), showing that the body-centered tetragonal (bct) Zr 2 Cu and hexagonal ZrBe 2 are the primary phases, in spite of the presence of other phases. These results are consistent with the complexity of the DSC curves obtained during the continuous heating and isothermal annealing.

4a0mWyfu.title: Low Dielectric Constant Nanoporous Silica Films
4a0mWyfu.abstract: A novel route to prepare low-dielectric constant mesoporous SiO2 films was reported. Silicate sols were prepared with the precursor of TEOS and template of CTAB catalyzed by hydrochloric acid. The films were prepared by dip-coating process. FTIR, XRD and AFM were employed to characterize the films. The dielectric constants were measured by impedance analysis apparatus. These films with dielectric constants smaller than 2.2 could be acquired by adjusting the concentration of CTAB and aging time.

OaEpvEtG.title: Preparation of laser frequency tripling antireflective film with high-strength
OaEpvEtG.abstract: Nano-porous SiO2 antireflective film with high-strength was made using dipping-coating technique with ammonia process post treatment by Sol-Gel method. The effect of different dip speed on transmission spectra is studied. The result shows that the site of transmission peak shifts with various dip speed. After ammonia process treatment, the mechanical property of film was improved obviously and the mechanism was discussed by IR spectrum, AFM analysis methods. Laser frequency tripling antireflective film was made on silex glass substrate. The reflectance of film at 355 nm is about 99.58%.

p3X86FQh.abstract: A nanostructured film of graphitized diamond crystallites for field electron emission was prepared and characterized. The process of dielectrophoresis was used. FXQKJHl9.title: Design and Implementation of Data Acquisition Instrument for FOG Strapdown Inertial Navigation System
FXQKJHl9.abstract: A data acquisition instrument is studied and implemented for the Fiber-optical -gyro Strapdown Inertial Navigation System (SINS). Based on the 80C196KC micro-controller unit (MCU), the data acquisition of the fiber-optical-gyros is implemented with the Quadruple Asynchronous Communication Element (QACE) chip TL16C554. And a 16-bit high precision AD676 is used for the data acquisition of the accelerometers. Both the hardware and software design of the data acquisition system is presented. The results show that the data acquisition instrument can meet the requirements for the SINS on data acquirement capability, and has good practicality.

cuA4aQQH.title: The selecting intention and influencing factors of the field of nursing of nursing students
cuA4aQQH.abstract: Objective:To understand the selecting intention and influencing factors of the field of nursing of nursing students.Methods:Totally 622 nursing students studying in Chongqing Medical University were investigated by self-designed Questionnaires.Results:The top three of most yearning field respectively are operating theatre(27.8%),obstetrics(19.0%) and paediatrics(16.6%).The top three of least yearning field respectively are psychiatry(48.2%),community health care(14.5%)and geriatric nursing(11.1%).Conclusion:There is serious imbalance when nursing students select the field of nursing,which makes against development of nursing profession.

uTYqIOAs.title: Direct synthesis of carbon nanotube on stainless steel cathode
uTYqIOAs.abstract: Fabrication of carbon nanotube cold cathode requires an efficient and low cost process. In the paper, carbon nanotube is direct synthesized on stainless steel which acts as cathode substrate and catalyst for growing carbon nanotube. The best type of stainless steel is chosen and investigated its effect on the synthesis quality of carbon nanotube. The field emission character of carbon nanotube on stainless steel is also measured. © 2013 IEEE.

LBLFx32M.title: Growth of a single graphene sheet on a tungsten tip
LBLFx32M.abstract: A single few-layer graphene (FLG) sheet is synthesized on a tungsten tip by using microwave plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition method. The sheet density of FLG on a tungsten tip is controlled by the substrate surface structure and local plasma density. This method provides a new way to fabricate a field emission point electron source.

KHNCf0ru.title: Modeling Mobile Learning System Using ANFIS
KHNCf0ru.abstract: Personalisation is becoming more important in the area of mobile learning. Learner model is logically partitioned into smaller elements or classes in the form of learner profiles, which can represent the entire learning process. Machine learning techniques have the ability to detect patterns from complicated data and learn how to perform activities based on learner profiles. This paper focuses on a systematic approach in reasoning the learner contexts to deliver adaptive learning content. A fuzzy rule base model that has been proposed in related work is found insufficient in deciding all possible conditions. To tackle this problem, this paper adopts the Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) approach to determine all possible conditions. ANFIS uses the hybrid (least-squares method and the back propagation gradient descent method) as learning mechanism for the Neural Network to determine the incompleteness in the decision made by human experts. The simulating results by Matlab indicate that the performance of ANFIS approach is valuable and easy to implement.

dvJxMpE1.title: Diagnostic Value of Parapharyngeal Space for Head and Neck Tumors on MR Imaging
dvJxMpE1.abstract: Objective To explore the diagnostic value of the displace direction of parapharyngeal space(PPS)and MRI features of head and neck tumors for confirming the location and nature of the lesions.Methods 76 cases of head and neck tumors histopathologically proved involving PPS were reviewed retrospectively,including 51 malignant and 25 benign lesions.Results The prestyloid space displaced laterally in tonsil tumor and nasopharyngeal carcinoma(NPC)and the prestyloid space displaced anterior-medially or/and carotid space displaced posteriorly in parotid tumor.Of the tumors located in the carotid space,there were anterior and lateral displacement of the internal carotid artery(ICA)and internal jugular vein(IJV)in neurinomas of sympathetic nerve.The ICA and IJV were separated apart in neurinoma of vagus nerve.The angle of the ICA and external carotid artery enlarged was increased in carotid body tumors.There were anterior and lateral displacement of the ICA and IJV in jugular glomus tumors,anterior and medial displacement of the vessels in metastatic nodal lymph.The border was clear in 25 benign lesions,which the signal intensity was homogeneous in 9 cases.Of 51 malignant lesions,the outline of 19 cases was vague and the signal intensity of 15 cases was heterogeneous.The fat plane of prestyloid space disappeared completely or partly were all malignant in 6 cases.Though the tumor border was clear,the lymph nodes of neck met the standard of metastatic adenopathy in 2 cases and the ICA and IJV were surrounded by tumors in 3 cases were also malignant.Conclusion The displace direction of PPS and MRI features of the tumors are of important value for confirming the location and nature of head and neck lesions.

NCUXK4MT.title: Design and Implementation of Monitoring Software for Inertial Devices Testing System
NCUXK4MT.abstract: In accordance with the needs of calibration and testing for inertial devices, monitoring software is designed and implemented with Visual C++ environment. In the development, with the key technology which includes the Memory Bitmap, the List and the Multimedia Timer, the goal of displaying the real-time dynamic signal curves and analyzing the sampling data has been achieved. In this paper,designing idea, structure and function of the system have been discussed exhaustively. Moreover, parts of codes are pro-vided. The applications show that the system is simple and feasible and has powerful practicality in engineering.

9WIHcKFc.title: Bone marrow MR imaging as predictors of outcome in hemopoietic stem cell transplantation.
9WIHcKFc.abstract: The purpose of this study is to investigate the role of femoral marrow MR imaging as predictor of outcome for hemopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in beta-thalassemia major. MR imaging of the proximal femur, including T1- and T2-weighted spin echo and short-tau inversion recovery and in-phase and out-of-phase fast field echo images, was prospectively performed in 27 thalassemia major patients being prepared for HSCT. The area of red marrow and its percentage of the proximal femur were measured, and the presence of marrow hemosiderosis was assessed. Age-adjusted multivariate logistic regression was used to determine the relationship between red marrow area percentage and marrow hemosiderosis and HSCT outcome. Red area percentage were less in patients with successful (90.25 +/- 4.14%) compared to unsuccessful transplants (94.54% +/- 2.93%; p = 0.01). Red marrow area percentage correlated positively with duration of symptoms(r = 0.428, p = 0.026) and serum ferritin (r = 0.511, p = 0.006). In multivariate-adjusted logistic regression analyses, red marrow area percentage was significantly inversely associated with successful HSCT (OR = 1.383, 95% CI: 1.059-1.805, p = 0.005). Marrow hemosidersosis and duration of sympotms and serum ferritin were not associated with HSCT outcome(p = 0.174, 0.974, 0.762, respectively). Red marrow area percentage of proximal femur on MR imaging is a useful predictor of HSCT outcome.
keywords: mr imaging . thalassemia . hematopoietic stem cell transplantation . bone marrow

BWRPYXlZ.title: Improvement of the Field Emission from Screen Printed Carbon Nanotube Cold Cathode by Applying Electrical Field
BWRPYXlZ.abstract: The effects of field emission cycles applied on the screen printed carbon nanotube (CNT) cold cathode were studied. CNT emitters were vertically well aligned and the emission images were visibly improved after the field treatment. The mechanism of the treatment was investigated using scanning electron microscopy. The mechanism may involve the erasion of hot spot and alignment of CNT

prgZsXHK.title: In vivo MRI monitoring nerve regeneration of acute peripheral nerve traction injury following mesenchymal stem cell transplantation.
prgZsXHK.abstract: To assess the continuous process of nerve regeneration in acute peripheral nerve traction injury treated with mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) transplantation using MRI.1 week after acute nerve traction injury was established in the sciatic nerve of 48 New Zealand white rabbits, 5×10(5) MSCs and vehicle alone were grafted to the acutely distracted sciatic nerves each in 24 animals. Serial MRI and T1 and T2 measurements of the injured nerves were performed with a 1.5-T scanner and functional recovery was recorded over a 10-week follow-up period, with histological assessments performed at regular intervals.Compared with vehicle control, nerves grafted with MSCs had better functional recovery and showed improved nerve regeneration, with a sustained increase of T1 and T2 values during the phase of regeneration.MRI could be used to monitor the enhanced nerve regeneration in acute peripheral nerve traction injury treated with MSC transplantation, reflected by a prolonged increase in T1 and T2 values of the injured nerves.

8QVNbXgW.title: Synthesis of large-scaled MoO2 nanowire arrays
8QVNbXgW.abstract: Large-scaled MoO 2 nanowire arrays have been prepared on silicon substrates by thermal evaporation of Mo in a flow of argon gas without using any catalyst. The nanowires are well aligned and vertically oriented to substrate surface. The cross-section of most of the nanowires has a polygonal shape with the width of about 150 nm, and the typical lengths of the nanowires vary from 2 to 4 μm. The X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy reveals that the nanowires contained elements of Mo and O. X-ray diffraction analyses and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy study show that the MoO 2 nanowires are of monoclinic structure.

LdHNQtHk.title: The Relationship between Steroid Therapy and Osteonecrosis of Hip and Knee in Patients with Recovered Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome
LdHNQtHk.abstract: Objective To determine the relationship between the steroid therapy and the osteonecrosis of hip and knee in patients with severe acute respiratory. Materials and Methods 148 healthcare workers with recovered SARS from 5 hospitals in Guangzhou were examined with MR imaging of the lower extremity including bilateral hips and knees. Of 148 healthcare workers, 42 cases had not treated with steroid, while 106 cases had treated with varied dosage steroid. The imaging protocol was consisted of screening and full examination. Coronal T1 weighted imaging and short T1 inversion recovery sequences were defined as the screening examination. The full examination was complement to the screening examination, transverse and coronal T2 weighted imaging and short T1 inversion recovery sequences were used. Results Of 42 cases without the treatment of steroid, none was found with the necrosis of lower extremity. Of 106 cases treated with steroid, 8 cases were found ischemia change in the lower extremity. Osteonecrosis of bilateral femoral head was found in 1 case,unilateral femoral head osteonecrosis in 2 cases, bilateral femoral heads and biilateral femoral condyle and tibial condyle concomitantly involved in 1 case, unilateral femoral condyle necrosis was found in 1 case. Femoral neck infarction with significant calcification occurred in 1 case. Bilateral femoral and tibial marrow edema were found in 2 cases. Results of multiple logistic regression analysis confirmed that cumulative prednisone-equivalent was the most important risk factor for osteonecrosis (P=0.001). Conclusion Osteonecrosis is occurred in the minority of healthcare workers with recovered SARS treated with steroid. The cumulative prednisone-equivalent dose is closely related to the occurrence of avascular necrosis.
keywords: Severe acute respiratory syndrome Osteonecrosis Magnetic resonance imaging

XSZDqFnz.title: Enhanced learner model for adaptive mobile learning
XSZDqFnz.abstract: Personalisation and learner modelling are becoming more important in the area of mobile learning applications, taking into consideration learners' interests, preferences and contextual information. Students nowadays are able to learn anywhere and at any time. Mobile learning application content is one of several factors within various contexts that play an important role in the success of the adaptation process. The vast amount of data involved in any successful adaptation process creates complexity and poses serious challenges. This paper focuses on how to model the learner and all possible contexts in an extensible way that can be used for personalisation in mobile learning. The enhanced learner modelling structure to be used in a mobile learning system is proposed. The proposed structure provides personalisation by adopting a hybrid approach combining two machine learning techniques.

BDFQ0o7Z.title: Compositional design and microstructure analysis of Zr-based bulk metallic glasses
BDFQ0o7Z.abstract: The systematical studies of Zr-based BMGs were summarized in terms of their compositional design and their structural characterization. In particular, several key issues of BMG materials were focused, including initial alloy design and subsequent composition optimization, solidification microstructure characterization and crystallization process specification. The results show that a compositional designing approach is successfully developed and, through extensive microstructure characterization using transmission electron microscopy, several new crystalline phases are discovered in these newly developed Zr-based BMG alloys. Crystallization behavior of Zr-based BMG is also determined based on the microstructure analysis. © 2007 The Nonferrous Metals Society of China.

0b0R4bjD.title: Methods and Mechanisms of Strengthening-toughening of NiAl Based Composite
0b0R4bjD.abstract: Recent researches on strengthening-toughening of NiAl based composite are reviewed.For improving the strength and toughness,several methods and mechanisms are introduced,such as alloying,grain refining or composite strengthening,and adopting advanced technology.But each of the strengthening methods can only improve the mechanical properties in a small range.At last,the existing problems in these researches and the future research aspects are pointed out,that if combines deeper researches in atomic scale with new technology and new equipment development,the shortness of mechanical properties of NiAl alloy could be well remedied,and the expectation for great use of this material could become true.

QGSUNZuV.title: Free volume and viscosity of Fe-Co-Cr-Mo-C-B-Y bulk metallic glasses and their correlation with glass-forming ability
QGSUNZuV.abstract: In this work, the variation of the glass-forming ability (GFA) in Fe-Co-Cr-Mo-C-B-Y alloy system with Co addition has been investigated from the viewpoints of non-isothermal viscosity and free volume. The best GFA for the alloy containing 7% Co is found to closely relate with its highest viscosity, and the minimum sizes and lowest concentrations of the intermediate and largest open volumes. The results may provide more insights into the formation mechanism of metallic glasses. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Uo3XtCUv.title: Predictive features of CT for risk stratifications in patients with primary gastrointestinal stromal tumour
Uo3XtCUv.abstract: Abstract Purpose To determine the predictive CT imaging features for risk stratifications in patients with primary gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs). Materials and methods One hundred and twenty-nine patients with histologically confirmed primary GISTs (diameter >2 cm) were enrolled. CT imaging features were reviewed. Tumour risk stratifications were determined according to the 2008 NIH criteria where GISTs were classified into four categories according to the tumour size, location, mitosis count, and tumour rupture. The association between risk stratifications and CT features was analyzed using univariate analysis, followed by multinomial logistic regression and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis. Results CT imaging features including tumour margin, size, shape, tumour growth pattern, direct organ invasion, necrosis, enlarged vessels feeding or draining the mass (EVFDM), lymphadenopathy, and contrast enhancement pattern were associated with the risk stratifications, as determined by univariate analysis (P < 0.05). Only lesion size, growth pattern and EVFDM remained independent risk factors in multinomial logistic regression analysis (OR = 3.480–100.384). ROC curve analysis showed that the area under curve of the obtained multinomial logistic regression model was 0.806 (95 % CI: 0.727–0.885). Conclusion CT features including lesion size, tumour growth pattern, and EVFDM were predictors of the risk stratifications for GIST. Key Points • CT features were of predictive value for risk stratification of GISTs. • Tumour size, growth patterns, and EVFDM were risk predictors of GISTs. • Large size, mixed growth pattern, or EVFDM indicated high risk GIST.

mikmQif4.title: Different Expression of Cysteine-aspartic Acid Protease-3 in Patients with Inflammatory Bowel Cisease
mikmQif4.abstract: Objective To study the correlation of plasma cysteine-aspartic acid protease-3(caspase-3)with clinical disease activity in patients with inflammatory bowel disease and its diagnostic value.Methods The expression of plasma caspase-3 levels in patients with Crohn's disease,ulcerative colitis and healthy controls were analyzed by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay(ELISA).Furthermore,correlation of plasma caspase-3 level and endoscopic disease activity was also analyzed.Receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC) was used to observe the potential clinical and research value of plasma caspase-3 in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.Data process was analyzed by GraphPad Prism 5.Results Plasma caspase-3 level was significantly higher in patients with Crohn's disease than in healthy controls(P=0.0022).However,plasma level of caspase-3 showed no significant difference in patients with ulcerative colitis from healthy controls(P=0.6377).caspase-3 level showeed low diagnostic value in differentiating Crohn's disease from healthy controls(AUC=0.6339,P=0.0039).Plasma caspase-3 level was not significantly associated with endoscopic disease activity in patients with Crohn's disease(r=-0.089,P=0.5172).Conclusion Plasma caspase-3 expression increases in patients with Crohn's disease.It is different from ulcerative colitis or healthy controls.

kFfCXiYD.title: Raman spectroscopic study of oxidation and phase transition in W 18O49 nanowires
kFfCXiYD.abstract: W18O49 nanowires were synthesized by a high-temperature physical evaporation technique. The structure, morphology, and composition of the nanowires were characterized by SEM, EMPA, XRD, XPS, and HRTEM techniques. The intrinsic Raman spectrum of W18U49 nanowires was obtained, and the effect of laser power on the change of their structure was also studied. W18O49 nanowires were first oxidized to tungsten trioxide nanowires under irradiation of a certain laser power, and then the tungsten trioxide nanowires underwent a phase transition from monoclinic to orthorhombic with increasing laser power; this phase transition was reversible on turning down the laser power. Copyright © 2006 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

v8Ik35Ox.title: Structural analysis and control of ultralow density silica aerogels prepared by sol-gel process
v8Ik35Ox.abstract: In this paper, nano-porous silica aerogels were prepared via sol-gel process with acid/base two-step catalysis technique. Silica aerogel structure can be effectively controlled by changing experimental parameter. Ultralow density silica aerogel with density as low as 3.4 mg/cm3 has been successfully prepared. Transmission electron microscope (TEM), gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) and particle size analyzer were used to characterize the properties of the microstructure and particle distribution of the sol. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used to characterize the microstructure of the aerogels. Structure controlling by changing the catalysis condition during sol-gel process was researched, and stabilization of the sol during long-time reserving was researched too. The results showed that silica sol particle can be controlled from 4nm to 9nm continuously and the optimized refluxing time was about 24 hours. © 2006 IEEE.

lf7UHSK8.title: Reflecting on ontologies: towards ontology-based agent-oriented software engineering
lf7UHSK8.abstract: "Ontology" in association with "software engineering" is becoming commonplace. This paper argues for the need to place ontologies at the centre of the software development lifecycle for multi agent systems to enhance reuse of software workproducts as well as to unify agent-based software engineering knowledge. The paper bridges the state-of-the-art of ontologies research from Knowledge Engineering (KE) within Artificial Intelligence and Metamodelling within Software Engineering (SE). It presents a sketch of an ontology-based Multi Agent System (MAS) methodology discussing key roles on ontologies and their impact of workproducts, illustrating these in a MAS software development project for an important application that utilizes dynamic web services composition.

QK8C1B6Q.title: Microstructure control of carbon aerogels
QK8C1B6Q.abstract: Thin and mechanically stable aerogel electrodes was prepared by integrating carbon fibers into the aerogel skeleton under ambient pressure instead of supercritical drying. The microstructure of carbon aerogel was investigated by using electron scanning microscope (SEM), pore size distribution and electrical conductivity measurement. Results show that the porous structure can be controlled from micro to macro porous through a variation of composition parameters, such as catalyst concentration, mass ratio, surface of fibres and the aged time prior to impregnation of the sol into fibres.

YWjOQu6S.title: Effect of probiotics on inducing remission and maintaining therapy in ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, and pouchitis: meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
YWjOQu6S.abstract: Whether probiotics are beneficial at all stages of treatment in inflammatory bowel disease or superior to placebo remains controversial.Two reviewers independently selected randomized controlled trials comparing probiotics with controls in inflammatory bowel disease and extracted data related to remission/response rates, relapse rates, and adverse events. Subanalyses were also performed.Twenty-three randomized controlled trials with a total of 1763 participants met the inclusion criteria. From the meta-analysis, probiotics significantly increase the remission rates in patients with active ulcerative colitis (UC) (P = 0.01, risk ratio [RR] = 1.51). The remission rates were significantly higher in patients with active UC treated with probiotics than placebo (P < 0.0001, RR = 1.80). Unfortunately, subgroup analysis found that only VSL#3 significantly increased the remission rates compared with controls in patients with active UC (P = 0.004, RR = 1.74). Interestingly, VSL#3 (P < 0.00001, RR = 0.18) also significantly reduced the clinical relapse rates for maintaining remission in patients with pouchitis. No significantly different adverse events were detected between probiotics and controls in the treatment of UC (P = 0.94, RR = 0.99) or CD (P = 0.33, RR = 0.87).Administration of probiotics results in additional benefit in inducing remission of patients with UC. VSL#3 are beneficial for maintaining remission in patients with pouchitis. And, probiotics can provide the similar effect as 5-aminosalicylic acid on maintaining remission of UC, although no additional adverse events presented.

M99YlKt1.title: Measurement of water transport rates across the gas diffusion layer in a proton exchange membrane fuel cell, and the influence of polytetrafluoroethylene content and micro-porous layer
M99YlKt1.abstract: Water management in a proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell is one of the critical issues for improving fuel cell performance and durability, and water transport across the gas diffusion layer plays a key role in PEM fuel cell water management. In this work, we investigated the effects of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) content and the application of a micro-porous layer (MPL) in the gas diffusion layer (GDL) on the water transport rate across the GDL. The results show that both PTFE and the MPL play a similar role of restraining water transport. The effects of different carbon loadings in the MPL on water transport were also investigated. The results demonstrate that the higher the carbon loading in the MPL, the more it reduces the water transport rate. Using the given cell hardware and components, the optimized operation conditions can be obtained based on a water balance analysis.

Muzusf4n.title: Effects of light illumination on field emission from CuO nanobelt arrays
Muzusf4n.abstract: Effects of pulsed and continuous light illumination on field emission from CuO nanobelt arrays have been studied by using a transparent anode technique. It is found that, at low-field emission current level, the field emission current generally increases under a pulsed irradiation; at an emission current level of 1.1 μA, a 19% increase in emission current was recorded. The photoinduced current increase is reduced with increasing emission current and is undetectable when the emission current is higher than 15 μA. On the other hand, a long time illumination of the sample decreases the field emission current. Possible physical mechanisms behind the observed phenomena are discussed. © 2005 American Institute of Physics.

eu2mZ21x.title: Tuned Cationic Dendronized Polymer as a Molecular Scavenger for Rheumatoid Arthritis Treatment.
eu2mZ21x.abstract: Cell free deoxyribonucleic acid (cfDNA) released from dead or damaged cells serves as a key autoantigen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). They could be recognized by nucleic acid (NA) sensors like toll-like receptor (TLR), leading to activation of the innate immune system and chronic inflammation. Herein, we develop a cationic molecular scavenger through a screening of cationic dendronized polymers, which could eliminate the cfDNA and inhibit the TLR recognition and nucleic acid-induced inflammation. The structure-property study demonstrates that toxicity, NA binding capacity and biodistribution could be balanced to achieve maximum therapeutic effect with exquisite control of molecular structure. In addition, the optimized cationic polymer effectively inhibited the joint swelling, synovial hyperplasia and bone destruction in collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model. The results supported that the synthetic polymers offer new paradigm for autoimmune disease treatment.

ERWGcaoC.title: Shear deformation and plasticity of metallic glass under multiaxial loading
ERWGcaoC.abstract: The evolution of multiple shear bands in a Zr-based metallic glass under multiaxial loading was systematically investigated by the small punch test. Unlike the fast propagation of the individual shear band and catastrophic failure of the metallic glass under uniaxial tensile or compressive loading, the metallic glass can be controlled to create regularly arrayed fine multiple shear bands under multiaxial loading. The distribution of the shear bands displayed a cobweb-like pattern along radial and circumferential directions. A large equivalent plastic strain (19.6%) was achieved in the metallic glass under multiaxial loading, which was far higher than that gained under uniaxial compressive loading. The multiaxial loading method was also applied to evaluate the mechanical properties of the annealed Zr-based metallic glass. Three types of failure modes were observed in the as-cast or annealed specimens: circumferential and radial shear failure, and radial normal (cleavage) failure. In contrast with uniaxial tension and compression, the multiaxial loading by small punch test was found to be very suitable for the evaluation of the mechanical properties of metallic glasses and, further, to distinguish the transition from ductility to brittleness more accurately.

3gcOjvBA.title: Growth direction manipulation of few-layer graphene in the vertical plane with parallel arrangement
3gcOjvBA.abstract: Vertical few-layer graphene (FLG) sheets have potential applications as field emitters and super capacitors. However, it remains a challenge to controllably grow FLG with vertical and parallel orientations. We intentionally designed the substrate surface structure to manipulate the distribution of the plasma sheath and induce the direction of the built-in electric field to guide the growth direction of the FLG in two dimensions. The effects of the plasma sheath and the built-in field on the FLG growth are discussed. The electrical and field emission characteristics of single sheet FLG with parallel and random types were measured, and they demonstrate similar and good characteristics. This method provides a way to controllably grow parallel and vertical FLG arrays. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

atqkJv4A.title: Characteristics and influencing factors of fault sealing in Pearl River Mouth Basin
atqkJv4A.abstract: Three groups of faults in north-west,east-west and north-east directions were generated in the Pearl River Mouth Basin under the extending stress in the south-east to south-north trending.The faults are almost the normal faults,and the positive and negative normal faults are coexistence.The sealing capacity of the faults is decided by the difference between threshold pressure and the displacement pressure of hydrocarbon.The different faults have the different effect on the fluid migration,and the same fault as a pathway for hydrocarbon migration at the different time has different capability.It is generally considered that the active fault is open and the stable fault is close.The analyses on the characteristics and the influencing factors for the fault sealing,and the study of stress,inner structure,deformation mechanism of the faults show that the content of clay is the key factor controlling the fault trap with hydrocarbon accumulation.At the same time,fault throw,fault trend,obliquity,activity time and subsequent small fault are also the affecting factors for fault traps in the Pearl River Mouth Basin.

cOZmeXqZ.title: Preparation and Characterization of Hydrophobic Silica Aerogels Doped with Fibers
cOZmeXqZ.abstract: Hydrophobic silica aerogel doped with ceramic fibers were prepared successfully via sol-gel process. The ceramic fibers were distributed inside the silica aerogels to act as a supporting skeleton material, which improved the mechanical property. The mechanical strength of the silica aerogels increases from 1.6×104 Pa to 9.6×104 Pa with the doping of 10% ceramic fibers, while the thermal conductivity is 0.029 W/(m?K) at room temperature in air. The hydrophobic properties of the doped aerogels are increased a lot by surface modification.

04Rso1lV.title: Catalyst-free synthesis of ZnO nanowire arrays on zinc substrate by low temperature thermal oxidation
04Rso1lV.abstract: High density ZnO nanowire arrays were successfully synthesized without catalyst by direct oxidation of zinc substrate in air below 400 °C, lower than the melting point of zinc metal. The as-grown ZnO nanowires are single crystalline with a Wurzite structure extending in <110> direction. The diameters of the ZnO nanowires range from 20 to 150 nm and the lengths from several to over ten micrometers. Room temperature photoluminescence measurements reveal an intense ultraviolet emission at 397 nm. The present work highlights the promise of the low temperature, direct oxidation process in the high-yield synthesis of high quality semiconductor nanowire arrays for nano-devices.

UPEclSgL.title: Cooling rate effect of nanomechanical response for a Ti-based bulk metallic glass
UPEclSgL.abstract: The effect of cooling rate on the mechanical behaviors of a Ti-based bulk metallic glass has been studied using nanoindentation technique. It is found that the hardness increases, while the plastic deformation capacity gradually decreases from the edge to the center of the sample. The variation of the structural uniformity within the as-cast glassy sample may account for the cooling rate dependence of mechanical performance.

Kvc1tHWh.title: Assessment of Cardiac Lead Perforation: Comparison Among Chest Radiography, Transthoracic Echocardiography and Electrocardiography-gated Contrast-enhanced Cardiac CT.
Kvc1tHWh.abstract: • ECG-gated contrast-enhanced cardiac CT has an accuracy of 98.1% in the diagnosis of cardiac lead perforation. • The AUROC of ECG-gated contrast-enhanced cardiac CT is higher than those of chest radiography and TTE imaging. • ECG-gated contrast-enhanced cardiac CT imaging has better diagnostic performance than both chest radiography and TTE imaging for the assessment of cardiac lead perforation.
