ENY5JXvu.title: MR imaging and T2 measurements in peripheral nerve repair with activation of Toll-like receptor 4 of neurotmesis.
ENY5JXvu.abstract: To investigate the role of MR imaging in neurotmesis combined with surgical repair and Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) activation.Forty-eight rats received subepineurial microinjection of the TLR4 agonist lipopolysaccharide (LPS, n = 24) or phosphate buffered saline (PBS, n = 24) immediately after surgical repair of the transected sciatic nerve. Sequential fat-suppressed T2-weighted imaging and quantitative T2 measurements were obtained at 3, 7, 14 and 21 days after surgery, with histologic assessments performed at regular intervals. T2 relaxation times and histological quantification of the distal stumps were measured and compared.The distal stumps of transected nerves treated with LPS or PBS both showed persistent enlargement and hyperintense signal. T2 values of the distal stumps showed a rapid rise to peak level followed by a rapid decline pattern in nerves treated with LPS, while exhibiting a slow rise to peak value followed by a slow decline in nerves treated with PBS. Nerves treated with LPS exhibited more prominent macrophage recruitment, faster myelin debris clearance and more pronounced nerve regeneration.Nerves treated with TLR4 activation had a characteristic pattern of T2 value change over time. Longitudinal T2 measurements can be used to detect the enhanced repair effect associated with TLR4 activation in the surgical repair of neurotmesis.• TLR4 activation had additional beneficial effects on neurotmesis beyond surgical repair. • TLR4 activation had a characteristic time course of T2 values. • T2 measurements can help detect beneficial effects with TLR4 activation.

sOR6GqCg.title: Large-scale fabrication of ordered arrays of microcontainers and the restraint effect on growth of CuO nanowires.
sOR6GqCg.abstract: Technique has been developed to fabricate ordered arrays of microcontainers. We report that ordered microcontainer arrays of Cu can be fabricated on glass substrate by thin film deposition and self-assembly technology. In addition, CuO nanowires are found to grow only in the inner sides of microcontainers, which verifies the stress growth mechanism of CuO nanowires. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy study reveals that CuO nanowires grow along the [110] direction. Such structure may have potential application in micro-electron sources, which have the self-focused function.

u1MoEImm.title: Optical absorption edge evolution of vanadium pentoxide films during lithium intercalation
u1MoEImm.abstract: The influence of lithium intercalation on the optical absorption of vanadium pentoxide films is reported in this paper. Thin films were prepared by thermal evaporation followed by annealing in air. Lithium was inserted electrochemically so that Li x V 2 O 5 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.54) was obtained. The pristine and lithium inserted films were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), optical spectroscopy, and ellipsometry. The optical absorption coefficient was calculated from measured normal transmittance and reflectance spectra. XRD analysis has shown that the as-grown V 2 O 5 films were amorphous, becoming microcrystal after annealing at 350 °C. The optical absorption spectra of all the samples exhibited two distinct regions of behavior: at high-energy where ( αhν ) 1/2 varied linearly with the photonic energy hν , and a low-energy tail. The blue shift of the optical absorption edge is attributed to the Fermi level going into the conduction band after lithium insertion, and the relation between the change of the optical gap and the inserted electron concentration is interpreted in terms of a Burstein–Moss shift. The results confirm that the anodic electrochromism of V 2 O 5 thin films is due to the blue shift of the absorption edge, and the near-infrared cathodic electrochromism arises from absorption of small polarons in V 2 O 5 . Keywords Vanadium oxide Optical properties Evaporation 1 Introduction Vanadium pentoxide films are of increasing interest due to their unique feature such as electro-chemical activity, high stability, high specific energy, high energy density, and high capacity as well as special layer structure. Therefore they are regarded as a promising candidate amongst the cathode active materials for electrochromic devices as well as for lithium secondary batteries, and for photo-catalysis and photovoltaics [1–5] . There are many methods, such as evaporation [6] , sputtering [7] , sol–gel process [8] , and chemical vapor deposition [9] , used to prepare V 2 O 5 films. Their structure, electrochemical, electrochromic, and optical properties, as well as influence of experimental conditions, have been extensively studied. Green and Pita [10] have studied the quantitative influence of lithium intercalation on the optical absorption of vanadium pentoxide films. However, further understanding an evolution of the optical absorption edge for vanadium pentoxide films during lithium intercalation has attracted theoretical importance in the electron state structure of the lithiated vanadium pentoxide. In this paper, V 2 O 5 thin films were prepared by the thermal evaporation of V 2 O 5 powder. Li x V 2 O 5 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.54) films were obtained using lithium electrochemical intercalation. The films were characterized by XRD, optical absorption, and ellipsometry. The optical absorption properties of the pristine and lithiated vanadium pentoxide films were investigated. Finally, the electronic state and absorption mechanism of the lithium inserted films are discussed. 2 Experimental details Vanadium pentoxide films were prepared by the vacuum evaporation of 99.99% pure V 2 O 5 powder using a resistively heated molybdenum boat positioned 25 cm below the substrate. The ITO (In 2 O 3 :Sn) coated and uncoated optical glass substrates had been chemically and ultrasonically cleaned. The apparatus was a vacuum system (the pressure lower than 1 × 10 −3 Pa) equipped with an oil diffusion pump backed by a mechanical pump. The evaporation rate was monitored by a quartz crystal oscillator and was kept at about 0.5 nm/s. In order to obtained uniformity of film thickness, the substrates must be revolved during deposition at a required speed. Then the samples were taken out of the chamber and annealed in an oven at 350 °C in an O 2 atmosphere. The temperature was automatically measured and controlled by a thermocouple; its accuracy is ± 1 °C. V 2 O 5 films were lithiated in a two-electrode electrochemical cell containing an electrolyte consisting of 1 M LiClO 4 in propylene carbonate (PC). The reagent grade LiClO 4 was dried under vacuum, and PC was distilled also under vacuum. The films with a 2.55 cm 2 active area served as working electrode in this cell, and Pt as the counterelectrode. A constant electrolysis current of 100 μA was used, and the amount of inserted charges was controlled by time. The cell was operated under dry condition in a glove box. Using the method of Talledo and Granqvist [11] , the quantity of lithium insertion–given as x in Li x V 2 O 5 –was derived from the known dimension of the films and the amount of intercalated charges, and assuming that the annealed films had the same density as the bulk of V 2 O 5 (3.357 g/cm 3 ). XRD patterns were obtained for samples using a Phillips PW170 X-ray diffractometer with CuK α radiation. The normal transmittance and reflectance spectra were recorded with a spectrophotometer (UV-4000, Hitachi), and a fresh Al mirror was used as the reference. Thickness of the films was determined by a Tencor Alpha Step instrument with a resolution of 2 nm and an accuracy of 5%. 3 Results and discussion The as-grown films had a slight green tint. After the films were annealed in an O 2 atmosphere at 350 °C for 20 min, the films had a characteristic yellow appearance, like V 2 O 5 powder. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the as-grown films are amorphous, while the post-treated samples have some diffraction peaks as shown in Fig. 1 corresponding to the orthorhombic V 2 O 5 , but the peaks are very weak, indicating that the films have a microcrystalline structure. This phenomenon has been observed by other researchers on sputtered [12,13] and sol–gel derived [14,15] V 2 O 5 films. Fig. 2 gives transmittance spectra of the pristine and lithiated V 2 O 5 films in the near-ultraviolet and visible region. It can be seen that the transmittance in the near-ultraviolet region changed strongly with the increase of the amount of intercalated lithium. At the wavelength of 400 nm, for example, the transmittance increases from 6.1% to 55.0% with the intercalated lithium x from 0 to 0.54, while the transmittance at 570 nm is kept almost unchanged. On the other hand, the transmittance in the near-infrared region has a slight change with the increase of intercalated lithium. For example, it has a change of about 14.1% at 700 nm when the amount of the intercalated lithium ranges from 0 to 0.54. All these have revealed that V 2 O 5 films have a double electrochromic effect. In the near-ultraviolet region, the films show an anodic electrochromic effect and, in the near-infrared region, a cathodic effect. This is in good agreement with that reported by Cogan et al. [2] . Fig. 3 presents the absorption spectra deduced from the optical reflectance and transmittance of the films in the 300–1000 nm wavelength region. It can be seen remarkably that the optical absorption edge E g of the films shifts to a shorter wavelength when the lithiated amount increases, showing a wider optical absorption gap of the lithiated V 2 O 5 films. Also the films gave a strong optical absorption in the range of wavelength at about 750 nm compared with the pristine V 2 O 5 films. This behavior is accompanied with a color change of the films. A similar shift in the absorption edge was observed in both sol–gel derived and sputtered V 2 O 5 films [7,16,17] . In order to understand an evolution of the energy band structure of V 2 O 5 films during lithium intercalation, optical absorption coefficient has been calculated as shown in Fig. 4 . It can be observed that there are two regions: in the higher energy region ( αhν ) 1/2 , a linear change with an increase of the photonic energy hν ; and in the lower energy region, there is a tail with strong optical absorption, especially for the lithiated V 2 O 5 films. Moreover, the absorption increases with increasing x in Li x V 2 O 5 . Meanwhile, the photonic energy at the intersection between the two regions moves to a higher energy after intercalating lithium. The absorption in the two regions may be attributed to the two different absorption mechanisms discussed as follows. To estimate the optical band gap E g , the absorption coefficient has been analyzed in terms of the relation: α ⁢ h ⁢ ν = B ( E − E g ) n where B is a constant. The Tauc plot ( n = 2), corresponding to an indirect transition, is shown in Fig. 5 . Extrapolating the line to photonic energy hν axis, the optical absorption edge E g is obtained. From the figure, it can be found that E g is 2.03 eV for the pristine V 2 O 5 films, and E g increases with increasing x , ranging from 2.03 eV to 2.62 eV when x increases from 0 to 0.54. For the pristine V 2 O 5 films, the obtained E g is quite reasonable because the E g of V 2 O 5 is dependent on the experimental conditions and preparation methods, usually between 1.90 and 2.18 eV calculated by Parker et al. [18] , Aita et al. [19] , and Benmoussa et al. [20] . On the other hand, the shift of the optical absorption edge to a lower wavelength has been confirmed by Cogan et al. [2] and Benmoussa et al. [7] after lithium ions and electrons insert into V 2 O 5 films. The widening of the optical absorption gap of the lithiated V 2 O 5 films can be explained based on the semiconductor model. Fig. 6 shows the energy band scheme [10,11,18] of V 2 O 5 . The conduction band (CB) is split two energy bands, and the energy gap between the lower and higher band is about 0.6 eV. The electron transition between the two parts of the CB is partly forbidden [21] . The lower band, split-off band, has a V 3d xy and V 3d yz character [10,18] . Therefore the narrowest optical gap is about 2.0 eV, where electrons transit from the top of the valence band (VB) to the split-off band [18] . The Fermi level is located somewhere in the midregion of the optical absorption gap for the pristine V 2 O 5 . After insertion of electrons and lithium ions into the V 2 O 5 films, the electron concentration n e in the films increases. When n e is small, the Fermi level is located below the conducting band. With increasing electron concentration, n e , the Fermi level moves up to near the bottom of the conduction band. When the electron concentration n e is larger than a critical value N c , the Fermi level enters into the conduction band [22] . The critical value N c can be estimated using the Mott criterion [22] : N c 1 / 3 a 0 * ≈ 0.25 where a 0 * is the effect Bohr radius, given by the expression a 0 * = h 2 ɛ 0 ɛ M /π e 2 m c *; here h is Plank's constant, ɛ 0 is the permittivity of the free space, ɛ M is the static dielectric constant of the host lattice, e is the charge of the electron, and m c *, the effective mass, can be obtained from the equation ɛ inf m c * = 1.4 m , where ɛ inf is the optical dielectric constant, and m is the electron rest mass. For V 2 O 5 , using the data from the value reported by Parker et al. [18] , the calculated N c is about 2.3 × 10 19 /cm 3 . When the electron concentration n e is larger than N c , the Fermi level lies in the conduction band. In the circumstances, the Fermi level can be expressed as ( h 2 /8π 2 m c *) K F 2 , where K F is the magnitude of the wave vector. At the Fermi level, it is (3π 2 n e ) 1/3 . For the high electron concentration n e above the critical value N c , the optical absorption gap widens because of the above shift of the Fermi level. Then the optical gap can be written as [22] : E g = E g 0 + Δ E g BM where E g0 is the optical gap for the pristine V 2 O 5 , and Δ E g BM is the Burstein–Moss (BM) shift, and is expressed as Δ E g BM = ( h 2 /8π 2 m νc *)(3π 2 n e ) 2/3 ; here the effective mass m νc * satisfies the expression: ( m νc *) −1 = ( m c *) −1 + ( m ν *) −1 . Experimentally, a constant current of 100 μA was injected into the V 2 O 5 thin film samples. When the inserted lithium x is 0.0021, the electron concentration n e just equals the critical value N c . Therefore, the Fermi level has entered into the conduction band in the studied range of the inserted lithium amount. Fig. 7 gives the relation between the inserted electron concentration and the BM shift. It can be found that they are very well satisfied with a line that is consistent with the Burstein–Moss theory. Theoretically, the band-gap widening is not only attributed to the Burstein–Moss effect [22] . According to the semiconductor theory, the amount Δ E g (= E g − E g0 ) of the band-gap widening upon insertion of lithium ions and electrons can be written as [22] : Δ E g = Δ E g BM + Δ ⁢ E ′ = Δ E g BM + h ∑ c ( k F , ω ) − h ∑ ν ( k F , ω ) where Δ E g BM means the Burstain–Mott shift, which is due to a blocking of the lowest states in the conduction band and hence a widening of E g [22,23] , while Δ E ′ is attributed to electron interaction and impurity, which tend to decrease the band-gap [22] . Green and Pita [10] gave a reasonable explanation about the latter. They thought there are two reasons. The first is due to interactions between lithium ions and the host lattice, which modifies the vanadium–oxygen bonding and must therefore modify the value of the main gap energy, although it is very weak. The second is due to the electrons accompanying lithium ion insertion and also interaction with the host lattice. However, the experimental results given by Green and Pita [10] also showed that the band-gap widening is almost directly proportional to the lithium ion inserted (amount x , when x is less than 0.55). That is in excellent agreement with our results. Therefore, it is reasonably supposed that electron interaction and impurity interaction are much weak, which means that Δ E ′ is much small; thus the BM shift mainly governs the band-gap widening when amount x of the inserted lithium ions is small. The absorption tail in the low photonic energy region has been also observed by Luksich and Aita [13] and Benmoussa et al. [20] . The absorption tail is attributed to charge defects in the films which are caused by impurities [19,20] . When the concentration of the impurity is very low, the absorption tail cannot be found clearly. After the concentration increases, the delocalization of charges happens due to the interaction between the adjacent impure charges. Thus, the flat strong absorption tail occurs [24] . In our experiment, the highly pure V 2 O 5 powder was used as the evaporation source material and the thermal evaporation was performed in a high vacuum system; there should be no other elements in the film. Moreover, Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) analyses [30] indicated that there are only O and V elements in the pristine V 2 O 5 films, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements [30] revealed that V atoms are not only in + 5 valence state, but also in + 4 valence state. These were also found by Luksich and Aita [13] and Salvi et al. [26] . Those V 4+ ions may arise from vanadyl O vacancies and/or the general disorder of the amorphous structure for the pristine films. Luksich and Aita [13] also confirmed that in the case of crystalline V 2 O 5 , V 4+ sites were created during growth, concurrent with creating vanadyl O vacancies, and for the amorphous materials, V 4+ sites arise possible from the general disorder even for amorphous, stoichiometric V 2 O 5 films. Therefore, the absorption tail results from V 4+ self-impurities. The research on optical properties of sputtered V 2 O 5 films reported by Luksich and Aita [13] has also confirmed the phenomenon. They found that the absorption coefficient is about 10 4 cm − 1 and that the low energy absorption tail disappears, attributed to the elimination of V 4+ . On the other hand, the semiconducting behavior of the amorphous vanadium pentoxide arises from hopping of electrons between V atoms in + 5 and + 4 valence states [13] . Therefore the absorption tail is assigned to polaron transition therein [25] . Electrons and lithium ions intercalated into the V 2 O 5 matrix can be expressed as: V 2 O 5 + x Li+ xe ⇔Li x V 2 O 5 Meanwhile it is well known that a change in the valence state of vanadium has taken place [6,26,27] (e.g., V 5+ + e →V 4+ ). Therefore upon insertion of electrons and ions, the concentration of V 4+ in the lithiated V 2 O 5 films increases. Thus the absorption tail increases as shown in Fig. 3 . In fact, the absorption tail in the lithiated V 2 O 5 films arises from polarons which move from V 4+ to V 5+ sites by absorbing photons. Electron nuclear double resonance (ENDOR) by Pecuenard et al. [28] has given clear evidence that the α-Li x V 2 O 5 structure produces polarons including bound ones trapped on four vanadium sites around the Li + ions and free polarons around a single vanadium site. Also the polarons in the Na a V 2 O 5 structure [29] have been confirmed. All these polarons contribute to the optical absorption in the low energy tail. Furthermore it has been found experimentally that the peak of the polaron absorption resulting from the electron transition from V 4+ sites to V 5+ sites ranges from the visible region to the near-infrared region [25] . This is consistent with our results. 4 Conclusions It can be concluded that as-grown V 2 O 5 films are amorphous and became microcrystal after annealing at 350 °C. The optical absorption spectra of all the samples exhibit two distinct regions of behavior: firstly, at high energy where ( αhν ) 1/2 varied linearly with the photonic energy hν , and, secondly, a low-energy tail. The blue shift of the optical absorption edge is attributed to the Fermi level going into the conducting band after lithium insertion, and the relation between the change of the optical gap and inserted electron concentration is well satisfied in terms of the Burstein–Moss shift. These results also confirm that the anodic electrochromism of V 2 O 5 thin films is due to a shift of the absorption edge, and the cathodic electrochromism arises from the absorption of small polarons in V 2 O 5 . t9AwEGxp.title: Study on reaction property of coprocessing of Yangcun bituminous coal with petroleum residue
t9AwEGxp.abstract: The reaction process of coprocessing Shandong Yanzhou Yangcun bituminous coal and petroleum residue from Beijing Yanshan Petroleum Chemical Corporation was studied by using resonance agitation reactor. The effects of temperature and time on coal liquefaction conversion and products, including preasphaltene, asphaltene, was also investigated. The possible reaction mechanism was discussed. The results showed that there is a optimum reaction temperature and time during coprocessing. In this experiment system, the optimum temperature and time are 430��C and 20 minutes respectively. The reaction can be divided into three stages: rapid cracking hydrogenation, slow cracking hydrogenation and condense polymeration. The duration of each stage was different at various temperatures.

4u2WQcMb.title: Exceptionally high glass-forming ability of an FeCoCrMoCBY alloy
4u2WQcMb.abstract: It has been well documented that the maximum thickness of as-cast glassy samples attainable through conventional metallurgical routes is the decisive criteria for measuring the glass-forming ability (GFA) of bulk metallic glasses (BMGs). Here we report the exceptionally high GFA of an FeCoCrMoCBY alloy which can be fabricated in the form of glassy rods with a maximum sample thickness of at least 16 mm. It is demonstrated that, by substituting Fe with a proper amount of Co in a previously reported Fe-based BMG alloy, the glass formation of the resultant new alloy can be extensively favored both thermodynamically and kinetically. The new ferrous BMG alloy also exhibits a high fracture strength of 3500 MPa and Vickers hardness of 1253 kg mm-2. © 2005 American Institute of Physics.

bHzHYh0O.title: Predictive value of pretreatment MRI texture analysis in patients with primary nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
bHzHYh0O.abstract: • Higher CE-T1WI-based uniformity and smaller tumour volume are predictive of improved PFS in NPC patients. • The combination of CE-T1WI-based uniformity with tumour volume and the overall stage has a better predictive ability for PFS than the tumour volume or the overall stage alone. • Pretreatment MRI texture analysis has a prognostic value for NPC patients.

bBfAkVa9.title: Laser welding of a single tungsten oxide nanotip on a handleable tungsten wire: A demonstration of laser-weld nanoassembly
bBfAkVa9.abstract: The authors demonstrate that individual nanotips (W18 O49) may be laser welded onto the supporting microtip. The nanotip-microtip assembly can be handheld or ready for further manual manipulation, and thus is very useful for individual nanowire's characterization, selection, and applications in nanoprobe analysis, nano-optical and nanoelectronic devices, and biostudy. Well mechanical and electrical connections are shown between the nanotip-microtip. Field emission characterization shows that the welded nanotip is a promising candidate for point electron source application. © 2007 American Institute of Physics.

x7SIh3yF.title: Effect of silicon addition on sintering densification and microstructure of M3:2 high speed steel
x7SIh3yF.abstract: The effects of silicon on sintering microstructure and density of liquid phase sintered M3:2 high speed steel were characterized. The sintered materials were examined by means of scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, energy dispersive spectrometer and hardness test. Experimental results show that the silicon addition can improve the densification of M3:2 steel sintered at 1230°C. The sintered density of M3:2 steel with silicon addition is higher than that without silicon addition, full density is obtained with silicon addition of 0.7 wt%. When the silicon addition is lower than 0.7 wt%, the addition of silicon decreases austenite content and increases hardness of the steel. But when the silicon content increases to 3.0 wt%, the microstructure of matrix transforms from austenite and martensite to pearlite which decreases the hardness. It is also found that compared to steel with silicon addition of 0.2 wt% and 0.7 wt%, M3:2 steel with 0.4 wt% Si shows a higher carbide content and small grain size.

wRgM5POq.title: Hot deformation and grain refinement mechanisms of commercially pure titanium processed via three-directional cryo-compression
wRgM5POq.abstract: Abstract   Commercially pure titanium specimens were processed via three-directional compression at cryogenic temperature to activate homogeneous high-density deformation twins, and subsequent hot compression at 500 °C was applied to induce homogeneous grain refinement. Thus, homogenous and refined grains with an average grain size of 1.6 µm were achieved. During three-directional compression, four type of twins were activated, namely, parallel     {  11   2   ¯    2  }     twins, parallel     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     twins, intersectional     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     twins and parallel     {  11   2   ¯    1  }     twins. In the first pass,     {  10   1   ¯    2  }    ,     {  11   2   ¯    1  }     and     {  11   2   ¯    2  }     twins were activated; in the second pass,     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     and     {  11   2   ¯    2  }     twins were activated; and in the third pass,     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     twins were activated. During hot compression, the dynamic recrystallization (DRX) process was divided into twin-active DRX stage and continuous DRX (CDRX) stage. In the first stage, the DRX mechanisms were twinning induced CDRX (TCDRX) and twinning induce DDRX (TDDRX) in parallel     {  11   2   ¯    2  }     twins, TCDRX and TDDRX in parallel     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     twins, TCDRX and intersectional twins induced DRX (ITDRX) in intersectional     {  10   1   ¯    2  }     twins and TCDRX in parallel     {  11   2   ¯    1  }     twins. Nine types of new texture components formed in this stage. In the last stage, the DRX mechanism was CDRX. The  a u003e basal slip,  a u003e pyramidal slip and 1st  c  +  a u003e pyramidal slip were the major deformation mechanisms during hot deformation.

juBUZloZ.title: Superplastic flow behavior of Zr base bulk metallic glass in supercooled liquid region
juBUZloZ.abstract: Isothermal tensile tests of Zr 41.25Ti 13.75 Ni 10Cu 12.5Be 22.5 bulk metallic glass in supercooled liquid region are carried out at four characteristic temperatures of 616 , 636, 656 and 676 K which are in the vicinity of the end temperature of glass transition. Experimental results indicate that the superplastic flow behaviors of the material, viz., the flow stress and the elongation depend strongly on the testing temperature and tensile rate. The elongation increases firstly and then decreases with increasing rate and the maximum elongation reaches 1625% at 656 K and 5 mm/min. The strain rate sensitivity exponents determined by using Backofen method are 0.25, 0.65 and 0.93 at 636, 656 and 676 K, respectively. The free volume model is used to interpret the observed superplastic flow behavior.

hkd6jHxM.title: THE BASIC CHARACTERISTIC OF ACTIVE FAULT NEAR BIG SHIXIA HYDROELECTRIC INSTALLATION OF XINJIANG AKESU
hkd6jHxM.abstract: By studying many active faults near big Shixia hydroelectric installation,we though that Wushi sunken area in west of Kuche develops mainly active pleat which two rows new upheaval.From north to south,it is in turn Samula and Suergun anticline zones.The active fault in the area is mainly by NE.In them,the bigger faults are the Kuokeshale fault,Maidan-Shayilamu fault and Kuqi underlying fault.In the research area,the bigger fault which influenced for site is Maidan-Shayilamu fault and the fault in front of mountain near big Shixia.They both display the partition characteristic from east to west.The whole active intensity of faults shows that the west is strong while the east is weak.It is consistent with the result which the predecessor got.That is,they thought that the whole active of Tianshan mountain structures is weak gradually from west to east.Kuqi underlying fault is a late epipleistocene last stage active fault.And the newest active time was about 14,000 years apart from now.

6GCF0FcZ.title: TECTONIC FEATURE AND NEW ACTIVITY OF DONGQIULITAG IN KUQA DEPRESSION LOCATING SOUTH TIANSHAN OF XINJIANG
6GCF0FcZ.abstract: The Kuqa depression is located in the middle segment of the southern Tianshan Mountains.There are four E-W extending rows of reverse fault and anticline zones in the depression. From the south Tianshan Mountains towards the Tarim basin, they are the mountain piedmont, the Kasangtuokai, the Qiulitag and the Yaken reverse fault and fold zones. The most recent active fold in this system is the Qiulitag fold belt. Dongqiulitag anticlinal zone belongs to east segment of Qiulitag reverse fault and fold zone. Comparing with other tectonic belts, new tectonic movement of the east segment is very strong. Research shows that dongqiulitag anticlinal is fault propagation-detachment mixed-fold, which results from effect of shallow detachment surface and reverse fault locating south of Dongqiulitag anticlinal. In the south of Dongqiulitag anticlinal, shallow reverse fault and deep ramp structure are important seismogenic locus. Back thrusting fault of shallow anticlinal core and kinking of the north wing of Dongqiulitag anticline belong to derivative secondary-structure. Size of the rupture and disturbance is finite. Latest activity of reverse fault, which locates south wing of the Dongqiulitag anticline, dislocated II terrace gravel layer. Activity date of the reverse fault is not less than earlier Holocene Epoch. The disturbance leaves paleoearthquake fractured trace behind in the ground surface, which is 3-4 kilometre. It shows that the rupture features of stick-slip movement.

ES4FH5lw.title: Effect of R substitution on magnetic properties and magnetocaloric effects of La1-xRxFe11.5Si1.5 compounds with R Ce, Pr and Nd
ES4FH5lw.abstract: Magnetic properties and magnetocaloric effects of La1-xR xFe11.5Si1.5 (R Pr, (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.5); R Ce and Nd, (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.3)) compounds are investigated. Partially replacing La with R Ce, Pr and Nd in La1-xRxFe11.5Si 1.5 leads to a reduction in Curie temperature due to the lattice contraction. The substitution of R for La causes an enhancement in field-induced itinerant electron metamagnetic transition, which leads to a remarkable increase in magnetic entropy change ΔSm and also in hysteresis loss. However, a high effective refrigerant capacity RCeff is still maintained in La1-xRxFe11.5Si1.5. In the present samples, a large ΔSm and a high RCeff have been achieved simultaneously. © 2009 Chin. Phys. Soc. and IOP Publishing Ltd.
